column13: Tweak: Use `posix_fadvice()` in `cvmfs_swissknife sync`
column20:
This uses posix_fadvice() to tell the kernel our intentions.
Files opened by AsyncReader are flagged with FADV_WILLNEED begging the kernel for readahead into kernel caches. Just before closing AsyncReader will reflag them to FADV_DONTNEED as they can now safely be evicted.
Furthermore LocalUploader flags files with FADV_DONTNEED as they are write-once read-never and do not need to be caches extensively.

column13: Tweak: Use `posix_fadvice()` in `cvmfs_swissknife sync`
column20:
This uses posix_fadvice() to tell the kernel our intentions.
Files opened by AsyncReader are flagged with FADV_WILLNEED begging the kernel for readahead into kernel caches. Just before closing AsyncReader will reflag them to FADV_DONTNEED as they can now safely be evicted.
Furthermore LocalUploader flags files with FADV_DONTNEED as they are write-once read-never and do not need to be caches extensively.
column21:
Findings so far: There is a huge difference between man posix_fadvise and what is actually happening in the kernel. While the documentation suggests posix_fadvise() to somewhat set a "cache strategy" for a file, the actual kernel source reveals that:

POSIX_FADV_NOREUSE is a NOOP... thank you very much!
POSIX_FADV_WILLNEED is essentially a readahead() with all pros and cons
POSIX_FADV_DONTNEED is evicting pages immediately but won't change the strategy after the invocation: Hence, the pattern should be: 1. open(), 2. read()/write(), 3. posix_fadvise(), [repeat 2. and 3. ...], close().
posix_fadvise() is conservative for non-page-aligned offsets: it will rather free too little pages rather then purging useful stuff.

So taking all this into account and comparing this pull request against the latest devel on a single-core OpenStack machine with 2GiB RAM (~ 1.8G Page Cache), publishing 50.000 30kB files (~ 1.45GiB) I see a speedup of more than 3x (3:30 vs. 11:00 minutes) where the former virtually doesn't read anything from disk and the latter heavily suffers from page cache thrashing.
Bottom line: As long as the entire CernVM-FS change set fits comfortably into the page cache, we see reasonable performance. Beyond that, also this version will suffer from cache trashing.
What needs to be done:

more measurements

in particular on the test.cern.ch with zfs and more than one core


have a second look at the page alignments of the posix_fadvise() offsets
make it compile on OS X again :o)

Feature: Asynchronous Cleanup of Scratch Directory
column20:
This Pull Request is requesting for comments!
After cvmfs_server publish-ing a large change set it might take a significant time to clean-out the scratch directory (i.e. /var/spool/cvmfs/<fqrn>/scratch). This allows to run this clean-up asynchronously to allow for quicker publishing round-trips. Setting CVMFS_ASYNC_SCRATCH_CLEANUP=false disables this and reverts back to the legacy behaviour.
The general idea of this workflow is:

create current and wastebin inside /var/spool/cvmfs/<fqrn>/scratch
publish as usual (using .../scratch/current as union fs scratch directory)
umount /cvmfs/<fqrn> and /var/spool/cvmfs/<fqrn>/rdonly
move .../scratch/current into .../wastebin/waste.XXXXXX/current
create a fresh .../scratch/current
spawn daemon process asynchronously deleting everything in .../wastebin
mount /var/spool/cvmfs/<fqrn>/rdonly and /cvmfs/<fqrn>

Note that there might be multiple concurrent cvmfs_suid_helper clear_scratch_async but they should not step on each other's feet. Subject to review: Is this actually true?
Theoretically back-to-back transactions should become quicker but this effect might be mitigated due to the background process stressing the file system with the recursive delete.
Furthermore this requires a repository migration step 2.2.x --> 2.3.0 to be developed.

column21:
It's a good idea in general.  I do something similar in frontier-squid to asynchronously clear the cache.   I do it all in bash however, which seems a lot simpler than the rather extensive changes to run_suid_helper.  I can give you the details if you're interested.
I don't see anything about catching signals.  In frontier-squid I run the rm with nohup so they'll keep going after a user logs out.  I think that's important.
I suggest reversing the sense of the variable to be CVMFS_SYNC_SCRATCH_CLEANUP so it can default to false and not require a migration step.  I doubt that anybody will have a problem with the default and want to change it.

column21:
I do it all in bash however, which seems a lot simpler than the rather extensive changes to run_suid_helper.

Unfortunately we need to do it in cvmfs_suid_helper because the scratch area might contain files with skewed permissions (f.e. hidden housekeeping stuff from the union file system). The changes to this code aren't so extensive, its mostly a refactoring of the recursive delete.

I don't see anything about catching signals.

Frankly I'm not sure, but do I need to do that after a double-fork?

I suggest reversing the sense of the variable to be CVMFS_SYNC_SCRATCH_CLEANUP so it can default to false and not require a migration step.

That's a good idea. I also thought about making this more transparent. That will require a bit of extra code in cvmfs_server but perhaps it is more reasonable than the explicit migration step.
Thanks for the comments.

Furthermore I've added a cvmfs_server migrate step for the change in /var/spool/cvmfs/<repo>/scratch. We won't easily get around that, I'm afraid.

column13: Optimisation: Create/Remove Nested Catalogs
column20:
This was on my list since a long time: Disentangling the management of nested catalogs from the processing of .cvmfscatalog in SyncMediator. This might speed up snapshotting significantly in certain situations.
Up to now, a nested catalog was created as soon as cvmfs_server publish hit a .cvmfscatalog file, and removed when it found a deleted .cvmfscatalog file. Conceptually that is fine, but it might lead to many unnecessary catalog updates.
For example: Imagine a user adds a new directory release and marks it a nested catalog (i.e. release/.cvmfscatalog), furthermore she adds 150.000 files to this new directory. In the worst case, cvmfs_server publish would traverse all 150.000 files, adding them to the father catalog of release. Only in the end it would find .cvmfscatalog which forced cvmfs_server publish to split the father at release and copying all 150.000 entries to the new nested catalog.
Similarly this could happen when cvmfs_server publish first finds a deleted .cvmfscatalog file and copys-up all entries into the father just before removing all of them, because actually the entire directory was deleted.
That patch disentangles the creation of nested catalogs from the processing of .cvmfscatalog in cvmfs_server publish. That simplifies the code and also allows to do the catalog creation smarter. I.e. a newly created directory containing a .cvmfspublished file will immediate result in a new (and empty) catalog that gets filled right afterwards. Similarly a removed directory containing .cvmfspublished is deleting an empty catalog and avoids an expensive and useless copy-up.
TODO: In the latter case, it would be even better to just remove the catalog and not even bother deleting all the entries first. But with our main use case directory deletion doesn't happen too often...
Furthermore this adds a test-case to verify the catalog creation/deletion sequencing.

One thing I don't like is that there's not a way to pass a different kind of error back through MountCatalog() and Init() in catalog_mgr_impl.h.  So the caller in cvmfs.cc's Init() just reports a generic "Failed to initialize root catalog" to /var/log/messages.

column13: FIX: Reflog Update During Snapshotting
column20:
This fixes several issues with the Reflog updates during cvmfs_server snapshot. In detail:

legacy Reflog was mistakenly downloaded from Stratum0 instead of Stratum1
missed call to Uploader::TearDown() resulting in assert()
Catalogs downloaded via previous-pointer were not registered

This adds regression checks to the integration test case 577.

This adds regression checks to the integration test case 577.

column13: Feature: Reflog cleanup on Garbage Collection
column20: This cleans out Reflog entries as soon as they are swept by the garbage collection. Note that this is based on FIX: Reflog Update During Snapshotting.
column21: This cleans out Reflog entries as soon as they are swept by the garbage collection. Note that this is based on FIX: Reflog Update During Snapshotting.

column13: Feature: Swissknife Ignores Missing Reflog
column20:
This changes the Reflog handling so that a missing Reflog can be ignored by most of the cvmfs_swissknife commands. In order to do garbage collection, a Reflog must be constructed from the available Catalog and History chains first (TODO).
Both cvmfs_server mkfs and an initial cvmfs_server snapshot will drop an empty Reflog to be filled opportunistically for new repositories and replicas.
column21:
This changes the Reflog handling so that a missing Reflog can be ignored by most of the cvmfs_swissknife commands. In order to do garbage collection, a Reflog must be constructed from the available Catalog and History chains first (TODO).
Both cvmfs_server mkfs and an initial cvmfs_server snapshot will drop an empty Reflog to be filled opportunistically for new repositories and replicas.

column13: Feature: Regenerate Reflog from Available Catalog and History Chains
column20:
This should be the final building block of the Reflog business. It introduces a new cvmfs_swissknife command (i.e. recreate_reflog) that walks as much of the root Catalog and History chains as possible to reconstruct the Reflog.
The use case is two fold: 1st it allows for an easy transition from the old-style garbage collection to the Reflog driven version and 2nd it serves as a failure recovery mechanism in case the original Reflog has been corrupted. We cannot guarantee that a full Reflog is reconstructable from the stored Catalog and History chains but this gives some best-effort.
Furthermore this contains a minor syslog logging fix which I was too lazy to extract. Also it adapts integration test 563 "Garbage Collection After Legacy Repository Import" to specifically check for the new feature along with CernVM-FS 2.0.x catalogs.
Note: This builds on top of FIX: Reflog Update During Snapshotting, Feature: Reflog cleanup on Garbage Collection and Feature: Swissknife Ignores Missing Reflog.

We cannot guarantee that a full Reflog is reconstructable from the stored Catalog and History chains but this gives some best-effort.
Furthermore this contains a minor syslog logging fix which I was too lazy to extract. Also it adapts integration test 563 "Garbage Collection After Legacy Repository Import" to specifically check for the new feature along with CernVM-FS 2.0.x catalogs.
Note: This builds on top of FIX: Reflog Update During Snapshotting, Feature: Reflog cleanup on Garbage Collection and Feature: Swissknife Ignores Missing Reflog.

column13: FIX: Catalog Migration not Updating Catalog Metadata
column20:
Turns out that all but the CernVM-FS 2.0.x catalog migrations didn't update the catalog meta information (i.e. previous revision pointer, revision number and last modified timestamp). Hence, catalog revisions generated by cvmfs_swissknife migrate -v [2.1.7 | chown | hardlink] logically "replaced" their base revision instead of creating an identical new catalog revision.
Unfortunately this is a bug that made it into production (at least at CERN we've been using cvmfs_server catalog-chown when moving to new release manager machines). As far as I can tell, this should not be critical though (apart from a catalog revision that is not garbage collectable anymore). I found this bug by chance when writing an integration test for Reflog.
This integrates a few regression checks in integration tests 519, 589 and 599 and fixes the problem. Furthermore the integration test 629 introduced 563 as changed here is sensitive to this bug when using OverlayFS.
column21:
Turns out that all but the CernVM-FS 2.0.x catalog migrations didn't update the catalog meta information (i.e. previous revision pointer, revision number and last modified timestamp). Hence, catalog revisions generated by cvmfs_swissknife migrate -v [2.1.7 | chown | hardlink] logically "replaced" their base revision instead of creating an identical new catalog revision.
Unfortunately this is a bug that made it into production (at least at CERN we've been using cvmfs_server catalog-chown when moving to new release manager machines). As far as I can tell, this should not be critical though (apart from a catalog revision that is not garbage collectable anymore). I found this bug by chance when writing an integration test for Reflog.
This integrates a few regression checks in integration tests 519, 589 and 599 and fixes the problem. Furthermore the integration test 629 introduced 563 as changed here is sensitive to this bug when using OverlayFS.

column13: Refactor: Health Check and Namespacing in `cvmfs_server`
column20:
This introduces several refactorings to cvmfs_server preparing for the integration of the cvmfs_server mount command. In detail:

namespace the cvmfs_server command functions (i.e. mkfs() --> cvmfs_server_mkfs()) to avoid clashes with standard system functions (i.e. mount()).
minor cosmetic fixes and protected methods (i.e. _migrate_<base>())
Restructuring of health_check() to disentangle status discovery, status message printing and mount point repairs
health_check() takes proper command line parameters
mount point repair must be explicitly requested with health_check -r
Add status messages to syslog

Trying to umount /cvmfs/${name}... [success|fail]
Trying to umount ${CVMFS_SPOOL_DIR}/rdonly... [success|fail]
Trying to mount /cvmfs/${name}... [success|fail]
Trying to mount ${CVMFS_SPOOL_DIR}/rdonly... [success|fail]
Trying to remount /cvmfs/${name} read/write... [success|fail]
Trying to remount /cvmfs/${name} read-only... [success|fail]
attempting mountpoint repair (<problem vector>)
finished mountpoint repair (<solved problem vector>)



The <problem vector> currently consists of five binary flags. Those are meant for debugging, thus they are not translated into human-readable outputs. In contrast the status messages printed to stderr are human readable (see __hc_print_status_report()).
The <problem vector> flags indicate (in this order):

Read-only mount point broken (CernVM-FS at .../spool/.../rdonly not mounted)
Read-only mount point outdated ( .../spool/.../rdonly reflects outdated root catalog)
Union file system mount point broken
Union file system mount point should be read-only but is not
Union file system mount point should be read/write but is not

Since there are some minor changes in the printed status messages, the pull request contains some updates to the associated integration test 582.
Note: Feature: Asynchronous Cleanup of Scratch Directory infrastructure migration step needs to be updated accordingly to reflect the protected cosmetics introduced here (i.e. migrate_2_2_0() --> _migrate_2_2_0()).

column13: FIX: Remove Usage of SSLv3_client_method() in libcurl
column20: This disables SSLv3 in the libcurl version we are currently using. As of OpenSSL 1.0.2g SSLv3 is disabled on Ubuntu 15.10 which prevents a successful build of CernVM-FS. The OpenSSL ABI didn't change, hence this doesn't affect our released binaries. This patch will most likely become obsolete when we update our libcurl version.

column13: Feature: `cvmfs_server mount [-a]` retrofitted to CernVM-FS 2.2
column20:
That retrofits the cvmfs_server mount [-a] feature to CernVM-FS 2.2. Refactoring of health_check() is omitted and the mount name clash is worked around rather than doing full cvmfs_server subcommand namespacing (#1549). This happens at the expense of a verbose and less concise status/error logging when running cvmfs_server mount.
Note that this also cherry-picks and adapts integration test 630 as well as the bash completion.

column13: Block Repository Migration in Transaction
column20:
This prevents a cvmfs_server migrate to run on a repository that is in a transaction. If a user runs into this situation he probably updated the CernVM-FS server software with an open transaction from the previous version. That might result in data loss, depending on what actions the cvmfs_server migrate performs (see 2.2.0 --> 2.3.0 step for example).
Furthermore this adds a pre-install check to both RPM and debian package that prevents their install if an open transaction on one of the hosted Stratum0s is detected.
Finally this adds the upcoming CernVM-FS 2.2.2 release version to the migration paths.

Finally this adds the upcoming CernVM-FS 2.2.2 release version to the migration paths.

column13: Feature: Upload to LevelDB
column20:
This is a first step to allow storage of CernVM-FS repositories inside one (or many) LevelDB databases. For the moment, it should be seen as a proof of concept. Note: This builds on top of Refactor: Eliminate some Code duplications in Uploaders.
Some details:

adds AbstractUploader implementation: LevelDbUploader
new SpoolerDefinition for LevelDB of the form: leveldb,<tmp path>,<config file>
understood LevelDB configuration variables:

CVMFS_LEVELDB_STORAGE - base path where the LevelDB(s) are stored
CVMFS_LEVELDB_COUNT - number of LevelDBs to shard object files into
CVMFS_LEVELDB_COMPRESSION - either snappy or none by default



TODO:

 error handling through AbstractUploader::GetNumberOfErrors()
 AbstractUploader::PlaceBootstrappingShortcuts() not implemented (.cvmfsalt-...)
 Apache-based read-end

column13: Tuning: Speed up Catalog Updates during Publish
column20:
This removes inefficiencies from the catalog update code during publishing. Profiling of these code paths revealed that path lookups and nested catalog discovery happened more often than necessary. Especially for large change sets and many touched nested catalogs we see a significant penalty.
In certain workloads one can expect a 25% speedup for the catalog updates as seen in the chart below (blue = before, green = after). This is meta-data updates per seconds over number of inserted directory entries (measured on my dev machine).

I'll put a more detailed comments into the patch itself.

column13: FIX: Pull Retry Logic
column20:
This fixes a problem in the retry logic of cvmfs_server snapshot that was introduced because of a misunderstood coverity issue.

Some code forensics for the sake of it:
Once upon a time in the old days of CernVM-FS in 2012 @jblomer implemented some retry logic (all together with backoff and timeout) directly in cvmfs_swissknife pull.
This was superseded by a retry logic implementation in an ancient "download module" while leaving parts of the old hard-coded logic in place. Later the "download module" was replaced by a local DownloadManager object but this brave piece of retry logic survived. While the years were passing the DownloadManager object moved from cvmfs_swissknife pull scope into global and later became managed by the swissknife::Command base class, but the little piece of code stayed with us in silence.
It didn't do anything useful since the beginning of 2013, but after I blindly removed the "logically dead" condition "that could never be true", Coverity was talking about, the remainings of the little hard-coded retry logic unleashed its power and downloaded each and every file three times. Fortunately this was never released, but it tells the tale of KISS.
Thanks for reading.
column21:
This fixes a problem in the retry logic of cvmfs_server snapshot that was introduced because of a misunderstood coverity issue.

Once upon a time in the old days of CernVM-FS in 2012 @jblomer implemented some retry logic (all together with backoff and timeout) directly in cvmfs_swissknife pull.
This was superseded by a retry logic implementation in an ancient "download module" while leaving parts of the old hard-coded logic in place. Later the "download module" was replaced by a local DownloadManager object but this brave piece of retry logic survived. While the years were passing the DownloadManager object moved from cvmfs_swissknife pull scope into global and later became managed by the swissknife::Command base class, but the little piece of code stayed with us in silence.
It didn't do anything useful since the beginning of 2013, but after I blindly removed the "logically dead" condition "that could never be true", Coverity was talking about, the remainings of the little hard-coded retry logic unleashed its power and downloaded each and every file three times. Fortunately this was never released, but it tells the tale of KISS.
Thanks for reading.

column13: FIX/Feature: cvmfs client-side authorization
column20:
Another round for the authorization.  Apologies for the large number of changes.  @bbockelm Apologies for screwing up git blame; all the meat is a copy & paste of your code, it just turned out to be easier to use the editor than git commands.
Principal change is a better separation between the cvmfs client and the authorization helper, including a well-defined interface between the two. The authorization helper executable needs to be defined in CVMFS_AUTHZ_HELPER.  Actually we might want to be smarter and define a naming convention to automatically deduct the authorization helper from the authz string in the catalog.  Currently there is of course only one (X.509 proxy) but we might see others in the future. @bbockelm, what do you think?
The new helper cvmfs_x509_helper also comes with its own spec file so that it can be developed and deployed independently from cvmfs (e.g. faster).
I'm still wondering if we want to have a dedicated audit log (different from debug log, syslog), to log all authorization relevant events.  In particular successful/failed authorizations, of course.
Regarding the interface: the helper gets spawned by the cvmfs client with stdin/stdout connected.  There is a command/reply style of messages.  Messages have a 4 byte version (=1), a 4 byte length, and then a JSON text that needs to contain the top-level struct cvmfs_authz_v1 { ... }.  Communication starts with a handshake where the client passes logging parameters to the authz helper.  The client then sends zero or more authorization requests that are answered by a positive or negative permit each that includes the access token for positive permits (in this case: X.509 proxy).  The permits are cached by the client with a TTL that the helper can chose.  On unmount, the client sends a quit command to the helper.
The download manager got an abstract interface of a class that can perform per-transfer surgery on CURL handles.  This way, the download manager does not need to know about authz internals.
All in all, I don't think we can make this modification part of a bugfix release with a clear conscience.  Once we are all happy with the code and have it merged, I'd suggest to have a phone call on release plans.  I'd much rather make a 2.3 feature release before Q4/16 and move the remaining tasks to version 2.4.

column21:
Two thoughts:

I had always planned to provide a prefix of some sort (x509:/DC=ch/DC=.../CN=Brian versus voms:/cms versus oauth2:some-great-authz) in the future.  If we are already doing this much work, we might as well add it now.  I assume we ought to ignore prefixes that are not understood and fall back to the current logic for things starting with /?
I agree it's becoming a bit disingenuous to call this a bugfix (although it certainly does fix a bug...).  On the other hand, I really need something I can deliver to LIGO relatively soon.  I was hoping to start scaling up the use in the summer, meaning we're already late.  Could we branch 2.3 now, mostly consisting of this feature?

Another round for the authorization.  Apologies for the large number of changes.  @bbockelm Apologies for screwing up git blame; all the meat is a copy & paste of your code, it just turned out to be easier to use the editor than git commands.
Principal change is a better separation between the cvmfs client and the authorization helper, including a well-defined interface between the two. The authorization helper executable needs to be defined in CVMFS_AUTHZ_HELPER.  Actually we might want to be smarter and define a naming convention to automatically deduct the authorization helper from the authz string in the catalog.  Currently there is of course only one (X.509 proxy) but we might see others in the future. @bbockelm, what do you think?
The new helper cvmfs_x509_helper also comes with its own spec file so that it can be developed and deployed independently from cvmfs (e.g. faster).
I'm still wondering if we want to have a dedicated audit log (different from debug log, syslog), to log all authorization relevant events.  In particular successful/failed authorizations, of course.
Regarding the interface: the helper gets spawned by the cvmfs client with stdin/stdout connected.  There is a command/reply style of messages.  Messages have a 4 byte version (=1), a 4 byte length, and then a JSON text that needs to contain the top-level struct cvmfs_authz_v1 { ... }.  Communication starts with a handshake where the client passes logging parameters to the authz helper.  The client then sends zero or more authorization requests that are answered by a positive or negative permit each that includes the access token for positive permits (in this case: X.509 proxy).  The permits are cached by the client with a TTL that the helper can chose.  On unmount, the client sends a quit command to the helper.
The download manager got an abstract interface of a class that can perform per-transfer surgery on CURL handles.  This way, the download manager does not need to know about authz internals.
All in all, I don't think we can make this modification part of a bugfix release with a clear conscience.  Once we are all happy with the code and have it merged, I'd suggest to have a phone call on release plans.  I'd much rather make a 2.3 feature release before Q4/16 and move the remaining tasks to version 2.4.

(gdb) up 1
#4  0x0000000000404437 in ParseRequest (
    msg="{\"cvmfs_authz_v1\":{\"msgid\":2,\"revision\":0,\"uid\":1221,\"gid\":10058,\"pid\":1955911,\"membership\":\"/DC=es/DC=irisgrid/O=uib/CN=alicia.sintes\n/DC=org/DC=cilogon/C=US/O=LIGO/CN=Alicia Sintes alicia.sintes@lig"...) at /home/cse496/bbockelm/projects/cvmfs/cvmfs/authz/x509_helper.cc:128
128   assert((json != NULL) && (json->first_child != NULL));
(gdb) p json
$1 = (JSON *) 0x0
(gdb) p msg
$2 = "{\"cvmfs_authz_v1\":{\"msgid\":2,\"revision\":0,\"uid\":1221,\"gid\":10058,\"pid\":1955911,\"membership\":\"/DC=es/DC=irisgrid/O=uib/CN=alicia.sintes\n/DC=org/DC=cilogon/C=US/O=LIGO/CN=Alicia Sintes alicia.sintes@lig"...

column21: As for the zombie: the failure handling is currently very simple.  Whenever something goes wrong, the cvmfs client puts the helper in "fail state" and doesn't do any authz anymore.  It will call wait eventually but you need to cvmfs_config reload the client (or unmount).

column21: For checking the call context: the client now exports CVMFS_AUTHZ_HELPER=yes when starting the authz helper.  This is used on the helper end to determine the call context instead of testing file descriptor 2.

column21: I'm not sure if I got the automatic authz helper discovery right.  The way it works now is that the everything before the first colon is treated as an "authz schema".  Cvmfs then looks for /usr/libexec/cvmfs/authz/cvmfs_<authz_schema>_helper.  The helper will receive the authz string with the schema stripped.

column21:
Hm - on further examination, I'm not sure the authz helper discovery approach is right.  Take an illustrative subset of the LIGO repo:
/DC=org/DC=cilogon/C=US/O=LIGO/CN=foo
/DC=org/DC=cilogon/C=US/O=LIGO/CN=bar
osg:/osg/ligo
LIGO:/ligo

So, there's a mix of VOMS extensions and X509 DNs (note the VOMS entries require a : character).
I was thinking we could upgrade this to something like this:
x509:/DC=org/DC=cilogon/C=US/O=LIGO/CN=foo
x509:/DC=org/DC=cilogon/C=US/O=LIGO/CN=bar
x509:osg:/osg/ligo
x509:LIGO:/ligo

Which then allows us to add lines of the form:
krb5:foo@FNAL.GOV
oauth2:baz

However, the current system doesn't really allow mixing auth types inside a single auth list.  I would be OK with maybe backing out b7af054 and saving this for later.

column21:
Couldn't we prefix the multi-line authz string once with x509?  The colon as a separator is indeed a bit confusing, how about a pipe instead, i.e.
x509|/DC=org/DC=cilogon/C=US/O=LIGO/CN=foo
/DC=org/DC=cilogon/C=US/O=LIGO/CN=bar
osg:/osg/ligo
LIGO:/ligo

If we later want to mix authz schemes, we can introduce a multi scheme with a corresponding helper that takes care of the dispatching.

The permits are cached by the client with a TTL that the helper can chose.  On unmount, the client sends a quit command to the helper.
The download manager got an abstract interface of a class that can perform per-transfer surgery on CURL handles.  This way, the download manager does not need to know about authz internals.
All in all, I don't think we can make this modification part of a bugfix release with a clear conscience.  Once we are all happy with the code and have it merged, I'd suggest to have a phone call on release plans.  I'd much rather make a 2.3 feature release before Q4/16 and move the remaining tasks to version 2.4.
column21: I switched to % as a separator, the pipe is a pain given all the bash code in the server.

column13: FIX/Feature: cvmfs client-side authorization
column20:
Another round for the authorization.  Apologies for the large number of changes.  @bbockelm Apologies for screwing up git blame; all the meat is a copy & paste of your code, it just turned out to be easier to use the editor than git commands.
Principal change is a better separation between the cvmfs client and the authorization helper, including a well-defined interface between the two. The authorization helper executable needs to be defined in CVMFS_AUTHZ_HELPER.  Actually we might want to be smarter and define a naming convention to automatically deduct the authorization helper from the authz string in the catalog.  Currently there is of course only one (X.509 proxy) but we might see others in the future. @bbockelm, what do you think?
The new helper cvmfs_x509_helper also comes with its own spec file so that it can be developed and deployed independently from cvmfs (e.g. faster).
I'm still wondering if we want to have a dedicated audit log (different from debug log, syslog), to log all authorization relevant events.  In particular successful/failed authorizations, of course.
Regarding the interface: the helper gets spawned by the cvmfs client with stdin/stdout connected.  There is a command/reply style of messages.  Messages have a 4 byte version (=1), a 4 byte length, and then a JSON text that needs to contain the top-level struct cvmfs_authz_v1 { ... }.  Communication starts with a handshake where the client passes logging parameters to the authz helper.  The client then sends zero or more authorization requests that are answered by a positive or negative permit each that includes the access token for positive permits (in this case: X.509 proxy).  The permits are cached by the client with a TTL that the helper can chose.  On unmount, the client sends a quit command to the helper.
The download manager got an abstract interface of a class that can perform per-transfer surgery on CURL handles.  This way, the download manager does not need to know about authz internals.
All in all, I don't think we can make this modification part of a bugfix release with a clear conscience.  Once we are all happy with the code and have it merged, I'd suggest to have a phone call on release plans.  I'd much rather make a 2.3 feature release before Q4/16 and move the remaining tasks to version 2.4.

Tidy up initialization/finalization code
column20:
Improvements to the boot/destruct code in cvmfs.  Much of the work done in cvmfs.cc:Init() went into two new classes, FileSystem and MountPoint.  The FileSystem constructs the global state of the client (e.g. sqlite settings) and initializes the cache directory and cache manager.  The MountPoint initializes all the manager classes necessary to access a cvmfs repository.  There can only be one FileSystem but multiple MountPoints.  This follows the approach of libcvmfs.  Application of the new classes to libcvmfs follows in another PR.
Advantages:

Much of the initialization/finalization code can be unit tested
Long functions broke down into smaller functions, making it somewhat easier to read/change
Opens the possibility to remove duplication in fuse and libcvmfs code; in the future, libcvmfs should benefit by default from new options
Preparation for new use cases of cvmfs, in particular mounting underneath the docker daemon

A few issues were fixed along the way:

Mount with a CVMFS_SERVER_URL with a file://... url
Small memory leak
Compiler warnings
Use the cache for fetching history database on mount

Initial implementation of a tiered cache.
column20:
This implementation provides a hierarchical write-through cache. It allows a site to setup a local disk cache in addition to a site-wide alien cache.
I envision this to be useful in two cases:

The performance of the alien cache (or, in the future, object storage) is better than a HTTP proxy setup because the underlying storage system allows several storage servers to peer.
When the repository is a secure CVMFS repo, as secure repos cannot be used with HTTP proxies.

No tests provided at this point - I just want to make sure this is the correct approach, coding-wise (plus push things through Travis-CI).

Add micro-benchmark framework
column20:
Add Google benchmark framework together with a few micro benchmarks to cvmfs.  The micro benchmarks are only compiled on request (cmake -DBUILD_UBENCHMARKS=yes) and the google benchmark library is downloaded on demand and compiled using a specific commit hash.  Use of micro benchmarks is similar to use of unit tests.  Requires a C++11 compiler, i.e. CC7 or newer.
This allows us to maintain a set of benchmarks for critical operations in cvmfs, such as compression, hashing, central data structures, IPC.  We can use the results to

Improve our intuition about the speed of things
Break down coarse-grained benchmarks in time spent in individual code paths
Fine-grained measurement of performance improvements of individual code paths
Decide for one or another implementation of a data structure if in doubt
Quickly benchmark a new platform
Derive lower limits of how long things take; e.g. publishing files can't be faster than compression + hashing

column13: Fix errno constant name
Use FileSystem and MountPoint classes to initialize libcvmfs
column20:
Unifies libcvmfs and fuse module's initialization and deconstruction code.  It gives libcvmfs access to all the options of the fuse module under the same key/value names.  It also provides the fuse modules (more precise) error codes.
To do so, access to the OptionsManager class is provided by a number of cvmfs_options_...() functions.  The cvmfs_init() and cvmfs_attach_repo() routines are now considered legacy and should be replaced by calls to cvmfs_init_v2() and cvmfs_attach_repo_v2().
Documentation of the libcvmfs public header is updated.
New cvmfs parameters were added for libcvmfs (but are now also recognized by the fuse module): CVMFS_CACHE_DIR, CVMFS_WORKSPACE, CVMFS_CWD_CACHE, CVMFS_SYSLOG_PREFIX, CVMFS_BLACKLIST

Feature o1 fds
column20: I changed the routines for opening/closing file descriptors in the RAM cache to O(1) and switched to fixed allocation of fds. An index of used/free fds is necessary, and each ReadOnlyFd needs to know its position in the fd index, increasing the memory use by ~2 ints/fd. I was also able to remove some unneeded fields from ReadOnlyFd.

column20: The parameter CVMFS_AUTO_TAG_TIMESPAN, which can be also set during cvmfs_server mkfs, allows to set a limit for the age of auto tags.  During every publish, auto tags older than the limit are automatically removed.  Like the garbage collection timespan, this parameter accepts everything that date can parse, for instance "4 weeks ago".

Custom allocator for in-memory object cache
column20:
A "heap allocator" for the RAM cache.  It mmap's one large chunk on construction and stays within this chunk.  It is copying (compacting), i.e. when the cache gets cleaned up, the surviving blocks will be compacted.  In effect, this allocator is  supposed to provide optimal utilization.
The cost is that every blocks needs to be prepended with an identifier that allows the user of this allocator to fix the pointers when it comes to a Compact().  For the RAM cache, it means that both content hash and content need to be stored in memory.  For average object sizes of 4k, the waste is still below the percent level.

Feature heapcache
column20:
I added another allocator for the RAM cache, and can run the ATLAS benchmark on it. The config key is
CVMFS_CACHE_RAM_MALLOC=heap

It uses the log-structured allocator @jblomer recently added. Since the new allocator needs to have id headers and know about all pointers to allocations, making the transactions call into the KvStore's allocator was proving troublesome. This PR makes a clean separation between the scratch memory for transactions (obtained via libc's malloc) and the KvStore allocated memory. Since transactions should either succeed or fail quickly, lingering allocations that other allocators address shouldn't be a problem. For a shared cache, this separation also fits, since it might not be possible to directly allocate memory through the KvStore.

column21:
Perhaps I'm overlooking something but it looks to me that we still could use the key-value store for open transactions, too.  We could add a Write method to the store and set a flag in the header byte that indicates if a block is committed or in a transaction.  It would cost us more lookup calls during a transaction but we would save the memory copy on commit.
Hm, but you are right that for the distributed case it might make more sense to fill a staging buffer before storing things in the key-value store.  In fact, most distributed key-value stores have a hard limit on the object size at around 1MB.  So I guess what we really want is multi-part objects in the key-value store.  The key would then be a concatenation of the hash and the part number. But I think that's for another pull request.
So let's stay with the sepration of the staging area and the key-value store maintained memory for the moment.

column13: Fix publishing of auto catalog markers (CVM-1079)
Fix error reporting when downloading replication sentinal file (CVM-1078)
Tiered cache manager (work in progress)
column20:
Based on #1615, a few fixes and additions.  Among them

There was a subtle problem with the lower cache tier: during a transactional write, the cache manager gets to know the path in /cvmfs that triggers addition of the object and the object type (catalog, regular file, ...).  This is information is lost during copy-up.  The cache manager interface is now changed: to open an object, the content hash needs to be "blessed" with the additional information.  This information is available at the time of open.
Simple unit test and integration test.  I think eventually we should run all client tests with several cache manager options.
Removal of the (rather unnecessary) cache namespace.
Virtual open file descriptors (as needed for the RAM cache and later the external cache) are factored out as independent data structure.

Missing is a proper configuraton of the cache manager(s), as discussed in CVM-1053.
The biggest hurdle I see with reloading/hotpatching support.  Clients need to save and restore their state.  For the traditional cache manager, that's easy because the open files are maintained by the OS for the cvmfs process.  For other cache managers, we need to ensure that the state of open files survies a reload.

Add support for handling special files when using OverlayFS
column20:
This commit fixes the problem with publishing a transaction
when there are special files added to the repository
and OverlayFS is used as a UnionFS driver.
Whiteout files in OverlayFS are represented as character devices
with both major and minor numbers 0. OverlayFS driver doesn't allow
users to create such files.
Both block and character devices will be ignored with a warning message
printed out.
A new SyncItemType is introduced: kBlockDevice
SyncItem has 4 new methods:

GetMajor
GetMinor
IsBlockDevice
IsSpecialFile

Handling special files may change in future in the following ways:

fail by default, enable explicitly in config to ignore with warning
add special files to the repo

Add configuration variable to enable ignoring special files
column20:
This change preserves old behavior for working with special files (stop publishing by default).
The configuration variable CVMFS_IGNORE_SPECIAL_FILES is introduced.
When this variable is set to true, special files will be ignored with and a warning message will be printed for each of them.
Otherwise, on first encounter of a special file (which is not a whiteout) a warning message will also be printed, but publishing will stop.

column13: Refactor cvmfs server
column20:
This branch contains an attempt to simplify the cvmfs_server script.
I'm putting this here to do review and keep track of the chages, but it's not ready to be merged.
The idea is to split the script (~6770 lines) into sub-scripts that each contain the functionality related to each command (transaction, abort, publish etc.). Common functionality of these scripts is also factored out into separate scripts. The main script should only do some minimal setup of the environment and source the other scripts. Subscripts are placed in the cvmfs/server subdirectory.
Current status:

 Added cvmfs/server/cvmfs_server_util.sh and cvmfs/server/cvmfs_server_common.sh scripts, containing simple utility functions and, respectively, larger functions used by the different subcommands
 Transaction, publish and abort subcommands have been factored out into the cvmfs/server/cvmfs_server_{transaction,publish,abort}.sh files.
 Finish factoring out of remaining subcommands into separate scripts.
 Deployment: the new multi-script program should be re-assembled into a single script for deployment, for convenience. A new make_cvmfs_server script can be added to assemble all the components for deployment
 Testing: must ensure that the new script behaves the same as the old one. There should be no regressions in the integration tests.
 Update Cmake scripts to use the make_cvmfs_server script

column13: Refactor cvmfs server
column20:
This branch contains an attempt to simplify the cvmfs_server script.
I'm putting this here to do review and keep track of the chages, but it's not ready to be merged.
The idea is to split the script (~6770 lines) into sub-scripts that each contain the functionality related to each command (transaction, abort, publish etc.). Common functionality of these scripts is also factored out into separate scripts. The main script should only do some minimal setup of the environment and source the other scripts. Subscripts are placed in the cvmfs/server subdirectory.
Current status:

 Added cvmfs/server/cvmfs_server_util.sh and cvmfs/server/cvmfs_server_common.sh scripts, containing simple utility functions and, respectively, larger functions used by the different subcommands
 Transaction, publish and abort subcommands have been factored out into the cvmfs/server/cvmfs_server_{transaction,publish,abort}.sh files.
 Finish factoring out of remaining subcommands into separate scripts.
 Deployment: the new multi-script program should be re-assembled into a single script for deployment, for convenience. A new make_cvmfs_server script can be added to assemble all the components for deployment
 Testing: must ensure that the new script behaves the same as the old one. There should be no regressions in the integration tests.
 Update Cmake scripts to use the make_cvmfs_server script

column13: Generator for .cvmfs directory providing access to named snapshots (CVM-1062)
column20:
Adds a VirtualCatalog class that can be used to generate a (nested) subcatalog /.cvmfs.  Creation and removal of the catalog is steered by the CVMFS_VIRTUAL_DIR server parameter.  The directory /.cvmfs/snapshots loads previous root catalogs as named snapshots.
To do this, the catalog revision was bumped to indicate newly added support for

hidden directory entries (.cvmfs) that do not appear in (file system) listings
"Bind mountpoints" table, that allows to distinguish between genuine nested catalogs and foreign catalogs linked in the directory hierarchy
A "bind mountpoint" flag for the directory representing the transition point

Little bit of refactoring to clearly distinguish between a catalog's root prefix and it's path in the mount hierarchy.
The implementation is backwards compatible in so far as older clients don't hide the .cvmfs directory but they treat the snapshot directories as empty directories.  Replication should be unaffected.

column20:
Some refactoring to the cvmfs_server scripts for better maintainability:

Split platform dependent functions to cvmfs_server_sys.sh, for example: calling the uname command, checking for files etc.
Updated the rest of the cvmfs_server_***** scripts to call the encapsulated functions (instead of calling uname directly, call cmvfs_sys_uname ...)
Added example test script for the check_overlayfs_version function, using mocking
Updated the cvmfs_overlay_version function to accept kernel 3.10.0-493 or newer, on RedHat. This change is required for ticket CVM-835 and will be backported there.

column13: Updated OverlayFS for RedHat 7 (CVM-835)
column20:
This branch:

 Updates the function check_overlayfs_version in cvmfs_server. The new success condition is either kernel 4.2.0 or newer on all Linux distributions, or, if running RedHat, kernel 3.10.0-493 or newer AND /var/spool/cvmfs should be located on an ext4 partition.
 Updates the integration test scripts to run the server tests on RedHat (CentOS) 7, setting up /var/spool/cvmfs on an ext4 partition.

New `swissknife_lease` command to work with repository leases
column20:
This PR implements the resolution to JIRA ticket CVM-1130.
The new swissknife_lease command is used to acquire a new repository lease from a running instance of the CVMFS repository services and also to drop an existing repository lease.
When a new lease is obtained, the session token associated with the lease is written in the file /var/spool/cvmfs/<REPO_NAME>/session_token. This session token is used for all future requests associated with this lease.

column21:
Hi!
The CI failure on MacOS is due to Travis removing old OSX images. We ask for 7.1 (internal Travis version number) and we get routed to 7.3.1, where we don't need to install cmake. To fix this issue, the .travis.yml file in the devel branch needs to be backported into the 2.3 branch.
This is just a quick fix, however. In January I've planned some work to ensure that we are again able to build on the latest version of MacOS - we are now building on OSX Yosemite 10.10, due to the removal of OpenSSL headers in 10.11 and 10.12. One this is done, this should make our Travis jobs and the entire MacOS build and packaging process more reliable.

column21: It's possible, but then we'd be setting a new precedent and would need to move at least .cvmfs_last_snapshot information also into repositories.json.   Writing to repositories.json would have to be made more robust, setting a lock and reading prior information at the end of every successful snapshot or gc, as opposed to generating it from scratch at every repo creation or removal.

column13: Add .cvmfs_last_gc timestamp file (CVM-1107)

column13: Add .cvmfs_last_gc timestamp file (CVM-1107)
column21:
What about the case where the repositories are owned by non-root users?  Then /srv/cvmfs/info would have to be writable by those users.  You're OK with that new requirement?  Typically on a stratum 1 they would all be one user, but on a stratum 0 there could definitely be multiple owners that could run a gc for their repository.  /srv/cvmfs/info would have to be world writable, or it would have to be done through cvmfs_suid_helper.
What if the upstream storage is not a local disk?  How would repositories.json be locked?  I suppose the lock could go in /var/spool/cvmfs, but how would we handle permissions so that all owners on a stratum 0 could lock and write to this file?
This looks to me like a can of worms, probably more than I would be willing to take on personally.  It would be too much for anyone for 2.3.3, I think.

column13: Add .cvmfs_last_gc timestamp file (CVM-1107)
column21: On the other hand if we added a per-repo json file to keep all such status information it would be a lot easier.  There's already code to prevent more than one publish or gc from happening on a given repo at a time, and one of my other pending pull requests prevents snapshots and gcs from happening at the same time.  No extra locking would need to be done, and no permissions complications.

column13: Fix builds with the Ninja generator
column20:
Ninja is an optional CMake generator; ninja focuses on speed and parallelism.  For example, calling ninja-build on a fully-built directory (meaning there is no actual buildign to do) returns in 50ms.
This commit allows CVMFS to be built using Ninja with the following changes:

Ninja requires all dependencies to be declared a-priori.  The libtbb target previously declared it output a single library but had several others created as a side-effect.  cvmfs_swissknife dependency on those other libraries, but Ninja didn't know how to create them.  Seems to be stricter than GNU make in this respect.
Ninja creates output directories that are not already present.  This breaks the TBB build as the output directory is created as a symlink during the libtbb target.
cvmfs_server dependencies aren't exposed to CMakeLists; this explicitly declares the dependency so the cvmfs_server script doesn't have to be regenerated each time.
column21:
Ninja is an optional CMake generator; ninja focuses on speed and parallelism.  For example, calling ninja-build on a fully-built directory (meaning there is no actual buildign to do) returns in 50ms.
This commit allows CVMFS to be built using Ninja with the following changes:

Ninja requires all dependencies to be declared a-priori.  The libtbb target previously declared it output a single library but had several others created as a side-effect.  cvmfs_swissknife dependency on those other libraries, but Ninja didn't know how to create them.  Seems to be stricter than GNU make in this respect.
Ninja creates output directories that are not already present.  This breaks the TBB build as the output directory is created as a symlink during the libtbb target.
cvmfs_server dependencies aren't exposed to CMakeLists; this explicitly declares the dependency so the cvmfs_server script doesn't have to be regenerated each time.

column13: Fix linking error of c-ares on CentOS 7.3
column20:
This addresses the linking error encoutered when building the c-ares dependency on CentOS 7.3 (CVM-1153). The error appears when linking some c-ares internal executables (ahost, acountry etc.) and causes the entire CVMFS process to fail.
The problem was not present on CentOS 7.2, but it stems from the fact that CVMFS passes some additional C and C++ compiler flags when building its external dependencies. I suspect most of these are needed to ensure consistency of the resulting CVMFS binary. The flag -fvisibility=hidden is an exception, since one cannot impose this on an external library. If the library does not have visibility annotations for the symbols of its API, this flag will make it impossible to use the library as a shared object.
This PR is for the CVMFS 2.3 branch, I'm preparing a separate PR for the devel branch, since the changes cannot just be cherry-picked, due to some refactoring that happened in the meantime.

I just checked the .travis.yml configuration on the cvmfs-2.3 and the devel branches. On cvmfs-2.3 we have selected the OS X image 7.1 which doesn't exist any more, while on the devel branch we use 6.4 (!) which will be retired this Friday.
At that point we will no longer have any way to compile for Mac on Travis, until we fix the OpenSSL issue.

column13: Fix typo in cmake invocation

Use LibreSSL on macOS (CVM-1112)
column20:
This PR addresses ticket CVM-1112, making it possible to build CVMFS on macOS 10.11 and newer, which no longer ship with public OpenSSL library and headers.
Changes:

On macOS (only), LibreSSL is used. It's compiled and linked at build time, like the other dependencies.
We are only using the LibreSSL static libraries (libssl.a, libcrypto.a)
libcurl is also linked with LibreSSL, on macOS

The modifications introduced here are not activated on Linux; there we always use the system version of OpenSSL.
Tested on macOS 10.10, 10.12 and on Linux (Ubuntu 16.04).

column13: Improvements to external dependency management (CVM-1161)
column20:
This branch introduces a series of improvements to the scripts that build external dependencies and to the CMake configuration files that handle the externals.
Summary:

bootstrap.sh has be modified. It's called at the beginning of the CMake configuration process, as before, but it will now configure and build all the external dependencies at once. Building them is no longer delayed until the CVMFS build phase. This makes it simpler to understand the external build process
After being built, the external libraries are all installed under the same prefix, by default ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/externals_install. This means that they can easily be used by multiple builds of CVMFS, if desired. The location of the external libs can be set using the EXTERNALS_PREFIX CMake variable.
It's possible to disable using built-in external libraries by giving the BUILTIN_EXTERNALS=OFF parameter to CMake.
At the end of the external build process, the file $EXTERNALS_INSTALL_LOCATION/.bootstrapDone contains a list of all the externals that are present. By default, the bootstrap.sh script will not recompile any library listed here. To force the recompilation of any of them, simply remove their name from the file and re-run the CMake configuration for CVMFS.
Various simplifications of the CMake configurations scrips:

When BUILTIN_EXTERNALS=ON, all the externals libraries are picked up from EXTERNALS_INSTALL_LOCATION. When BUILTIN_EXTERNALS=OFF, they are picked up from the default system prefix. In both cases, it's now possible to rely on the find_package standard mechanism.
Adding new Find****.cmake modules for external libs, where this was missing.
Cosmetic, cleanup etc.


It's now possible to use the Ninja build system instead of Make. Just configure CVMFS with `cmake -G Ninja ../"

All these changes should not modify the output (executables, libraries etc.) of the build system in any way!

After being built, the external libraries are all installed under the same prefix, by default ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/externals_install. By default, the bootstrap.sh script will not recompile any library listed here. To force the recompilation of any of them, simply remove their name from the file and re-run the CMake configuration for CVMFS.
Various simplifications of the CMake configurations scrips:

When BUILTIN_EXTERNALS=ON, all the externals libraries are picked up from EXTERNALS_INSTALL_LOCATION. When BUILTIN_EXTERNALS=OFF, they are picked up from the default system prefix. In both cases, it's now possible to rely on the find_package standard mechanism.
Adding new Find****.cmake modules for external libs, where this was missing.
Cosmetic, cleanup etc.


It's now possible to use the Ninja build system instead of Make. Just configure CVMFS with `cmake -G Ninja ../"

All these changes should not modify the output (executables, libraries etc.) of the build system in any way!

column13: Improvements to external dependency management (CVM-1161)
column20:
This branch introduces a series of improvements to the scripts that build external dependencies and to the CMake configuration files that handle the externals.
Summary:

bootstrap.sh has be modified. It's called at the beginning of the CMake configuration process, as before, but it will now configure and build all the external dependencies at once. Building them is no longer delayed until the CVMFS build phase. This makes it simpler to understand the external build process
After being built, the external libraries are all installed under the same prefix, by default ${PROJECT_SOURCE_DIR}/externals_install. This means that they can easily be used by multiple builds of CVMFS, if desired. The location of the external libs can be set using the EXTERNALS_PREFIX CMake variable.
It's possible to disable using built-in external libraries by giving the BUILTIN_EXTERNALS=OFF parameter to CMake.
At the end of the external build process, the file $EXTERNALS_INSTALL_LOCATION/.bootstrapDone contains a list of all the externals that are present. By default, the bootstrap.sh script will not recompile any library listed here. To force the recompilation of any of them, simply remove their name from the file and re-run the CMake configuration for CVMFS.
Various simplifications of the CMake configurations scrips:

When BUILTIN_EXTERNALS=ON, all the externals libraries are picked up from EXTERNALS_INSTALL_LOCATION. When BUILTIN_EXTERNALS=OFF, they are picked up from the default system prefix. In both cases, it's now possible to rely on the find_package standard mechanism.
Adding new Find****.cmake modules for external libs, where this was missing.
Cosmetic, cleanup etc.


It's now possible to use the Ninja build system instead of Make. Just configure CVMFS with `cmake -G Ninja ../"

All these changes should not modify the output (executables, libraries etc.) of the build system in any way!
column21:
Hi, thanks for the feedback. I'll add the newlines, to avoid any potential warnings.
By the way, since we're using find_package across the board, in the CMake output we now have a report with the description of each linked library, so it's easier to track which one is linked statically vs dynamically.

column13: Chirp cache plugin
column20: This is a first draft of a CVMFS cache plugin that uses a Chirp server as a storage backend. It's a straightforward implementation that mostly just forwards everything to the Chirp server. There's still plenty of room to improve performance, especially by minimizing the number of remote I/O operations. I added a new configure flag so that this plugin (which depends on CCTools) isn't built by default. Running CMake with -DBUILD_CCTOOLS=yes will enable this feature. Once the configuration syntax is finalized, this plugin might make a good lower-tier cache to share data among several workers without stressing the Squids. Also note that this is written in the CCTools way (C, tabbed indentation, etc.) to the style might not be suitable for CVMFS.

Thanks @trshaffer for this! It's great to have a new cache plugin implementation.
I wonder if this isn't a good opportunity to set up a new CVMFS contrib repository in the CVMFS GitHub organization.
Ideally, things like cache or authorization plugins could go there and could use CVMFS through the standard CMake find_package system. That would also ensure that the artifacts related to the cache plugin system are installed properly.
I could create this new repo tomorrow and help out with the CMake stuff, if needed.
Cheers!

column13: Instance-based cache manager configuration
column20:
Allows for declaring named cache instances in the cvmfs configuration files.  A concrete instance is selected like
CVMFS_CACHE_PRIMARY=myInstanceName
CVMFS_CACHE_myInstanceName_TYPE=posix

Multiple instances can thus be safely defined but only one is selected when the mountpoint is constructed. This allows to defined tiered caches with multiple underlying cache instances.  The change is backwards compatible.  Regular cache configuration syntax is automatically mapped to the CVMFS_CACHE_default_... instance.  In order to store all cache related settings in parameters prefixed by CVMFS_CACHE_, there is also a mapping from legacy cache options
CVMFS_SHARED_CACHE --> CVMFS_CACHE_<name>_SHARED
CVMFS_ALIEN_CACHE --> CVMFS_CACHE_<name>_ALIEN
CVMFS_SERVER_CACHE_MODE --> CVMFS_CACHE_<name>_SERVER_MODE
CVMFS_QUOTA_LIMIT --> CVMFS_CACHE_<name>_QUOTA_LIMIT

If both legacy and new names are defined, the new name as precedence.
Since multiple cache manager objects of the same type can exist, it was also necessary to prefix their statistics counters by the cache instance name.  This triggered resolving CVM-913.
Support for CVMFS_CWD_CACHE (used by libcvmfs) needed to be dropped because in general there is no single well-defined cache directory anymore.
Another commit will add a cvmfs_talk command to show the effective cache manager(s).

column13: Improvement: smart pointers
column20:
This branch add Boost smart pointers, providing a safe automatic memory management through reference counting.
Summary:

Adds the Boost smart_ptr module as an external dependency. This module is header-only, it introduces no new library dependencies. The smart_ptr headers and their requirements are extracted from the Boost sources, to avoid exploding the size of the CVMFS sources (The complete Boost sources are ~80MB compressed, while the smart_ptr sources are ~400kB compressed).
The smart pointer classes are: scoped_ptr - single copy owning pointer, like UniquePtr from CVMFS, shared_ptr - a shared ownership pointer based on reference counting, weak_ptr - a pointer for maintaining weak, non-owning references to shared_ptr and intrusive_ptr - reference-counted pointer which maintains the reference count in the managed object itself.
The smart pointer classes from Boost are the basis of the design of the smart pointers from the C++11 standard. Using the smart pointers from Boost makes a potential future upgrade to C++11 smart pointers very simple (substitute boost namespace for std, substitute scoped_ptr for unique_ptr etc.).
The Boost smart pointers do not require any special C++ compiler support, they compile on any C++98 compiler. The branch has been tested on all the platforms that we support (see results) and also on CentOS 5 with the default compiler - GCC 4.1 (Note: on CentOS 4 and 5 CVMFS is compiled with a newer version of GCC from our yum repos).
Includes unit tests exercising the scoped_ptr, shared_ptr and weak_ptr classes and demonstrating usage and semantics.

Merging this branch opens the possibility of migrating CVMFS to a safer memory management strategy. This migration should be incremental: new code can safely be written using smart pointers, existing code can gradually be migrated as the opportunity arises.
Jenkins cross-platform build results are here:
https://phsft-jenkins.cern.ch/view/CVMFS/job/CvmfsIncrementalBuild/653/

Merging this branch opens the possibility of migrating CVMFS to a safer memory management strategy. This migration should be incremental: new code can safely be written using smart pointers, existing code can gradually be migrated as the opportunity arises.
Jenkins cross-platform build results are here:
https://phsft-jenkins.cern.ch/view/CVMFS/job/CvmfsIncrementalBuild/653/

column13: Improvement: smart pointers
column20:
This branch add Boost smart pointers, providing a safe automatic memory management through reference counting.
Summary:

Adds the Boost smart_ptr module as an external dependency. This module is header-only, it introduces no new library dependencies. The smart_ptr headers and their requirements are extracted from the Boost sources, to avoid exploding the size of the CVMFS sources (The complete Boost sources are ~80MB compressed, while the smart_ptr sources are ~400kB compressed).
The smart pointer classes are: scoped_ptr - single copy owning pointer, like UniquePtr from CVMFS, shared_ptr - a shared ownership pointer based on reference counting, weak_ptr - a pointer for maintaining weak, non-owning references to shared_ptr and intrusive_ptr - reference-counted pointer which maintains the reference count in the managed object itself.
The smart pointer classes from Boost are the basis of the design of the smart pointers from the C++11 standard. Using the smart pointers from Boost makes a potential future upgrade to C++11 smart pointers very simple (substitute boost namespace for std, substitute scoped_ptr for unique_ptr etc.).
The Boost smart pointers do not require any special C++ compiler support, they compile on any C++98 compiler. The branch has been tested on all the platforms that we support (see results) and also on CentOS 5 with the default compiler - GCC 4.1 (Note: on CentOS 4 and 5 CVMFS is compiled with a newer version of GCC from our yum repos).
Includes unit tests exercising the scoped_ptr, shared_ptr and weak_ptr classes and demonstrating usage and semantics.

Merging this branch opens the possibility of migrating CVMFS to a safer memory management strategy. This migration should be incremental: new code can safely be written using smart pointers, existing code can gradually be migrated as the opportunity arises.
Jenkins cross-platform build results are here:
https://phsft-jenkins.cern.ch/view/CVMFS/job/CvmfsIncrementalBuild/653/
column21:
To answer your questions:

POWER8, ARM64

I submitted a new CvmfsIncrementalBuild job to test building+unit tests for the latest version of the branch. I included the Arm64 configuration this time (but it may also hang like the nightly builds...)
(Update: Arm64 is hanging during the CvmfsSetupBuildEnvironment stage).
I don't know what difference these platforms will make, though. The implementation of smart pointers is very basic. I expect that in the smart pointer code there is some branching based on compiler, less branching based on platform.

Stack traces

You will not see anything, unless you capture a stack trace at the exact moment the smart pointer is constructed or destroyed. In any case, shared pointers are implemented without "magic" - just a reference count somewhere, either an atomic integer, or an integer and a lock.
Intrusive smart pointers (I haven't used their implementation from Boost or the C++11 standard lib) are more... intrusive (to have a type be reference countable with intrusive pointers, the type needs to be derived from the intrusive pointer itself, which ensures that the reference count is with the object, not elsewhere), but even there I wouldn't expect to see anything in the stack trace.

Adding a new C++ dependency.

It's not difficult to write a basic shared pointer implementation. On the other hand, writing something that works consistently across platforms and covers any corner case is much more difficult. Another example: we can easily write a simple key-value store. Re-writing LevelDB for our purpose is not feasable.
The smart_ptr module is quite old and has seen a lot of use, which is why the smart pointer implementation and API in C++11 is based on it. I think that when it comes to risk you can do much worse than with a core module of Boost. One can disagree with the designs of some of the very templated libraries, but the core libraries are really good quality.
On the other hand, it may happen that in the future there is a compilation error because I didn't include all the headers files (I had to extract them manually from the Boost sources). In that case it's just a matter of adding the missing files to fix the problem (I already had to do this twice, on macOS and Fedora).
Bottom line, I'm not worried about depending on Boost smart pointers. However, I am worried about memory errors and leaks with manual memory management.
I was wondering if we are running Valgrind as part of the CI suite? I can't find it in Jenkins. I'm running Valgrind manually on the unit tests and it definitely sees memory leaks. Of course, some of them would be in the server tools (maybe less severe), hopefully none or few are in the FUSE client (very bad, imagine). (Update: I found the valgrind.md documentation + test functions).

column20:
Addresses CVM-1132.
This branch contains an implementation of a new uploader backend for the Spooler class. The new backend groups multiple files into object packs which are then asynchronously uploaded to an instance of the gateway services.
This PR is part of the "CVMFS Repository Services" epic, which is work-in-progress. Further work in this epic will supersede some of the additions introduced here.
Regardless, this PR should be safe to merge, as it does not change existing functionality.

Use HMAC for signing HTTP gateway API requests
column20:
Addresses CVM-1191 and CVM-1193.

All the requests (new lease, drop lease, submit payload) made to the HTTP gateway API are now signed with an HMAC computed with a pre-shared secret key.
The shared key is configured through the CVMFS_KEY configuration option, written in the server onfiguration file (server.conf) of the repository. Right now the key has a test format - first line is the public key id, second line is the secret - but this can be updated in the future to use standard key formats.
The gateway services (cvmfs_services) checks the HMAC added to all the requests.

Gateway API cleanup
column20:
This PR brings some improvements to the gateway API:

Gateway key handling is now done in a forward compatible manner, which will allow supporting multiple types of keys:

The file with the configuration of the gateway keys of a repo is listed in the CVMFS_GATEWAY_KEYS variable, in the repo's server.conf. The file mentioned here can have multiple key definitions, one per line, as follows:
<KEY_TYPE> <KEY_DEFINITION>
where <KEY_TYPE> and <KEY_DEFINITION> are separated by a space.
Currently the only key type recognized is:
test <KEY_ID> <SECRET>

Adding version information to all the gateway API requests.

The API request for a new lease now must include the api_version field in the JSON body. In its reply, the gateway services will include the max_api_version field, equal to the minimum of the client and the gateway API versions.

column13: Add missing include

Refurbish client remount code, use active cache eviction with modern fuse
column20:
This PR moves the code for applying new file system snapshots from the fuse main module into a FuseRemounter class.  Things are a little bit better documented now and partially unit tested.  We also get rid of the alarm() signal handling code.
Invalidating the kernel caches is now being done by a FuseInvalidator, which, on modern fuse (2.9 / EL7 and newer), will actively kick out entries from the kernel caches.  In most cases, this gets rid of 1 minute waiting time and results in immediate application of the new file system snapshot.  Along with it, there is a new command cvmfs_talk remount sync which only returns once the new file system snapshot is available.

In most cases, this gets rid of 1 minute waiting time and results in immediate application of the new file system snapshot.  Along with it, there is a new command cvmfs_talk remount sync which only returns once the new file system snapshot is available.

column20:
Introduces the new cvmfs_receiver tool which processes payloads submitted to the gateway services.
cvmfs_receiver is spawned by the gateway services and is managed as a coprocess (I/O is done through stdin/stdout). Payloads submitted to the gateway, packaged as cvmfs::ObjectPacks, are dispatched to a running instance of the cvmfs_receiver tool. The tool then deserializes the object packs, verifies the contents and writes them to storage.
This PR also some cleanup and bug fixes in relevant classes and tests.
This PR is a prerequisite for CVM-1195, which, when implemented, completes the pipeline associated with the new workflow.
As usual, this PR should not break any existing workflow of functionality.

Add support for branching
column20:
Adds the cvmfs_server checkout command that allows to branch off a given tag.  Makes most sense with the vitual catalog that provides the /.cvmfs/snapshots directory.  The tag database now has a new column branch, and a new table that stores parent-child branch relationship and the initial revision of branches.  A branch is removed if all the tags using it get removed.  Children of removed branches are automatically re-parented to their grand-parents.
Root catalogs store their branch.  Comes with a new extended attribute branch.
The recycle bin table in the tag database was unused since the introduction of the reflog.  The table is now flushed and deprecated, since we were anyway dealing with the SQL code around the tag database.
Fixes a bug in the creation of the snapshots directory discovered during testing.  Also, stratum 0 garbage collection does not modify anymore the history (and hence the manifest) anymore.  Adds the missing update-repoinfo to the new cvmfs_server build system.

The tag database now has a new column branch, and a new table that stores parent-child branch relationship and the initial revision of branches.  A branch is removed if all the tags using it get removed.  Children of removed branches are automatically re-parented to their grand-parents.
Root catalogs store their branch.  Comes with a new extended attribute branch.

column21:
That's a good question.  One reason is to ensure that root catalogs are unique.  So far, storing the revision was enough, but now the revision became a two dimensional (branch, revision).  To ensure root catalogs are unique, we could instead store a UUID in the root catalog.  As for the user interface, users can lookup the catalog revision already through extended attributes.  So it might make sense for them to be able to query both to distinguish catalog revision X on two different branches.
Then again, I expect that users access branched tags anyway through the .cvmfs/snapshots directory of the latest catalog. And we can also argue that tags and branches are sort of annotations to an existing repository.
I guess storing the branch doesn't hurt much for the time being.  I could remove the access to the branch through extended attributes so that we don't commit to the branch being stored in the root catalog.

column13: Several minor fixes
Code reuse between cvmfs_swissknife and cvmfs_receiver
column20:
Addressed CVM-1268.
The implementation of CVM-1195 required that the body of the swissknife::CommandDiff and swissknife::CommandSign tools be factored out and used with the cvmfs_receiver tool.
This PR updates the two swissknife classes to make use of the factored out components( ServerTool, DiffTool, SigningTool etc.), to avoid code duplication.
There is no change in functionality.

column21: Ok, I pushed an update, but since I need to use a string it isn't quite as clean as an integer constant.   C++03 does not allow setting a per-class static constant string that is initialized at the same time as it is defined.  Instead I have to define it in the class definition but initialize it in swissknife_graft.cc.   I can initialize an integer when it is defined, but GetDescription() wants a string.  C++11 has a new 'constexpr' way to assign strings the same time as they're defined, but we're not using C++11.

column21:
Many thanks!
Since the suggestion is anyway to increase the buffer on ERANGE, how about dropping the calls to sysconf.  Instead both functions can continue doubling the buffer until errno != ERANGE.

column13: change usage of getgrnam_r and getpwnam_r to follow man page API
column20: See CVM-1304
column21:
The man page says the API is to use those values.  If you want me to go ahead and stick with 16K anyway and ignore the API, please confirm and I will change it.  The value for getgrnam_r does start out at only 1K (at least on el6) so it takes 4 doublings to get to 16K and is less efficient when it has to do that.
The API for getpwnam_r is different than getgrnam_r.  According to the el6 man page, the former says to just use the value of the sysconf variable and that tells you the maximum size.   On the other hand, I just checked and the el7 man page's description is just like getgrnam_r, where you are to retry with a larger buffer if you get ERANGE.  Oh, I see that the el6 man page says there is also ERANGE if you give it too small of a value, so it should be alright there too.
The Mac getgrnam_r man page doesn't say anything about sysconf nor does it say that it can return an ERANGE error if the buffer is too small.  It does say that it can return an error value but doesn't say what the errors can be.   On the other hand the Mac getpwnam_r man page does say that it can return an ERANGE, so probably getgrnam_r can too and it is just missing from the man page.

column13: change usage of getgrnam_r and getpwnam_r to follow man page API
column20: See CVM-1304
column21: Yep, please leave the current 16kB initial buffer but having buffer doubling on ERANGE.  I just tested on OS X, getpwnam_r behaves as expected.

Sorry for the late reply.
I'm thinking about where to put the log files. In the cvmfs_services application the lager_syslog backend is configured with a cvmfs_services identity and an rsyslog configuration file for the application is installed into /etc/rsyslog.d. The log files are created and owned by the syslog user. I think this is a clean way to do it, probably facilitates the integration with system-wide log rotation tools.
Wouldn't it be better to configure the logging here to use the same approach (configure syslog to handle things for us)?

column13: Optionally omit generation of bulk hashes for chunked files
column20:
For the time being, the default is still to create bulk hashes except for the graft utility.  The graft utility does not (yet) have a stable interface.
As a side effect, large hard links are now chunked, too, which wasn't the case before.
Note: When bulk hashes are omitted in gc-enabled repositories, all stratum 1s have to update, too.  Otherwise they will remove chunks from files without a bulk hash during garbage collection.
This PR also reverts to zlib 1.2.8, version 1.2.11 introduced bug fixes that affect cvmfs.  The PR also fixes building of the cvmfs_swissknife_debug binary.
column21:

This PR also reverts to zlib 1.2.8, version 1.2.11 introduced bug fixes that affect cvmfs.  The PR also fixes building of the cvmfs_swissknife_debug binary.

Cache geoapi DNS lookups in a threaded shared wsgi python interpreter
column20:
See CVM-1349
This changes the geoapi to cache all DNS lookup results for 5 minutes.  If a DNS lookup fails and there is an old result available, it will be reused.  The interpreter is multithreaded so the cache is protected with a lock.
This also changes the WSGI apache config to all be in one shared cvmfs.webapi.conf apache config file instead of in every cvmfs.<repo>.conf file.  I hadn't been able to figure out how to do that before or I would have done it earlier.  The key was to put the WSGIProcessGroup inside of a  section for the wsgi script.  Also WSGIApplicationGroup is needed to make them all use the same python interpreter.  Only one WSGIDaemonProcess is started but with 64 threads.
