column13: RAII temporary directory helper class
column20:
Addresses CVM-1306.
Provides a helper class to create scoped temporary directories - the directories are created in the constructor of the object and removed in its destructor.
Some classes used in the cvmfs_receiver application have beem modified to use this class, to avoid leaving rubbish files behind.

column13: Minor fixes
Some code review fixes for the RaiiTempDir class
Fix off-by-one error for chunk size.
column20:
Previously, a new chunk would be emitted after N+(buffer size) bytes when the user requested N bytes for chunk size.  So, if the user wanted a 24MB chunk, CVMFS would create 24MB+16KB chunks for cvmfs_swissknife graft.
This corrects the issue; 24MB chunks are created when 24MB chunks are requested for grafts.
(This seems trivial, but it is actually really annoying when trying to validate other implementations of grafting!)

column13: do not do health check on resign
column20:
See CVM-1358
Please commit to both devel and cvmfs-2.4 branches.
column21:
Further testing made me realize that when the repository keys change you always have to do a cvmfs_server resign after a cvmfs_server resign -p, because the fingerprint changes.   So the health check on regular resign also gets in the way.
Meanwhile in my testing I have been able to work around the problem by doing two transaction/abort pairs, but it is ugly and I'm not sure if it will work in all cases one might want do this recovery.  I really don't see any good reason to do a health check in order to resign anything, and I think it is better to just not do it.

column13: Enable the use of the CVMFS gateway services with S3 storage backend
column20:
Addresses CVM-1264.
Removes all hardcoded values for temporary directories (i.e. /srv/cvmfs/<REPO_NAME>/data/txn) and Stratum0 URL from the cvmfs_receiver application. All values are now read from the repo's server.conf file and all files are transfered to/from the repository upstream storage using the appropriate objects (DownloadManager, Uploader etc.).
The cvmfs_receiver tool now also responds to an optional configuration parameter in server.conf: TEST_CVMFS_RECEIVER_UPSTREAM_STORAGE - this is only useful for integration tests where the release manager and the gateway are running on the same machine, and allows specifying the upstream storage string for the cvmfs_receiver (in this test configuration, cvmfs_server needs to see an upstream storage of type "gw", while cvmfs_receiver needs to use "local" or "S3").
column21:

column13: WIP: Adding initial support for SciTokens plugins
column20:
This adds support for SciTokens, which is an OAuth Bearer
token based authentication scheme.  The bearer token is
retrieved from an external authz helper.
This pull request is not complete, and needs to be reviewed and tested.  The purpose of this pull request is to begin gathering feedback on this feature.
@bbockelm

In CC7, apache (httpd) is configured to have a private temp enabled, so the outside /tmp (where the test files are located, as well as the test certs) cannot be accessed by httpd.
Currently, the test bind mounts /etc/grid-security into a directory /tmp.  Let me change the test to just put files in that directory /etc/grid-security.  It will be less clean, but necessary.

column13: Restart authz_helper process after a cool-off period.
column20:
Although I haven't quite figured out why, we have a few crashing cvmfs_x509_helper processes on one of the OSG sites.
In order to avoid permanent black-hole nodes, this allows the CVMFS authz helper to restart after kChildTimeout seconds (I considered an immediate restart, but I am worried about continuously churning processes).

@bbockelm: good question... cvmfs has the Watchdog class but we are probably not able to use it between fork() and execve() because of the unknown state of the cvmfs2 process at this point.  We might be able to cvmfs2 itself as a trampoline process, so that we can do
fork()
execve() --> cvmfs2 with special parameters
spawn off watchdog
execve into the actual helper

column13: Fix off-by-one error for chunk size.
column20:
Previously, a new chunk would be emitted after N+(buffer size) bytes when the user requested N bytes for chunk size.  So, if the user wanted a 24MB chunk, CVMFS would create 24MB+16KB chunks.
This corrects the issue; 24MB chunks are created when 24MB chunks are requested for grafts.
column21:

column13: Remove a nested catalog's subtree in constant time
column20:
Addresses CVM-1405.
Performance optimization.
Adds a parameter to the WritableCatalogManager::RemoveNestedCatalog function to allow removing the nested catalog including its contents. By default, the behaviour of the function is unchanged (i.e. the nested catalog is removed and its contents are merged into its parent).
For the moment, the new functionality is only be used on the repository gateway, in the CatalogMergeTool class.
Nested catalog handling in  CatalogMergeTool is already tested in the integration test 802-repository_services_nested_catalogs.

Are you sure about the Conflicts: clause?  Wouldn't that mean that no two config packages can be installed concurrently?
Please resubmit against the 2.4 branch.

column13: Turn cvmfs-config into Debian virtual package, default cvmfs-config-default
column20:
https://sft.its.cern.ch/jira/browse/CVM-1420
I have tested this on my Debian machine with cvmfs-config-default and cvmfs-config-none in a local apt repository, works as expected.
column21:
I changed the base; I branched it off of cvmfs-2.4 in the first place, it was just a mistake on the PR submission.
Yes the Conflicts clause prevents two cvmfs-config packages from being installed concurrently.  I thought that was what we wanted.  I still think that's what we want; I think that the name cvmfs-config should be reserved for a base configuration package which does conflict with other base configuration packages, even if they don't install the same files.  For example, they probably would all (except for cvmfs-config-none) define a config repository.  Of course people can create other cvmfs-config-* packages which do not Provide & Conflict with cvmfs-config.
Even though cvmfs-config-none does not set a config repository, its intention is to allow people to not install any base config repository, so I think it should also Provide & Conflict with cvmfs-config.   In fact when I was testing this PR I found that I had accidentally installed an old version of cvmfs-config-none that did not have the Conflict, and I was having trouble figuring out why it wasn't installing cvmfs-config-default.
By having the Conflicts statement there, when somebody does apt-get install cvmfs-config it says that cvmfs-config is a virtual package and lists all the possible packages to choose from.

column13: New pthread based ingestion pipeline
column20:
Replaces the current tbb based file processing pipeline by a purely POSIX thread based ingestion pipeline.  The change was triggered by the deadlock described in CVM-1360.  Removing tbb improves debuggability and simplifies deployment.  The change allows us to re-enable parallel processing of file catalogs.
Two basic performance nobs are:

the number of threads for the different tasks (reading, hashing, compressing, ...)
the memory watermarks that throttles ingestion wrt. to the speed of the pipeline

Things that probably are worthwhile adding

Performance counters, logged in a StatisticsManager
Micro-benchmarks for some of the tasks

column13: React to a change of DNS server (macOS)
column20:
Addresses CVM-496.
On macOS, when roaming across wireless networks, a change of DNS server was not detected, leading to I/O errors.
This is addressed here by watching the "/etc/resolv.conf" file for changes in a background thread. When the file is modified the new nameserver address is read and given to all DownloadManager instances.
This solution is limited to macOS, for the moment, as for Linux there are alternative solutions available (see JIRA discussion).
The feature is controlled by the CVMFS_DNS_ROAMING repository parameter - by default it is ON.
column21:
Addresses CVM-496.
On macOS, when roaming across wireless networks, a change of DNS server was not detected, leading to I/O errors.
This is addressed here by watching the "/etc/resolv.conf" file for changes in a background thread. When the file is modified the new nameserver address is read and given to all DownloadManager instances.
This solution is limited to macOS, for the moment, as for Linux there are alternative solutions available (see JIRA discussion).
The feature is controlled by the CVMFS_DNS_ROAMING repository parameter - by default it is ON.

column13: React to a change of DNS server (macOS)
column20:
Addresses CVM-496.
On macOS, when roaming across wireless networks, a change of DNS server was not detected, leading to I/O errors.
This is addressed here by watching the "/etc/resolv.conf" file for changes in a background thread. When the file is modified the new nameserver address is read and given to all DownloadManager instances.
This solution is limited to macOS, for the moment, as for Linux there are alternative solutions available (see JIRA discussion).
The feature is controlled by the CVMFS_DNS_ROAMING repository parameter - by default it is ON.

column13: Swallow libarchive
column20:
In this PR we swallow libarchive.
We add the "compressed" source as an external dependency. (We also include a small README.txt that explain how to get from the official sources to the compressed one).
We configure, build and install the software (in configureHook.sh and makeHook.sh) and get around some issues created by the compression.
We modify the bootstrap file to actually work on libarchive.
Finally we add the dependency in CMakeList.
I wasn't able to cleanly remove the commit (810526c, checkpoint) the one that started the whole PR, it should automagically merge though.
column21:
In this PR we swallow libarchive.
We add the "compressed" source as an external dependency. (We also include a small README.txt that explain how to get from the official sources to the compressed one).
We configure, build and install the software (in configureHook.sh and makeHook.sh) and get around some issues created by the compression.
We modify the bootstrap file to actually work on libarchive.
Finally we add the dependency in CMakeList.
I wasn't able to cleanly remove the commit (810526c, checkpoint) the one that started the whole PR, it should automagically merge though.

column13: write checksum to computed checksum dir
column20:
Using parrot, we found that the repository checksums were being written to the current working directory, rather than the usual temp directory. I believe this is because the checksum_dir was not being used when writing the file.
Doing an strace, it seems that first libcvmfs does try to read the checksum from the temp dir, but then it writes it in the current directory:
open("/tmp/parrot.196886/cvmfs/cvmfschecksum.cms.cern.ch", O_RDONLY) = -1 ENOENT (No such file or directory)
open("./cvmfschecksum.cms.cern.ch.wObQ37", O_RDWR|O_CREAT|O_EXCL, 0600) = 9
rename("./cvmfschecksum.cms.cern.ch.wObQ37", "./cvmfschecksum.cms.cern.ch") = 0
column21:

cvmfs_talk remount with a fixed catalog would crash the client.  Now it remounts.

column13: Run automatic garbage collection only every so often
column20: The new parameter CVMFS_AUTO_GC_LAPSE can be used to trigger how frequently auto GC should run.  By default it is 1 day ago,  meaning that auto gc will only run if the last gc (manual or automatic) is more than 1d ago.
column21: The new parameter CVMFS_AUTO_GC_LAPSE can be used to trigger how frequently auto GC should run.  By default it is 1 day ago,  meaning that auto gc will only run if the last gc (manual or automatic) is more than 1d ago.

column21: @btovar Based on #2070 this PR writes the checksum to the cvmfs "workspace". The workspace can be set through the CVMFS_WORKSPACE parameter, which defaults to the cache directory.  In the legacy options scheme, it is the lock_directory parameter that sets the workspace explicitly. Please let us know if this works for you.

column13: Improve memory utilization in ingestion pipeline
column20: The I/O payload pushed through the pipeline is allocated separately from the system malloc. Also, the number of files in flight is limited. Both measures combined should keep the memory envelope of cvmfs_swissknife sync within 4G independent of the change set.

column13: Fix macOS crash in remount loop
column20:
Reverting "increase robustness of remount trigger thread management", which was causing a crash in the remount loop, due to a broken implementation of poll on macOS:
https://daniel.haxx.se/blog/2016/10/11/poll-on-mac-10-12-is-broken/

column13: Fixup after integration test run
Make Signal multi shot
column20:
Signal is now SingleShot.
Once Wakeup is called, every successive call to Wait will simply not wait.
Wakeup set fired_ to true and the next invocation of Wait will acquire the lock but it will not enter the main loop.
This PR reset the Wait to false so that we are forced to have a sequence of Wait -> Wakeup -> Wait -> Wakeup
I believe we could discuss if we want another class that has the MultiShot behaviour and leaving signal SingleShot, however, this one, is a quite tricky API to manage and I figure out this SingleShot behaviour only by chance...
column21:

column21: Very well!  Are there any other users currently of the Signal class?  If so we need to check them one by one and perhaps leave the default behaviour single-shot but allow for a constructor parameter that turns it into a multi-shot Signal.

column13: Make Signal multi shot
column20:
Signal is now SingleShot.
Once Wakeup is called, every successive call to Wait will simply not wait.
Wakeup set fired_ to true and the next invocation of Wait will acquire the lock but it will not enter the main loop.
This PR reset the Wait to false so that we are forced to have a sequence of Wait -> Wakeup -> Wait -> Wakeup
I believe we could discuss if we want another class that has the MultiShot behaviour and leaving signal SingleShot, however, this one, is a quite tricky API to manage and I figure out this SingleShot behaviour only by chance...
column21:
I believe we are save.
There is only one other place where Signal is used: https://github.com/cvmfs/cvmfs/blob/devel/cvmfs/cache_extern.h#L252-L258
However the Signal is stack initialized, make it Wait and immediately destroyed here: https://github.com/cvmfs/cvmfs/blob/devel/cvmfs/cache_extern.cc#L111-L120
Then there is a single Wakeup: https://github.com/cvmfs/cvmfs/blob/devel/cvmfs/cache_extern.cc#L542
So after this last Wakeup Signal just get destroyed.
The change is such that it modify the behaviour only with multiple call of Wait, in our case we are safe.
Anyway we should discuss if we want to maintain the Single Shot semantic for Signal and create a new class for Multi Shot.

column13: Make Signal multi shot
column20:
Signal is now SingleShot.
Once Wakeup is called, every successive call to Wait will simply not wait.
Wakeup set fired_ to true and the next invocation of Wait will acquire the lock but it will not enter the main loop.
This PR reset the Wait to false so that we are forced to have a sequence of Wait -> Wakeup -> Wait -> Wakeup
I believe we could discuss if we want another class that has the MultiShot behaviour and leaving signal SingleShot, however, this one, is a quite tricky API to manage and I figure out this SingleShot behaviour only by chance...
column21: Hm, might be a problem here: if Wakeup is called before Wait, then Wait never returns. Let's discuss.

column13: Check for autofs in cvmfs_server rmfs for stratum 0 only
Removing get_redhat_version.sh
Automatically configure fuse on Debian-derived platforms
column20:
The debian packaging system features a tool called config-package-dev which automates common operations on configuration files in a reversible and predictable manner. This pull request causes /etc/fuse.conf to be replaced by a symbolic link to /etc/fuse.conf.cvmfs which has been transformed from its packaged value by a simple sed operation that removes the comment in front of user_allow_other.
Additionally, a backup created at /etc/fuse.conf.cvmfs-orig; upon removal of the package /etc/fuse.conf is replaced by /etc/fuse.conf.cvmfs-orig and the latter is deleted.
The only thing to maintain in this package is a single line withinpackaging/debian/cvmfs/cvmfs.transform that modifies /etc/fuse.conf as packaged by fuse to that as needed by cvmfs.
thomas.downes@downes-stretch:~/work/cvmfs/ci/cvmfs$ cat /etc/fuse.conf
# /etc/fuse.conf - Configuration file for Filesystem in Userspace (FUSE)

# Set the maximum number of FUSE mounts allowed to non-root users.
# The default is 1000.
#mount_max = 1000

# Allow non-root users to specify the allow_other or allow_root mount options.
#user_allow_other
thomas.downes@downes-stretch:~/work/cvmfs/ci/cvmfs$ sudo dpkg -i /tmp/cvmfs-pkg/cvmfs_2.5.0~1+debian9.4_amd64.deb
Selecting previously unselected package cvmfs.
(Reading database ... 131423 files and directories currently installed.)
Preparing to unpack .../cvmfs_2.5.0~1+debian9.4_amd64.deb ...
Unpacking cvmfs (2.5.0~1+debian9.4) ...
Setting up cvmfs (2.5.0~1+debian9.4) ...
creating cvmfs user/group...
Adding 'diversion of /etc/fuse.conf to /etc/fuse.conf.cvmfs-orig by cvmfs'
Processing triggers for libc-bin (2.24-11+deb9u3) ...
thomas.downes@downes-stretch:~/work/cvmfs$ ls -lh /etc/fuse.conf*
lrwxrwxrwx 1 root root  15 Apr 25 17:12 /etc/fuse.conf -> fuse.conf.cvmfs
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 279 Apr 25 16:08 /etc/fuse.conf.cvmfs
-rw-r--r-- 1 root root 280 Apr 25 13:49 /etc/fuse.conf.cvmfs-orig
thomas.downes@downes-stretch:~/work/cvmfs$ cat /etc/fuse.conf
# /etc/fuse.conf - Configuration file for Filesystem in Userspace (FUSE)

# Set the maximum number of FUSE mounts allowed to non-root users.
# The default is 1000.
#mount_max = 1000

# Allow non-root users to specify the allow_other or allow_root mount options.
user_allow_other
thomas.downes@downes-stretch:~/work/cvmfs$ sudo apt-get remove cvmfs
Reading package lists... Done
Building dependency tree
Reading state information... Done

column21:
Package installation succeeds even if the user has previously edited /etc/fuse.conf such that there are no lines that match user_allow_other and begin with #. In these cases, /etc/fuse.conf is unmodified. Examples of such cases:

manually removing the comment so that user_allow_other is enabled
making large alterations to fuse.conf that do not contain user_allow_other at all (commented or uncommented)

Thus, the impact of this commit should be benign.

Hrm. I actually looked at that ticket because I remembered it but it didn't leap out at me (for some reason) that it was resolved. This took about 10 minutes to develop + test, so no big deal to close.
The ticket contains a link to a documentation update that is incomplete. autofs need not only be running but you must reload or restart the service. You should expect a cvmfs-contrib package soon that sets up autofs out-of-the-box; on Debian it will do the reload/restart (because on Debian that's normal) while on RedHat it will be up the user (because on RedHat that's normal).

column13: Eliminate the following Debian packaging warnings or errors
column20:
I'd like to spend a little time cleaning up the Debian packaging process to better conform with Debian policy. I have updated the policy for the cvmfs package (but not others) to identify itself as in compliance with 3.9.6.1, which corresponds to Debian 8 and has the effect of eliminating the warning W: cvmfs source: ancient-standards-version 3.9.3.1 (current is 3.9.8).
I have rebuilt the package successfully and believe the changes I have made are harmless. I'm happy to go through all the other packages and make similarly harmless modifications if you accept this pull request.
At that point, there will be some real issues to consider. For example, static compilation of zlib:
E: cvmfs: embedded-library usr/lib/libcvmfs_fuse.so.2.5.0: zlib

This pull request includes an example of how to "override" a warning when you know the action to be OK. This is discouraged for obvious reasons, but it's there as a tool when necessary. My example overrides the Debian policy manual's refusal to adopt the FHS 3.0 standard.
Warnings/errors eliminated:
E: cvmfs source: depends-on-build-essential-package-without-using-version g++ [build-depends: g++]
E: cvmfs source: depends-on-build-essential-package-without-using-version gcc [build-depends: gcc]
E: cvmfs source: depends-on-build-essential-package-without-using-version libc6-dev [build-depends: libc6-dev]
E: cvmfs source: depends-on-build-essential-package-without-using-version make [build-depends: make]
E: cvmfs source: obsolete-relation-form-in-source in cvmfs-server conflicts: cvmfs-server (< 2.1)
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: bash
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: coreutils
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: debianutils
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: grep
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: libc-bin
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: sed
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: sysvinit-utils
W: cvmfs source: ancient-standards-version 3.9.3.1 (current is 3.9.8)
W: cvmfs source: debhelper-but-no-misc-depends cvmfs
W: cvmfs source: debhelper-but-no-misc-depends cvmfs-dev
W: cvmfs source: debhelper-but-no-misc-depends cvmfs-server
W: cvmfs source: debhelper-but-no-misc-depends cvmfs-unittests
W: cvmfs: maintainer-script-needs-depends-on-adduser postinst
W: cvmfs: non-standard-dir-in-usr usr/libexec/

fix things that are (hopefully) not controversial like this PR
use the override mechanism to suppress the other errors/warnings. I presume that one can include comments in the override file and this can be useful for tracking why the package is the way it is (and detecting problems introduced going forward).

I'd like to spend a little time cleaning up the Debian packaging process to better conform with Debian policy. I have updated the policy for the cvmfs package (but not others) to identify itself as in compliance with 3.9.6.1, which corresponds to Debian 8 and has the effect of eliminating the warning W: cvmfs source: ancient-standards-version 3.9.3.1 (current is 3.9.8).
I have rebuilt the package successfully and believe the changes I have made are harmless. I'm happy to go through all the other packages and make similarly harmless modifications if you accept this pull request.
At that point, there will be some real issues to consider. For example, static compilation of zlib:
E: cvmfs: embedded-library usr/lib/libcvmfs_fuse.so.2.5.0: zlib

This pull request includes an example of how to "override" a warning when you know the action to be OK. This is discouraged for obvious reasons, but it's there as a tool when necessary. My example overrides the Debian policy manual's refusal to adopt the FHS 3.0 standard.
Warnings/errors eliminated:
E: cvmfs source: depends-on-build-essential-package-without-using-version g++ [build-depends: g++]
E: cvmfs source: depends-on-build-essential-package-without-using-version gcc [build-depends: gcc]
E: cvmfs source: depends-on-build-essential-package-without-using-version libc6-dev [build-depends: libc6-dev]
E: cvmfs source: depends-on-build-essential-package-without-using-version make [build-depends: make]
E: cvmfs source: obsolete-relation-form-in-source in cvmfs-server conflicts: cvmfs-server (< 2.1)
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: bash
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: coreutils
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: debianutils
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: grep
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: libc-bin
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: sed
E: cvmfs: depends-on-essential-package-without-using-version depends: sysvinit-utils
W: cvmfs source: ancient-standards-version 3.9.3.1 (current is 3.9.8)
W: cvmfs source: debhelper-but-no-misc-depends cvmfs
W: cvmfs source: debhelper-but-no-misc-depends cvmfs-dev
W: cvmfs source: debhelper-but-no-misc-depends cvmfs-server
W: cvmfs source: debhelper-but-no-misc-depends cvmfs-unittests
W: cvmfs: maintainer-script-needs-depends-on-adduser postinst
W: cvmfs: non-standard-dir-in-usr usr/libexec/
column21:
Sounds great!
This will make it into the 2.6 release as we are just releasing 2.5.

column13: PayloadProcessor - check for Spooler upload errors
column20:
Addresses CVM-1545.
The PayloadProcessor should detect any Spooler errors and return an error code. The cvmfs_receiver worker process can notify its supervisor process (the cvmfs-gateway application) of this error and the publication process is stopped, without going forward with the commit phase.

column13: Run client integration tests on macOS
column20:
Addresses CVM-1413.
This enables running the client intergration tests for macOS. There is a matching PR in the https://github.com/cernvm/ci-scripts repo.
The macOS tests can be selected through the platform matrix of the Jenkins job, as with Linux. The difference is that they are not run on a spawned VM, but on a physical machine - a Mac mini.

column13: Avoid format truncation warnings for old and new gcc alike
Re-enable integration test suite with S3-backed repositories
column20:
Addresses CVM-1554.
This PR brings back the server integration tests using S3-backed repository storage. The "fake_s3" Ruby gem was replaced with a real S3 implementation - Minio - which is run on the same node as the tests.
Also included is a cleanup of the setup phase of the repository gateway integration tests, allowing them to be run with local or S3 storage.
The S3-backed test suite is activated for SCL6, CC7 and Ubuntu x86_64.
column21:
Addresses CVM-1554.
This PR brings back the server integration tests using S3-backed repository storage. The "fake_s3" Ruby gem was replaced with a real S3 implementation - Minio - which is run on the same node as the tests.
Also included is a cleanup of the setup phase of the repository gateway integration tests, allowing them to be run with local or S3 storage.
The S3-backed test suite is activated for SCL6, CC7 and Ubuntu x86_64.

column13: Configuration templating variables
column20:
Within the configuration file values it is now possible to use variables by inserting @foo@ where foo is the name of a variable.
The first variable available across all configuration files (where applicable[1]) is @fqrn@ which is resolved to the repository name.
This will enable repository dependent configuration values and will be used for the tracer (to allow one trace log per repository).
To make this change in a way that new configuration template variables can easily be added, an OptionsTemplatingManager was introduced which manages the available templating variables and is passed to the ParsePath methods of the OptionsManagers.
The unit tests in T_Options were extended to check the behaviour described above.
[1] It seemed to me that there is no fqrn available in cvmfs/cache_plugin/libcvmfs_cache_options.cc and cvmfs/libcvmfs_options.cc. Therefore the fqrn is not resolved when the configuration is parsed through invocation of one of these 2 functions.

column21:
Concerning the SwitchTemplateManager method: Should this reevaluate everything or only symbols which have not previously been resolved? If we were to go for a full reevaluation I would propose to evaluate the templating variables upon retrieval in GetValue (not during charging). This would avoid having to store all configuration options twice (once in its template variable resolved version, once in the original version).
This is only feasible though if the calls to GetValue mostly happen during charging (not during the file system system calls)

Please do not merge yet, since I found out that the current implementation of this branch is breaking the Tracer functionality in the following pull request (and crashes the program on an assertion if the Tracer is being activated even in this version).
I'm underway of fixing this issue...

column13: Configuration templating variables
column20:
Within the configuration file values it is now possible to use variables by inserting @foo@ where foo is the name of a variable.
The first variable available across all configuration files (where applicable[1]) is @fqrn@ which is resolved to the repository name.
This will enable repository dependent configuration values and will be used for the tracer (to allow one trace log per repository).
To make this change in a way that new configuration template variables can easily be added, an OptionsTemplatingManager was introduced which manages the available templating variables and is passed to the ParsePath methods of the OptionsManagers.
The unit tests in T_Options were extended to check the behaviour described above.
[1] It seemed to me that there is no fqrn available in cvmfs/cache_plugin/libcvmfs_cache_options.cc and cvmfs/libcvmfs_options.cc. Therefore the fqrn is not resolved when the configuration is parsed through invocation of one of these 2 functions.

column13: Tracer implementation
column20:
Note: This pull request should only be considered once #2151 is merged
This pull request contains the implementation of a tracer which allows the tracing of the following file system operations:

opendir and open
lookup
statfs and getattr
listxattr and getxattr
readlink

The tracer was implemented in a way that should minimize the overhead when the tracer is deactivated and used the base implementation already available in tracer.cc.
An integration test was added to check the functionality described above.
The tracer can be activated by defining CVMFS_TRACEFILE in the configuration file.
Additionally CVMFS_TRACEBUFFER (size of the tracebuffer) and CVMFS_TRACEBUFFER_THRESHOLD (threshold for a tracebuffer flush) can be defined to further customize the behaviour of the tracer.

column13: Print statistics about number of files added/removed/changed-stage1
column20:
Addresses CVM-1566.
Print statistics about number of files added/removed/changed by simple operations (rm, touch, cp etc) at the end of each publication.
Output example:
[ddosaru@phsftpc2r20:~/cvmfs/build]$ sudo -E cvmfs_server publish test.repo.org 
Using auto tag 'generic-2018-06-25T14:19:14Z'
Processing changes...

Statistics:
Files   added: 1
Files removed: 0
Files changed: 0
Waiting for upload of files before committing...
Committing file catalogs...
Wait for all uploads to finish
Exporting repository manifest
Tagging test22.repo.org
Flushing file system buffers
Signing new manifest
Remounting newly created repository revision

rm -rf or cp -r are not counted yet.

column13: Add extended cvmfs stat call to libcvmfs
column20:
This addition to libcvmfs provides a functions for retrieving not only the stat information, but also information specific to CVMFS like checksum and the stored names. This also adds tests for stat and ext_stat in t_libcvmfs.
Note: this coincides with #2155 so one will need to be rebased off the other prior to merging.

column21: If you are referring inside of the cvmfs_stat structure, I am using chars so that this is accessible in c, not just c++.  The exceptions are for checksum and xattr so that the CVMFS structured data remains. If a c application were interested in this data, there would likely have to be a conversion or helper function to access the data.

column13: Feature tracer ready
column20:
Newer version of pull request #2152 (based on results of #2151)
Quote:
This pull request contains the implementation of a tracer which allows the tracing of the following file system operations:

opendir and open
lookup
statfs and getattr
listxattr and getxattr
readlink

The tracer was implemented in a way that should minimize the overhead when the tracer is deactivated and used the base implementation already available in tracer.cc.
An integration test was added to check the functionality described above.
The tracer can be activated by defining CVMFS_TRACEFILE in the configuration file.
Additionally CVMFS_TRACEBUFFER (size of the tracebuffer) and CVMFS_TRACEBUFFER_THRESHOLD (threshold for a tracebuffer flush) can be defined to further customize the behaviour of the tracer.

column13: Create SQLite database during publication
column20:
Address CVM-1567 and CVM-1568.
Create/Open SQLite database and insert statistics data into it at the end of each publication (sync/ingest commands).
By default, a /var/spool/cvmfs/<REPO_NAME>/stats.db file is created/opened (if exists).
The user can specify a certain location and file name for the database file by defining the following variable in the server.conf file:
CVMFS_STATISTICS_DB=<ABSOLUTE_PATH_OF_THE_DB>/<DB_FILE_NAME>
View publish_statistics table format here!

column13: Address test failing on 32 bit systems
column20:
The issue was that I was prematurely freeing a character string. How this was not causing problems for me may have just been luck as a result of the memory not being changed, but regardless it has been addressed.
Also in this pull request string comparison tests are now using EXPECT_STREQ and EXPECT_STRNE for more simplified reading of the tests. Also comment styles were updated to the expected format.
column21:
The issue was that I was prematurely freeing a character string. How this was not causing problems for me may have just been luck as a result of the memory not being changed, but regardless it has been addressed.
Also in this pull request string comparison tests are now using EXPECT_STREQ and EXPECT_STRNE for more simplified reading of the tests. Also comment styles were updated to the expected format.

column21:
I think I fixed everything you noticed.  The debian problem was not with the missing maxminddb.h; it intentionally tries that compile and continues without it if it fails.  The problem was that there was a lib.linux-i686-2.7 directory instead of a lib directory.  I changed it to use lib*.
If this doesn't fix everything, feel free to fix it yourself either by updating this PR or by merging it and making a new one, instead of waiting for me and getting into multiple 24 hour cycles.

column13: Only assume workspace is cwd if in FUSE
column20: When setting up a cache workspace we set the cache_path to the cwd as it is assumed we had moved to the directory earlier in setup. This only occurs if the type is Fuse, but if the type is Library we don't chdir. This checks if the type is Fuse before assuming we are in the cwd for the cache.

column13: Fix noisy error in CentOS 7 integration tests
Allow to ingest tarballs with hardlink multiple times
column20:
This fix is necessary when we are ingesting a tarball with hardlinks, if
there are already file with the same name and content of the hardlink
(basically only when we are ingesting twice the same tarball) we would
try to add twice the same unique hash, which produce a runtime error
violating the UNIQUE constraint in SQLite.
With this PR we simply check if the file is already there and if it is,
we eliminate it.

column20:
Some images include devices like /dev/full which are quite complex to manage, as an example normal tar utility do not extract the /dev/full device.
The other alternative is to don't accept devices, however this will mean to avoid the abort() if every check fail.

column13: check for files that start with `./` and remove the prefix
column20:
Some docker layers have this peculiar structure of having the whole content inside the . folder.
Basically the . folder is the root of the tarball, and inside it, the filesystem tree develops.
This shows up as two characters ./ prefix when we are working with the file path that breaks some ingestion.
This PR fix the issue by removing the two char if present.
Given the semantic of the two particular characters, I believe that there would no issues. But I could be wrong.

The process is a little more involved that I though.
Ideally I could just pass a non-const reference and change the string in place, but the linter seems not so fine with that.
I would like to avoid copy the whole string everytime.
I settled for this solution right now that copies the string only if it need to be modified.
Maybe we can do better, but it seems a very minor performance concern.
Thoughts?
@jblomer

column13: [WIP] Shrinkwrap Utility
column20:
*NOTE: This pull request is not necessarily ready to be merged yet. The main purpose of this pull request for the time being is to make the CVMFS Shrinkwrap Utility code more visible
This branch contains the CVMFS shrinkwrap utility which allows the export of a specified CVMFS-Repository subset into a posix folder as well as various other formats (tar and squashfs supported through taring/squashing after posix export, docker supported through a docker injector).
The provided interface of the Shrinkwrap Utility is not yet final and quite possibly subject to change.

column13: Several fixes following integration tests
add permission for other to read and execute files
column20:
When ingesting a tarball we allow the user to ingest it into a specific directory, suppose tar/foo
Unfortunately, with the current permission, only the same owner of the repository will be able to see what files have been ingested, which is not very ergonomic.
I believe we should allow everybody to see the content of those folders.
column21:
When ingesting a tarball we allow the user to ingest it into a specific directory, suppose tar/foo
Unfortunately, with the current permission, only the same owner of the repository will be able to see what files have been ingested, which is not very ergonomic.
I believe we should allow everybody to see the content of those folders.

column13: Fix includes for libattr >= 2.4.48
Fix uploaded bytes count
column20:
I noticed that I was counting uploaded_bytes for duplicated files too, so I fixed it:
In StreamedUpload() I was using the bytes_written variable, but I couldn't tell if those bytes were actually duplicated or not.
In FinalizeStreamedUpload() function I can count only the real uploaded bytes, but I have to use a system call - stat.
I need to make this change for #2180's integration tests.
column21:
I noticed that I was counting uploaded_bytes for duplicated files too, so I fixed it:
In StreamedUpload() I was using the bytes_written variable, but I couldn't tell if those bytes were actually duplicated or not.
In FinalizeStreamedUpload() function I can count only the real uploaded bytes, but I have to use a system call - stat.
I need to make this change for #2180's integration tests.

column13: [WIP] Shrinkwrap Utility
column20:
Note: This should only be considered for a merge once #2203 has been merged.
This branch contains the CVMFS shrinkwrap utility which allows the export of a specified CVMFS-Repository subset into a posix folder as well as various other formats (tar and squashfs supported through taring/squashing after posix export, docker supported through a docker injector).
The provided interface of the Shrinkwrap Utility is not yet final and quite possibly subject to change.
Work left to do:

 Find solution for hardlink count problem
 Update integration tests to use our tracing/build scripts
 Possibly restructure the arguments of the shrinkwrap script
 Software packaging?

column13: Disable GEOAPI in incremental build script on Red Hat older than 6
column20:
The GEOAPI component seems to fail to build on RedHat 4 and 5 due to the very old version of Python shipped with the system.
This PR disables building the GEOAPI component in the incremental build script on these platforms.
However, I haven't yet understood why the full build is passing.

column13: Add option to create catalog during ingestion.
column20:
This pull request add a flag (-c, short for --catalog) that allow to
automagically add a (sub-)catalog when ingesting a tar file.
The catalog is added in the base dir, where the tar is "uncompressed".
I am not so sure about this implementation.
It is not a very clean design, we borrow a method from a nice interface
(AddCatalogMarker from CatalogBalancer), similarly when we are actually
adding the catalog (in SyncMediator::Commit) we are basically repeating
what is happening inside the CatalogBalancer.
However I believe that the implementation is quite reasonable and strike
a balance between functionality added and extremelly clean design.

repository publication scripts. This PR explicitly sets the compression to gzip.

column13: X509 Authentication Fixes
column20:
This PR fixes a segfault introduced by @djw8605 in the SciTokens patch - the wrong void* was being cast to an sslctx_info pointer.
Additionally, I took the opportunity to free up X509 data structures as soon as we hand them off to OpenSSL.

column13: Improve syslog messages for HTTP failures.
column20:
This splits the source of "host connection error" into three:

Actual connection errors to the host.
Timeouts from the download.
Host responds with insufficient data.

This should hopefully improve our ability to debug failures; the tweaked log messages were immensely useful for figuring out some issues with the LIGO repository.

Many thanks!
We have several places where we check for kFailProxyConnection and kFailHostConnection in download.cc, object_fetcher.h and swissknife_pull.cc.  These places now need to check for the additional error codes.  I'd suggest adding static functions like bool download::IsHostTransferError(download::Failures error_code) and IsProxyTransferError to have this check in one place.
I think we should merge this into the 2.5 branch and make the patch part of the 2.5.2 release (no ETA yet).

column21: It turns out that calculating the host name is quite a complicated thing to do, probably requiring reading the proxy & host urls back from the curl handle and parsing them, not to mention following redirects.  The syslog does show when proxies and servers are switched so it should be possible for the sysadmin to get that information, although that also doesn't show redirects.  I wonder if it would be possible & relatively easy to get the socket that was used from curl, and use that to get the IP address.

column13: Add backoff to busy loop in ReadHalfPipe
Script for submitting publisher statistics to a Carbon server
column20:
Addresses CVM-1571.
This script sends stats to a carbon server (graphite) using the pickle protocol .
Usage: send_stats_to_graphite.py [-h] <db_file> <carbon_server_IP> <carbon_server_PORT>
This script uses  last_timestamp_sent file to send only the new stats data form the db_file.
Format of the last_timestamp_sent file:

First line: last start_time sent for publish_statistics table
Second line: last start_time sent for gc_statistics table

If the last_timestamp_sent file does not exist in the same directory as db_file, this script will create one and it will write the current UTC timestamp in the it.

Addresses CVM-1571.
This script sends stats to a carbon server (graphite) using the pickle protocol .
Usage: send_stats_to_graphite.py [-h] <db_file> <carbon_server_IP> <carbon_server_PORT>
This script uses  last_timestamp_sent file to send only the new stats data form the db_file.

column21:
Good job, this is a great start!
Here's what I would improve, though:


The Carbon server IP, port etc. should not be hardcoded, but given as commandline parameters. You can use the argparse module to implement all the commandline parameter handling.


By default, the script should be "one-shot": it starts, it looks for any new rows, pickles them, uploads them and stops. The continuous mode can be optional.


You could create an auxiliary file alongside stats.db in /var/spool/cvmfs/<REPO> to store some information about which rows have already been uploaded. I think storing the number of rows and last uploaded timestamps would be useful. You can then implement the logic for only uploading new rows.

column13: Fix build on macOS 10.14 with Xcode 10
column20:
In Xcode 10, /usr/local/lib is no longer in the default library search
path. Our CMake scripts were just adding "-losxfuse" to the list of
linked libraries, leading to a linking error.
This patch changes our CMake scripts to use the library detected by
"find_package(FUSE)" and also removes some redundant variables in
CMakeLists.txt
column21:
In Xcode 10, /usr/local/lib is no longer in the default library search
path. Our CMake scripts were just adding "-losxfuse" to the list of
linked libraries, leading to a linking error.
This patch changes our CMake scripts to use the library detected by
"find_package(FUSE)" and also removes some redundant variables in
CMakeLists.txt

column13: Notification system tools
column20:
Addresses CVM-1575, CVM-1634, CVM-1635.
This is the first PR related to the CVMFS Notification System feature. Introduces tools for interacting with the CVMFS notification server and adds support to the CVMFS client for receiving notifications.
Summary of tasks in this PR:

 Define interfaces for publishers and subscribers to the notification system
 Add concrete implementation of a publisher based on cURL
 Add concrete implementation of a subscriber based on Websockets
 Add cvmfs_swissknife notify subcommand
 Integrate notification system subscriber into the CVMFS client
 Refactor logging in notification system classes
 Review documentation
 Review unit tests for new classes
 Run memory-safety checks (Valgrind or sanitizer) on SubscriberWS which uses libwebsockets.
 Add integration test

column13: Select "quick" integration tests together with various fixes
Fix cache control headers for S3 backend
column20: Actively set the cache-control header for immutable content-addressed objects under data to 3 days (previously: no setting) and for the .cvmfs... files to 61 seconds to avoid running into the Squid bug where "no cache" objects are cached forever.
column21: Actively set the cache-control header for immutable content-addressed objects under data to 3 days (previously: no setting) and for the .cvmfs... files to 61 seconds to avoid running into the Squid bug where "no cache" objects are cached forever.

column13: Fix cache control headers for S3 backend
column20: Actively set the cache-control header for immutable content-addressed objects under data to 3 days (previously: no setting) and for the .cvmfs... files to 61 seconds to avoid running into the Squid bug where "no cache" objects are cached forever.
column21: So Jakob, these are on the client side, correct?  Normally cache-control: max-age is set on the server side, but the client can also set it to reduce a time set from the server.  The 61 second squid limitation (with default squid configuration) is I believe only the server side.

column13: Fix cache control headers for S3 backend
column20: Actively set the cache-control header for immutable content-addressed objects under data to 3 days (previously: no setting) and for the .cvmfs... files to 61 seconds to avoid running into the Squid bug where "no cache" objects are cached forever.
column21: Also, what squid "no cache" bug are you referring to?

column13: Fix cache control headers for S3 backend
column20: Actively set the cache-control header for immutable content-addressed objects under data to 3 days (previously: no setting) and for the .cvmfs... files to 61 seconds to avoid running into the Squid bug where "no cache" objects are cached forever.
column21: It's during upload, so it's supposed to tell the S3 service the cache-control header it is supposed to send when clients ask for it. Regarding Squid, I thought we set the cache-control to 61 seconds because everything below that value is mistakenly cached without a time limitation.

column13: Fix cache control headers for S3 backend
column20: Actively set the cache-control header for immutable content-addressed objects under data to 3 days (previously: no setting) and for the .cvmfs... files to 61 seconds to avoid running into the Squid bug where "no cache" objects are cached forever.
column21: Oh, that's what you meant by the "no cache" bug.  That's right, if you're setting server cache headers, it should be a minimum of 61 seconds.  If you go less than that from the server side the max-age is ignored and the squid uses its default, which is typically 3 days I think.  The reason for the 61 seconds is the squid option minimum_expiry_time which defaults to 60 seconds.  So it's a feature, not really a bug.  frontier-squid-3.5.19 and later sets the default minimum to 0, but you can't depend on people running that.

column13: Tagging of quick integration tests, various test fixes
Tagging of quick integration tests, various test fixes
Fix gateway integration tests with S3 backend
column20:
This fixes a configuration error in the gateway integration tests with S3 backend: the CVMFS server tools were not configured with the gateway upstream address, but directly the S3 backend.
Most tests were finishing correctly, except the ones which involve acquiring a lease on a repository subpath. Trying to write files outside of this subpath should fail when a gateway is mediating the transaction, but succeeds when publishing directly to the backend, which doesn't have the concept of lease.
column21:
This fixes a configuration error in the gateway integration tests with S3 backend: the CVMFS server tools were not configured with the gateway upstream address, but directly the S3 backend.
Most tests were finishing correctly, except the ones which involve acquiring a lease on a repository subpath. Trying to write files outside of this subpath should fail when a gateway is mediating the transaction, but succeeds when publishing directly to the backend, which doesn't have the concept of lease.

column13: Support arbitrary subpaths inside S3 bucket
column20:
Addresses CVM-1641.
Using the recommended DNS-style bucket URL, it's possible to provide an arbitrary subpath for the repository URL. For example, using "/cvmfs", to maintain the familiar URL naming scheme for CVMFS:
http://<bucket_name>.s3.cern.ch/cvmfs/<repo_name>

This PR provides support for this arbitrary subpath, by encoding it into the "repository_alias" token of the upstream configuration:
CVMFS_UPSTREAM_STORAGE=S3,/var/spool/cvmfs/s3test.cern.ch/tmp,cvmfs/s3test.cern.ch@/etc/cvmfs//s3/cern.conf

This solution is backward compatible, providing a subpath is optional.

column13: Removal of unused files and code parts
Simplify the use of cvmfs_server {abort,publish} with repository gateway
column20:
Addresses CVM-1601.
In the presence of a repository gateway, the lease subpath
(i.e. repo.cern.ch/some/path/to/lock) only needs to be given to the
cvmfs_server transaction command. The abort and publish commands
can find and use the session token of the current lease.
This PR allows the following workflow:
$ cvmfs_server transaction repo.cern.ch/some/path
$ cvmfs_server publish repo.cern.ch
or
$ cvmfs_server abort repo.cern.ch

As per the existing convention, if there is a single repository configured on the machine, even the repository name can be omitted.

Quality-of-life improvement for obsessive compulsives
Fixes the reported language for the repository on GitHub: previously was falsely reported as C due to the large number of C files in the externals dir. Explicitly marking externals as a directory for vendored dependencies makes the linguist tool properly report the project language as C++.

column13: Add bionic repository to debian cvmfs-release

Enable creation of nested catalogs during ingestion
column20:
The first important fix is about the test.
The final $ is necessary to tell grep to match a new line. Without it,
grep match the few catalogs that have been normally added in the test.
(The catalog under /a and /a/b)
Then we simply fix the logic, adding a new empty file called
.cvmfscatalog into the repository. Earlier it was a file called as the
base_directory where the tar is ingested.... No idea why, but the
failure of the test I believe was shadowing the error.
Finally to make everything work I had to implement a method on the
DummyDirectory. Without the implementation it would call a method in a
base class that simply assert(false), it is not bad to implement that
method for the Dummy, otherwise we would have too re-structure a lot of
code for benefits that I fail to see.
Also address: #1163

column13: Several fixes to the shrinkwrap utility

column20: Throttles the S3 uploader for a maximum of 10 seconds on HTTP 429.  The default are 250ms, but if exists, the values of retry-after and x-retry-in headers are applied.  The last header wins.  Currently only supports only second values in these headers.

Added scan mode and updated stats
column20:
Added scan feature (used to track expected package size).
Updated stats for added clarity of data files vs file tree. This included changes to count and size tracking for accuracy and clarity.
Moved print loop into main traversal loop and wait loop(loop after traversal is done, but copy is not). The print loop was originally in copy thread, which leads to no or limited printing when updating large images with only a few changes.
Let me know if there are any changes and I will watch to see that formatting and unit tests still pass.

column13: change permision for dummy directory from 0705 to 0755
column20:
During ingestion this permision are applied when the directory we are ingesting into does not exists yet.
cvmfs_server ingest --tarball - --base_dir /foo/bar/fuzz

If any of either foo, bar or fuzz don't exist they have applied the permission we are changing now. It makes sense to give to the group at least the same permission level of others.
column21:
During ingestion this permision are applied when the directory we are ingesting into does not exists yet.
cvmfs_server ingest --tarball - --base_dir /foo/bar/fuzz

If any of either foo, bar or fuzz don't exist they have applied the permission we are changing now. It makes sense to give to the group at least the same permission level of others.

column21:
If you are able to publish without acquiring a lease, I suspect that you are using the session token that was already acquired through an earlier call to cvmfs_server transaction.
I think the cvmfs_swissknife ingest command should take the following steps:

Try to get a lease for the relevant path - if not possible, abort and inform the user (they can call cvmfs_server abort if there is an existing lease that conflicts).
Perform the tarball ingestion
Make sure that FinalizeSession(true, ....) is called on the Spooler object to commit the transaction on the gateway (see how it's done in swissknife_sync.cc):


  
    
      cvmfs/cvmfs/swissknife_sync.cc
    
    
         Line 915
      in
      ce33b7b
    
  
  
    

        
          
           if (!spooler_catalogs->FinalizeSession(true, old_root_hash, new_root_hash, 
        
    
  



If everything is ok, we are done. If there was an error, drop the active lease (cvmfs_swissknife lease -a drop ...).

Makes sense?

column21:
@siscia
There can only be one active lease on each publisher machine and the session token is saved in /var/spool/cvmfs/<REPO>/session_token_. cvmfs_swissknife lease -a acquire should give an error if there is an active lease.
Right now, I don't think it's possible to know which paths are leased.
I guess that with the ingestion, it becomes possible to have multiple concurrent "transactions" per repo on the same machine. Some thought needs to be given to how to handle multiple session token files.

column20:
This fixes compilation issue on macOS Mojave, without requiring the extra header package to be installed ( /Library/Developer/CommandLineTools/Packages/macOS_SDK_headers_for_macOS_10.14.pkg)
Ensure /usr/bin/clang is used for c-ares,curl,pacparser. The way it works is that /usr/bin/clang will call the compiler from the current active toolchain (either Xcode or Xcode Commandline Tools) with the proper include and library paths for the system SDK.
A bug in the configuration scripts of c-ares, curl and pacparser require forcing the use of /usr/bin/clang.

column13: Libfuse3 support
column20:
This provides basic support for libfuse3 without exploiting the new features yet.
The cvmfs client decides dynamically whether to use libfuse2 or libfuse3.  To do so, the cvmfs2 binary now loads the libcvmfs_fuse_stub or libcvmfs_fuse3_stub library, depending on availability and on the new libfuse=[2,3] mount option. The libcvmfs_fuse_stub library thus contains the code the previously was in the cvmfs2 binary.  The libcvmfs_fuse3_stub library loads the corresponding libcvmfs_fuse3 library.
This allows to add libfuse3 support simply by deploying the additional libcvmfs_fuse3 and libcvmfs_fuse3_stub libraries. For FC29, the sub package cvmfs-fuse3 does just that. It also ensures that updating and hotpatching existing libfuse2 based clients continues to work.

column13: Fix gateway key parser to handle adjacent equal characters
Allow garbage collection on repository gateway
column20:
Addresses CVM-1705.

Fixes an issue in the manifest generation on the repository gateway, that made it impossible to run garbage collection on the gateway.
Ensures that no root hash is written in /var/spool/cvmfs/<REPO_NAME>/client.local on the gateway after each commit. Without this change, the mount on the gateway was locked to the earlier revision.
Running cvmfs_server gc on the repository gateway checks that no leases are active and then temporarily turns off the gateway during the garbage collection procedure.

This is a temporary measure allowing manual GC for gateway-managed repositories. More complete GC functionality for gateway repositories will be implemented in CVM-1712.
column21:

Running cvmfs_server gc on the repository gateway checks that no leases are active and then temporarily turns off the gateway during the garbage collection procedure.

This is a temporary measure allowing manual GC for gateway-managed repositories. More complete GC functionality for gateway repositories will be implemented in CVM-1712.

column13: Include reflog checksum in the repository manifest
column20:
Addresses CVM-1732.

This PR makes the hash of the repository reflog available as an optional member of the manifest. This is needed for cases where /var/spool/cvmfs/<REPO>/reflog.chksum is not available, such as on publisher machines connected to a repository gateway.
The manifest signing tool (signing_tool.cc) now obtains the reflog hash from the manifest, if the name of a file on disk containing the hash is not given.
The cvmfs_server check command now falls back to the reflog hash contained in the manifest, if the "reflog.chksum" file is not present, for validating the reflog.
column21:
Addresses CVM-1732.

This PR makes the hash of the repository reflog available as an optional member of the manifest. This is needed for cases where /var/spool/cvmfs/<REPO>/reflog.chksum is not available, such as on publisher machines connected to a repository gateway.
The manifest signing tool (signing_tool.cc) now obtains the reflog hash from the manifest, if the name of a file on disk containing the hash is not given.
The cvmfs_server check command now falls back to the reflog hash contained in the manifest, if the "reflog.chksum" file is not present, for validating the reflog.

column13: build fuse3 on rhel >= 6

Adjust unit test nfd limit
Add breadcrumb abstraction for .cvmfschecksum files
column20: The .cvmfschecksum files are used to remember the last good root catalog in a local cache.  This is now wrapped in the Breadcrumb abstraction and part of the cache manager interface.  It should fix various corner cases with uncommon cache manager configurations, where previously it was unclear where to store/load the .cvmfschecksum data.
column21: The .cvmfschecksum files are used to remember the last good root catalog in a local cache.  This is now wrapped in the Breadcrumb abstraction and part of the cache manager interface.  It should fix various corner cases with uncommon cache manager configurations, where previously it was unclear where to store/load the .cvmfschecksum data.

column13: Fix root catalog reload logic
[WIP] Support fuse premount in mount.cvmfs helper
column20:
With these changes I am able to run mount.cvmfs directly from the new fuse premounting function in singularity PR 3679.
There are still a few issues I have noticed that I may want to add fixes for in this PR, so for now consider this a WIP, but these changes are needed minimally.  The issues I have noticed are:

fuse_session_loop_mt reports that it cannot support file descriptor cloning and disables it.  I don't know if this happens normally or not.
With singularity -p (which uses a process namespace) there are many defunct sh processes and a couple of defunct cvmfs processes.
Without singularity -p, cvmfs2 processes remain running after singularity exits.

column13: S3Fanout: MkV4Authz: fix wrong host when using non-standard port
Various fixes for issues discovered during integration tests
Notification refactor
column20:
This introduces some needed changes to the notification system client code, accompanying the migration of the notification server into the repository gateway.

New notification subscriber is based on Curl, uses server-sent events
Removed libwebsockets (no new third-party library)
Notification server URL handling is simplified - both publishing and subscription tools now use the gateway API root URL
Refactoring, cleanup, simplification, improved validation of manifests
The notification background thread is properly joined on mountpoint reload or unmount

column13: Swissknife filestats feature
column20:
New swissknife subcommand 'filestats'. Traverses the catalog tree and exports useful information into sqlite db:

catalogs table (number of entries, file size)
objects table (hash, size)
symlinks table (string length)
N-to-N files-objects relation (useful for deduplication stats, N-to-N relation useful for chunked files)
column21:
New swissknife subcommand 'filestats'. Traverses the catalog tree and exports useful information into sqlite db:

catalogs table (number of entries, file size)
objects table (hash, size)
symlinks table (string length)
N-to-N files-objects relation (useful for deduplication stats, N-to-N relation useful for chunked files)

column13: Ducc unitfiles
column20:
Create a simple unit file to run DUCC loop as a daemon
The first step in this commit is to create a template file for the unit file, the only variable in the template file is the installation prefix used by CMAKE. This is necessary since we need to provide an absolute path to ExecStart in the UnitFile.
The second step is to configure the template and install the configured file into /etc/systemd/system.
Finally we documented how to use the generated unit file.
We also fix a small bug on the loop command, if the recipe file provide is empty, DUCC used to go in an infinite loop doing nothing and not responding to signals : ddf6eeb
Still, the generated unitfile is not added to .rpm and .deb packages.
column21:
Create a simple unit file to run DUCC loop as a daemon
The first step in this commit is to create a template file for the unit file, the only variable in the template file is the installation prefix used by CMAKE. This is necessary since we need to provide an absolute path to ExecStart in the UnitFile.
The second step is to configure the template and install the configured file into /etc/systemd/system.
Finally we documented how to use the generated unit file.
We also fix a small bug on the loop command, if the recipe file provide is empty, DUCC used to go in an infinite loop doing nothing and not responding to signals : ddf6eeb
Still, the generated unitfile is not added to .rpm and .deb packages.

column13: Ducc unitfiles
column20:
Create a simple unit file to run DUCC loop as a daemon
The first step in this commit is to create a template file for the unit file, the only variable in the template file is the installation prefix used by CMAKE. This is necessary since we need to provide an absolute path to ExecStart in the UnitFile.
The second step is to configure the template and install the configured file into /etc/systemd/system.
Finally we documented how to use the generated unit file.
We also fix a small bug on the loop command, if the recipe file provide is empty, DUCC used to go in an infinite loop doing nothing and not responding to signals : ddf6eeb
Still, the generated unitfile is not added to .rpm and .deb packages.

column13: Remove raw aborts
column20:
Draft for switching to raw abort() to the possible use of throw.
The switch is necessary since we want to create a library libcvmfs_server.so where a raw aborting is not desiderable. However we would like to keep the original behaviour in the binaries.
The first idea was to have a much simpler function that using pre-compilation condition would either simply abort() (for the binaries) or throw an exception string (for the library).
This approach would imply to find good descriptive string for all the abort in the code. Some abort do not have any message associate with (implying that we don't expect them to ever been called), other are preceded by a log (implying that we are facing a known error condition).
Overall it seems complex to find reasonable string messages for all the panics and to format those messages correctly.
The proposed approach will allow to automatically replace either the call to plain abort(void) with a call to Panic(void) or the call to LogCvmfs(source, mask, format, ...) to a call to Panic(source, mask, format, ...) leaving untouched the original semantic of the calls.
Downside of this approach is the problem in compilation phase annotate in the comment.
Panic/3+ should be defined taking as first argument const LogSource source while now it is just const int source (it is correctly defined in the .cc file). Indeed including logging.h break the compilation process, this should be investigate and understood correctly

column13: Remove raw aborts
column20:
Draft for switching to raw abort() to the possible use of throw.
The switch is necessary since we want to create a library libcvmfs_server.so where a raw aborting is not desiderable. However we would like to keep the original behaviour in the binaries.
The first idea was to have a much simpler function that using pre-compilation condition would either simply abort() (for the binaries) or throw an exception string (for the library).

The proposed approach will allow to automatically replace either the call to plain abort(void) with a call to Panic(void) or the call to LogCvmfs(source, mask, format, ...) to a call to Panic(source, mask, format, ...) leaving untouched the original semantic of the calls.

column13: Fix active cache eviction of negative cache entries
column20:
This PR introduces a new kernel cache tracker, the nentry tracker, in order to allow for active cache eviction of negative entries.  When the fuse lookup returns a negative reply to the kernel, it inserts at the same time the parent inode and entry name into the nentry tracker.  The nentry tracker is simply a queue of such items.  It can easily be cleaned because the deadlines (now + timeout of the entry) are monotonic.  The timeout is by default set to 1 minute (CVMFS_KCACHE_TIMEOUT). This should keep the memory utilization of the new tracker under control.
For loading tensorflow, e.g., some 3000 entries get added to the cache. Starting ATLAS HelloWorld adds some 25000 entries to the negative cache, resulting in ~1.4M additional memory consumption.  This space is freed after 1 minute, i.e. after expiry of the kernel cache.

It can easily be cleaned because the deadlines (now + timeout of the entry) are monotonic.  The timeout is by default set to 1 minute (CVMFS_KCACHE_TIMEOUT). This should keep the memory utilization of the new tracker under control.
For loading tensorflow, e.g., some 3000 entries get added to the cache. Starting ATLAS HelloWorld adds some 25000 entries to the negative cache, resulting in ~1.4M additional memory consumption.  This space is freed after 1 minute, i.e. after expiry of the kernel cache.

column13: EL8 fixes to build and package system
Repository migration test
Ducc ChainID preparatory work.
column20:
Preparing work for removing singularity dependency and working with ChainID images.
The main contributions of this PR are two.
First of all, is now possible to compute the ChainID of a docker image.
The Image struct gains another method GetDiffIDs which returns a list of hashes (the docker DiffIDs). These hashes can be plugged into the new ChainID code to produce the list of ChainIDs on which a docker image is based upon.
Then, we create a new function ApplyDirectory(bottom, top) that simulate an union file system, applying the content of the top directory to the bottom one. The bottom directory is modified.
Whatever feedback is greatly appreciated @jblomer @janpriessnitz

column13: Use relative symbolic links in DUCC
column20: Address CVM-1817
column21:
Yep, something like the following should do the trick:
#!/usr/bin/python3

import pathlib, os

p = pathlib.Path('/cvmfs/foo.ch')

for x in p.glob('*/*/*'):
    if x.is_symlink():
        link_to = os.readlink(str(x))
        link = os.path.relpath(link_to, x)
        link = os.sep.join(link.split(os.sep)[1:])
        os.remove(x)
        os.symlink(link, x, target_is_directory=True)

With the benefits that we can check if this is work, and if not just rollback :)

column13: make catalina checks future proof
Several fixes for integration tests
Fix potential file descriptor mix-up of external cache manager
column20:
As discovered in the integration tests, the external cache manager can mix-up file catalog file descriptors if

the file system client gets reloaded
after the root file catalog got updated/remounted

This is due to the fact that during reload and restore of the previous cache manager file system table, the file descriptor for the newly attached root file catalog is lost. With this fix, the root catalog's file descriptor gets remapped into the restored file descriptor table.
column21:
As discovered in the integration tests, the external cache manager can mix-up file catalog file descriptors if

the file system client gets reloaded
after the root file catalog got updated/remounted

This is due to the fact that during reload and restore of the previous cache manager file system table, the file descriptor for the newly attached root file catalog is lost. With this fix, the root catalog's file descriptor gets remapped into the restored file descriptor table.

column13: External POSIX cache plugin
column20:
Add executable 'cvmfs_cache_posix', which acts as an external
CVMFS cache plugin and uses CVMFS PosixCacheManager.
Currently, it does NOT use QuotaPosixManager, so it does not
support object listing and cache shrinking. User can still clean
cache manually.

This is still a work in progress, but I am quite unsure on commit d5adde8 which does nothing but heavily annotate the function DiffRec, very useful during debugging, but maybe too heavy on the annotation.
The work is also being documented in this gist

column13: DownloadManager fix: switch hosts after redirect
column20:
When a host redirects to another failing URL, DownloadManager
incorrectly does not switch to next host. This is caused by
assuming that CURLINFO_EFFECTIVE_URL variable does not change
after a redirect, when it actually does.
Rewrite the 'do_switch' condition in SwitchHost() without the
help of CURLINFO_EFFECTIVE_URL variable.
column21:

column21: I'm not sure about the log source.  The log source actually only makes sense for the debug log, when you try to parse a long log and quickly want to grep for things or skip others.  For PANIC, things come to a full stop, so we simply can use kLogCvmfs as the default source and not bother repeating it for every PANIC call.

Parallel catalog traversal in GC
column20:
Implement CatalogTraversalParallel, a child of CatalogTraversal
class, which offers the functionality, but traverses the catalog
tree in parallel using multiple threads.
The interface of CatalogTraversalParallel is almost identical to
the one of CatalogTraversal and the two classes can be used almost
interchangeably.
Use CatalogTraversalParallel in garbage collection.

column13: add CVMFS_GEO_DB_FILE
column20: See CVM-1833.  Makes most sense to merge after #2469.
column21:
I really like this solution, but how it works when we are creating a new replica? Is the variable CVMFS_GEO_DB_FILE define and read in that case? Or we don't really care?
If I understand correctly we would:

first create a replica,
then set CVMFS_GEO_DB_FILE and
finally call the update-geodb

I was trying to avoid step 2 and 3 and it was getting quite complex. If this is enough I am more than happy with the result.
On similar notes, with Jakob we were thinking how to avoid the user to set the CVMFS_GEO_DB_FILE variable at all and use the system provided one.
Do you think it would be a good idea to check if the file is present in the default locations? And if it is present use the most recently updated one?
The default location at the moment are /usr/share/GeoIP for debs packages and and /var/lib/GeoIP for rpms.

column13: add CVMFS_GEO_DB_FILE
column20: See CVM-1833.  Makes most sense to merge after #2469.
column21:
On a new machine, people won't be able to create a replica without setting either CVMFS_GEO_DB_FILE or CVMFS_GEO_LICENSE_KEY first.  There should be no need to call update-geodb once they have set one of those, because add-replica will either create the link or do the download.
I don't think it's worth looking in the default rpm/deb locations, because I don't believe they will continue to exist.  On the other hand it might be worth looking in the default location from Maxmind's geoipupdate tool.

column13: add CVMFS_GEO_DB_FILE
column20: See CVM-1833.  Makes most sense to merge after #2469.
column21:
Indeed, in my understanding, geoipupdate updates the files in /usr/share/GeoIP (at least reading from the source and reading the default configuration).
I was hoping they would coordinate the location between debs and rpms, but ok.

column13: Use next-generation server code for `cvmfs_server diff`
column20:
The diff command is the first cvmfs_server command that uses the next-generation server code base. The current/old cvmfs_server mechanics works by shell code parsing the configuration and translating it into a cvmfs_swissknife low-level tool invocation.
The new code is fully C++. The command line interface code parses the configuration and the command line parameters. The actual logic is implemented in the new libcvmfs_server. Among many other advantages of this architecture, the high-level server-side operations (publish, snapshot, etc.) become unit testable.
During the transition phase, cvmfs_server forwards the command line invocation of rewritten commands without any additional handling to cvmfs_publish. Eventually, the cvmfs_publish binary will disappear for a general cvmfs command that will provide the command line UI of cvmfs (client, server, ...). At this point cvmfs_server becomes an alias to cvmfs server.
column21:
The diff command is the first cvmfs_server command that uses the next-generation server code base. The current/old cvmfs_server mechanics works by shell code parsing the configuration and translating it into a cvmfs_swissknife low-level tool invocation.
The new code is fully C++. The command line interface code parses the configuration and the command line parameters. The actual logic is implemented in the new libcvmfs_server. Among many other advantages of this architecture, the high-level server-side operations (publish, snapshot, etc.) become unit testable.
During the transition phase, cvmfs_server forwards the command line invocation of rewritten commands without any additional handling to cvmfs_publish. Eventually, the cvmfs_publish binary will disappear for a general cvmfs command that will provide the command line UI of cvmfs (client, server, ...). At this point cvmfs_server becomes an alias to cvmfs server.

column21:
In principle, looks good to me.  But I'd change the naming of variables from Docker and Singularity to Layers and Flat.  We have in fact three options for conversion:

Produce the flat unpacked image
Produce the individual unpacked layer directories
Upload the thin image

Options 1 and 2 are orthogonal, option 3 depends on option 2.

column21:
I built the current version of this PR and tried it and am not having good luck.  Here's my wishlist.yaml:
version: 1
user: dwd
cvmfs_repo: test.ducc
input:
    - 'https://registry.hub.docker.com/davedykstra/cvmfs-fuse3:latest'
    - 'https://registry.hub.docker.com/davedykstra/cvmfs-fuse3:testing'

First with cvmfs_ducc convert --convert-docker=false wishlist.yaml  I got the error
ERRO[0000] No password provide to upload the docker images  error="Env variable (DUCC_DOCKER_REGISTRY_PASS) storing the password to access the docker registry is not set"

The registry is readable to the world so I don't see why that was needed, so I set DUCC_DOCKER_REGISTRY_PASS to xx and then got these errors:
WARN[0000] Error in creating the wish                    error="Impossible to identify the registry of the image:  | Error in parsing the output image"
WARN[0000] Error in creating the wish                    error="Impossible to identify the registry of the image:  | Error in parsing the output image"
INFO[0000] No recipe to convert  

Aren't I supposed to be able to do without an output_format line with --convert-docker=false?  If I add the output_format line from the documentation then it seems to do the right thing.  However if I run it again I thought it would notice that there's no change, but I see it publishing both images again.  Also it leaves behind a /tmp/conversionNNNN directory for every image each time it is run.

column13: add flag to opt-out of docker conversion
column20:
WIP, still need to add test for this.
But it should completely address CVM-1786
column21:
Can you make sure that it publish both image again?
It is running 24/7 here and it is not publishing the same images again...
Please, understand that DUCC was born to manage Singularity and Docker thin images, with a lot of focus on the Docker thin images that use to be very complex to make. It seems like docker and docker thin images are loosing a bit of momentum and that they might not be so relevant in our future. But it will take more time on DUCC to adjust for it.

I am closing this issue since there is no reason for this to stay open.

column13: Build cvmfs-fuse3 libraries on Debian 10
Add feature to clone directory subtrees
column20:
Adds a CloneTree() method to the catalog manager that can copy an entire subtree to a new location. This is a meta-data only operation.  A first test with cloning /cvmfs/cms.cern.ch/slc7_ppc64le_gcc530 results in at least 50k file system entries per second.
Cloning is supposed to provide the core functionality for "fast flattening" of container images. Given that the chain directory for layers 1..n-1 already exists, one can create the chain for layers 1..n by cloning the chain[1..n-1] and then publishing only the last delta layer. See CVM-1801
