column13: Statistics ROOT plots + HTML page
column20:
Add a ROOT macro taking CVMFS stats DB and generating various plots to a ROOT file.
Add an HTML page which can display plots in given ROOT file.
Modify cvmfs server scripts to automatically upload the ROOT file + HTML page to upstream storage after publication/GC (only if the CVMFS_UPLOAD_STATS_PLOTS option is on).

Add a ROOT macro taking CVMFS stats DB and generating various plots to a ROOT file.
Add an HTML page which can display plots in given ROOT file.
Modify cvmfs server scripts to automatically upload the ROOT file + HTML page to upstream storage after publication/GC (only if the CVMFS_UPLOAD_STATS_PLOTS option is on).

column13: [DUCC] support wildcard in image specification
column20:
Adding tag wildcards to DUCC
This PR allow to specify images in the whishlist in the format of:
https://registry.hub.docker.com/library/redis:*

This will include all the images library/redis regardless of the tag.

column13: DO NOT MERGE: Test commit
Ducc gc better version
column20:
A rewrite of the GC in DUCC.
The new version is a little less smart than the old one, however it is much simpler and more complete in functionality.
It scans the whole tree and delete the layers and paths that are not in use anymore.
An upgrade to this would be to provide a grace period before to eliminate the files.
A possible implementation of this grace period would be to touch a .last_used file in the metadata folders of the layers and of the images once a day.
Eventually we would delete only the layers/images whose .last_used file is older than the grace period.

column13: Ducc gc better version
column20:
A rewrite of the GC in DUCC.
The new version is a little less smart than the old one, however it is much simpler and more complete in functionality.
It scans the whole tree and delete the layers and paths that are not in use anymore.
An upgrade to this would be to provide a grace period before to eliminate the files.
A possible implementation of this grace period would be to touch a .last_used file in the metadata folders of the layers and of the images once a day.
Eventually we would delete only the layers/images whose .last_used file is older than the grace period.
column21:
It was keeping a file to know what directory to eliminate directly, without traversing the filesystem.
Actual test show that traversing the filesystem need between 30 seconds (parallel) and 1 minutes (sequential) on unpacked.cern.ch .
Given that the performance penalty is very low, I opted for a simpler and more robust implementation.

column13: Ducc change naming
column20:
This address CVM-1838
It changes the external naming interface from docker to layers and from singularity to flat. I don't see many reasons at the moment to change also the internal naming.
Since we are changing the interface anyway I followed the suggestion of @DrDaveD and change the boolean flags (--convert-docker and --convert-singularity) into their negative (--skip-layers and --skip-flat)
There is also some enhancement to the CLI, making it more clear what arguments are necessary.
Finally we enhance the convert-singularity-image and upgrade it to convert-single-image that by default convert both the flat filesystem and layers, but of course accept the flags to skip them.
column21:

Statistics DB: prune old records
column20:
Delete old records to keep the statistics DB small.
Maximum age of records to keep can be configured by
CVMFS_STATS_DB_DAYS_TO_KEEP and is 365 by default.

column21: On second thought, I think we can factor out this optimization from the fanout class.  How about a FileBackedBuffer class next to the memory mapping utility functions.  This class would implement a buffer that can be filled first and then read back.  Internally, we can implement the logic of keeping small data sets in memory.  This class could then also be independently unit tested.

column13: Fix catalogs create by ingestion command
column20:
The ingestion command accept an argument --catalog to create a nested catalog in the directory where the tarball is ingested.
The implementation seems wrong, and, sometimes it creates catalogs of size zero but with content.
I believe the problem is in the use of the libarchive library, but I was unable to actually understand completely what is going on.
This PR takes a much cleaner approach to the creation of nested catalogs.
The error was found because trying to open a .cvmfscatalog file resulted in an I/O error, moreover, the file pointed to an hash that actually contains content.
At the moment I don't see anymore I/O errors while trying to open the .cvmfscatalog, but it is true that the error was transient. Given the PR,  however, I don't expect the .cvmfscatalog file to have any content.
Maybe we could add a runtime check to make sure that the declared size of files is actually correct.

This PR takes a much cleaner approach to the creation of nested catalogs.
The error was found because trying to open a .cvmfscatalog file resulted in an I/O error, moreover, the file pointed to an hash that actually contains content.
At the moment I don't see anymore I/O errors while trying to open the .cvmfscatalog, but it is true that the error was transient. Given the PR,  however, I don't expect the .cvmfscatalog file to have any content.

I believe the problem is in the use of the libarchive library, but I was unable to actually understand completely what is going on.
This PR takes a much cleaner approach to the creation of nested catalogs.
The error was found because trying to open a .cvmfscatalog file resulted in an I/O error, moreover, the file pointed to an hash that actually contains content.
At the moment I don't see anymore I/O errors while trying to open the .cvmfscatalog, but it is true that the error was transient. Given the PR,  however, I don't expect the .cvmfscatalog file to have any content.
Maybe we could add a runtime check to make sure that the declared size of files is actually correct.
column21: Actually, this should be opened against the 2.7 branch and only then merged into devel

column13: Fix catalogs create by ingestion command
column20:
The ingestion command accept an argument --catalog to create a nested catalog in the directory where the tarball is ingested.
The implementation seems wrong, and, sometimes it creates catalogs of size zero but with content.
I believe the problem is in the use of the libarchive library, but I was unable to actually understand completely what is going on.
This PR takes a much cleaner approach to the creation of nested catalogs.
The error was found because trying to open a .cvmfscatalog file resulted in an I/O error, moreover, the file pointed to an hash that actually contains content.
At the moment I don't see anymore I/O errors while trying to open the .cvmfscatalog, but it is true that the error was transient. Given the PR,  however, I don't expect the .cvmfscatalog file to have any content.
Maybe we could add a runtime check to make sure that the declared size of files is actually correct.

column13: Optimize loading of nested catalogs
[DO NOT MERGE][DUCC] remove singularity as dependency
column20:
This PR removes singularity dependencies from DUCC.
It is based on the concept of ChainID, however it use a naive copy of directories, which makes the whole business quite slow.
We plan to merge this when the fast-copy of directories get implemented and merge in cvmfs.
I also took a change to update the dependencies, this in retrospective might have been a mistake since it add a lot of noise to the PR. Sorry.
column21:
This PR removes singularity dependencies from DUCC.
It is based on the concept of ChainID, however it use a naive copy of directories, which makes the whole business quite slow.
We plan to merge this when the fast-copy of directories get implemented and merge in cvmfs.
I also took a change to update the dependencies, this in retrospective might have been a mistake since it add a lot of noise to the PR. Sorry.

column13: Next-generation server code for `cvmfs_server transaction`
column20:
Implements cvmfs_server transaction using libcvmfs_server. Remaining todos:

 In order to test lease handling, a mock gateway server is required.
Retry logic (up for later)
 Return value should indicate the why a transaction cannot be started

This will introduce a change to the rarely used retry parameters of transaction: instead of specifying the backoff parameters individually, the new code simply expects the maximum retry duration.

Retry logic (up for later)
 Return value should indicate the why a transaction cannot be started

This will introduce a change to the rarely used retry parameters of transaction: instead of specifying the backoff parameters individually, the new code simply expects the maximum retry duration.

column13: Change cvmfs_server transaction return code
column20: quired
column21:
This pull request proposes to change the return code for cvmfs_server transaction in several cases. I would find it useful to know when the failure is due to user errors:

when a transaction already exists
when a lock already was taken for path we want to lease
I tried to find meaningful return code, and looking at the standard error numbers, I thought that EEXISTS and EBUSY could make sense.

column13: sketch for publish/diff for transaction
column20:
This is a sketch for a first implementation of the diff command.
It will allow to make the diff between different tags but it will also show the differences in the current transaction.
There are few things to fix, but the overall architecture should stay.

column13: Add quantiles computation to Log2Histogram
column20:
Quantiles are useful for performance and regression tests on the
client side.
This was suppose to be one of the first tasks of the summer student. Nevertheless I believe it is important to keep this development line open as well.
It would be interesting to have a command to spit out just this numbers so that we can compare the performance on the client programmatically from different installation and user bases.
At the moment the output produced is somehow like this:

help
cpplint
unittest + [full] + [ducc] + [linux] + [mac]
cloudtest + [full] + [nodestroy] + [cc7]
all

column13: Make fast check for images
column20:
Checking if an image is already in DUCC / unpacked is an IO bound task.
We need to fetch the manifest from the registry.
Before this PR the fetch of manifest was done sequentially, in a synchronous way.
Now we pre-fetch the manifest asynchronously.
We replace a standard vector with a go channel and we use goroutines to actually get the manifests.
Improvements in time are significant, from ~5min to ~20second.
column21:
Checking if an image is already in DUCC / unpacked is an IO bound task.
We need to fetch the manifest from the registry.
Before this PR the fetch of manifest was done sequentially, in a synchronous way.
Now we pre-fetch the manifest asynchronously.
We replace a standard vector with a go channel and we use goroutines to actually get the manifests.
Improvements in time are significant, from ~5min to ~20second.

column13: Add 'chunks_access' xattr listing regular file chunks
use different channels for layers and flat conversion
column20:
A channel can be read from only once, so while we try to read
from the same channel twice (once for the layer conversion and
another time for the flat conversion) the second read will be
empty.
Different solutions might work but I find simpler to just use
two different channels.
column21:

from the same channel twice (once for the layer conversion and

Different solutions might work but I find simpler to just use
two different channels.

column13: Add a hidden `cvmfs_server eliminate-bulk-hashes` command
column20: The command removes bulk hashes from files that also exist in chunked form.
column21:
2169 had the command.
I hadn't thought it through enough to realize it would only work on stratum 0s, but of course that's the case.  The smallest repository I found that was affected was geant4.cern.ch, so on my test stratum 1 I converted that repository into a stratum 0 with rmfs -p and import -t -r.  It required a masterkey which I didn't have handy so I created a temporary repository, copied the .masterkey and .pub, and deleted the temporary repository.  I had quite a hassle with import complaining about no .cvmfsreflog so I should delete reflog.chksum, but there was no such file.  I figured out it was reading the hash from .cvmfspublished, and was able to get it to work after downloading .cvmfsreflog from the FNAL stratum 1.  I ran eliminate-bulk-hashes, enabled gc and ran it, but it didn't delete the bulk files.  Now I'm taking a fresh snapshot which should hopefully do it.

column13: Add a hidden `cvmfs_server eliminate-bulk-hashes` command
column20: The command removes bulk hashes from files that also exist in chunked form.
column21: The command removes the reference of bulk hashes from the trunk catalog revision.  You might have it still referenced in previous tags (e.g. trunk-previous). The garbage collection can only kick in once all the historic tags are phased out (by more recent publishes) or removed.

The apache log showed the file downloaded OK.  I ran it twice and it stopped at the same point.  I thought it might be a file descriptor problem, and indeed after I increased ulimit -n from 16384 to 132000 it has gotten past that point and is still running.

column21:
Interesting!  For the remaining large files, CMS needs to touch them to trigger re-publication in chunks.
Not sure why the cvmfs gc did not kick in.  It might have saved the last few revisions behind your back.  Can you try with cvmfs_server gc -r0 which should avoid the silently kept revisions.

column13: Add a hidden `cvmfs_server eliminate-bulk-hashes` command
column20: The command removes bulk hashes from files that also exist in chunked form.
column21:
Using gc -r0 worked.
I found there are 487 remaining files greater than 17000K compressed, adding up to only 15G.  It's not worth doing anything about them to save space, but if the files are still accessed I'd be concerned about the impact they might have on squids. All but 8 are less than 100M, and only two are more than 160M (a 311M and a 556M) so maybe I'll only ask them to republish those. column13: Update cvmfs-config-default for a config-repo based configuration
column20:
As discussed in CVM-1085.  The corresponding configuration repository is the default branch of cvmfs-contrib/config-repo.  I tested it by putting that contents into my own test repository, then setting CVMFS_CONFIG_REPOSITORY to point to it in a /etc/cvmfs/default.d/95-dwd.conf.  The configuration repository contents will need to be published before this is released.
I have seen one problem with this on Debian, in that when I upgrade from the current version of cvmfs-config-default to this version, it does not remove the files under /etc/cvmfs that got removed even though they hadn't been modified.  I don't know if that's just my test machine, something in the package definition, or what.  That will need further investigation before this is merged but I wanted to get it started being reviewed, and maybe someone else knows the answer to this problem.

column13: BUGFIX: div by 0 in generate_stats_plots.C ROOT macro
column20: start_time and finish_time fields in statistics database are precise to one second. If the operation takes less than one second, the duration (finish_time - start_time) would be 0. If this happens, add 0.5 second so we do not divide by 0.
column21: start_time and finish_time fields in statistics database are precise to one second. If the operation takes less than one second, the duration (finish_time - start_time) would be 0. If this happens, add 0.5 second so we do not divide by 0.

column13: [CVM-1697] Receiver error propagate to client and gateway
column20:
This PR should propagate the exception from the the receiver to the gateway, for logging, and to the client to give feedback to the user.
Should address: CVM-1697
column21:
Hummm it is not an easy fix.
We need to escape strings because the stacktrace will contains characters that need escaping, however, when we create nested object, we just pass a string, that get escaped twice, which is wrong and generate the wrong JSON.
The option that I see at the moment are:

hack it around, adding another parameter to the JSON creator to decide if escape or not the strings.
Create a hierarchical structure to manage complex JSON
Include some external library that generate JSON for us

I want to explore how complex is 2 first, but maybe we can just go for 1.

column13: Create container integration tests
column20: Adds a new EL8 based platform to test various container runtime integration scenarios with a new suite of tests.  This should serve both as a regular integration test suite and as a documentation on how to use cvmfs with containers.

Fix generation of JSON snippets
column20:
The gateway tests showed a small mistake on the statistics manager. It didn't handle correctly the case of no statistics while generating the JSON.
The JSON was generated by hand, but we do have an interface to generate valid JSON, hence I decided to let the statistics use the already present interface.
In doing so, however I would have introduced some dependencies (util/pointer.cc and json_document.cc) to  all the code that use the statistic class.
So I refactor our own JSON generation in a separate, header only, file.
I transition from a struct + function to a simple class, and rename in what I believe is more appropriate.
Also I modified the interface in something more ergonomic.
In modifying the interface, however, I broke the receiver/reactor.h interface. It was relying on raw pointer and checking them. I am not sure I understand why.
Hence I also re-work the interface of the reactor in something that seems better.
Overall, this PR fix a small error, add a test, make some interface more ergonomics in -7 lines of code! Yeaaah! :)
@janpriessnitz does it LGTY? Are the JSON code equivalent?
@jblomer I am making some mistake in refactoring the reactor to accept a reference to a string instead of a raw pointer? I really don't understand why that choice was made.

column21:
The unit test output says CC7 passes. Ubuntu and SuSE both fail though.
So it turns out Ubuntu and SuSE fiddle with the output of gcc -version to insert the distro name in the parentheses.
CMAKE_C_COMPILER_VERSION is available back to at least CMake 2.8.10, which is older than what's in SLC6. Is there any reason cvmfs can't use that?

column21:
I am thinking what it would mean to use a temp file for the stacktrace, and it is not as trivial as it seems.
The approach I considered are:

Create a temp file, I need to delete those files if not needed (most of the times) and I would rely on some RAII, that eventually will not work when we switch to exceptions.
Create a temp file, save the path, delete immediately the file. I don't like the idea of making the system call only to get the path of the file and immediately delete it. But it is a strong candidate.
Write on os.getenv("TMP") some configuration won't have the variable set. Especially weird one that run inside jenkins or other CI
Just write on /tmp it is the less correct option, but the most pragmatic. Everybody understand it and it will work on most systems and it is simple to understand also for operators.

At the moment I am going for 4. eventually it will be simple to change for 2.

column13: add watchdog to the swissknife sync
column21: I agree, let's go for 4 for the time being.

Could you please give an example of how to use this?  It's not obvious from the code how to do that.
Regarding the use of colon as a delimeter between source and destination paths, I think that's not a good idea because docker uses colon to distinguish image names from version numbers, and both unpacked.cern.ch and singularity.opensciencegrid.org as a result has colon in many container image names.  I suggest perhaps comma, or semi-colon if we don't mind asking people to quote it from the shell.

Oh, I'm sorry.  I had installed the cvmfs client compiled from the branch but forgot to install the cvmfs-server.  I tried it now with a centos7 container and it was blazing fast.  I want to try it also on an atlas container.
I noticed that there's no description of the -T in the cvmfs_server transaction help.
It is convenient to be able to have one short one-letter parameter.  Maybe '=' would be a good delimeter.  It's kind of meaningful too, since you're making the two paths equal, although in programming languages it's the left hand side that's made equal to the right.  '->' would be more meaningful, but it would have to be quoted from the shell so that would be annoying.

column13: RPM packaging: fix selinux policy files
column20:
files_type() macro seems to be broken.
This commit rewrites the files_type() macro
in cvmfs.te into the expanded explicit form.
The commit should not change the original meaning
of the macro.
column21: @traylenator The problem is that the RPM selinux plugin wants to set some attributes on every file listed in the %files section, even just on package upgrade. With autofs mounted on /cvmfs, this is not possible and results in error. I'm currently trying to find out how to disable this plugin hook for /cvmfs.

column13: RPM packaging: fix selinux policy files
column20:
files_type() macro seems to be broken.
This commit rewrites the files_type() macro
in cvmfs.te into the expanded explicit form.
The commit should not change the original meaning
of the macro.
column21: @jblomer I think having a separate package, let alone a subpackage in the filesystem package, is not a good option for us. The hook which causes problems is fsm_file_prepare. Here it says it's run on every file in the %files section: https://rpm.org/devel_doc/plugins.html . That means /cvmfs cannot be in the %files section. I think the current dirty fix is the best we can do.

column13: RPM packaging: fix selinux policy files
column20:
files_type() macro seems to be broken.
This commit rewrites the files_type() macro
in cvmfs.te into the expanded explicit form.
The commit should not change the original meaning
of the macro.
column21: All right, thanks for the investigation!

From a tactical point of view I would ask to modify the podman flags to be negative flags, like the two others.
On an higher level, do you think we can come up with a design that does not force ConvertWishDocker to know if we are converting podman as well?
There are other things I would like to have clarified before to merge, but I do want to get the overall big design right at first.

column21:
Instead of CVMFS_USE_OPENHTC , perhaps the variable name could be CVMFS_USE_CDN ?
This way we may have a chance to consolidate and standardize somewhat, for example Compute Canada may use Cloudflare but not openhtc.io, while other organizations might use some other CDN, or there could be other changes in CDN implementation details. But it would be unfortunate and could lead to confusion if different communities or organizations had different names of the special variable that users have to know in order to enable CDN use.
For that matter, it would be nice if there was a keyword like "CDN" so you could do something like
CVMFS_HTTP_PROXY="CDN;DIRECT" but that would sort of bend the concept of the proxy list and the server list ; it could be hard to implement that behaviour in a way that maintains consistency.

column13: Update default config, use cvmfs-config repository
column21: CVMFS_USE_CDN is a good idea.  I was thinking that at least for OSG & EGI we could use unset/blank to mean default (which is enabled when CVMFS_HTTP_PROXY is "DIRECT" or "auto;DIRECT") and when set to "yes" would be always enable or when set to "no" would be always disable.

Several minor fixes for unit test issues
S3 over HTTPS
column20:
As the S3 is becoming always more and more widespread, some provider started to accept only HTTPS connections.
While this is not an immediate problem for us, it would be nice to stay up to date.
The main objective of this PR is to allow to create a CVMFS repo over HTTPS on S3 backend storage.
While reaching for this objective we also tidy up a little bit several pieces of code.
More checks are necessary, especially on the client side, but this PR might accidentally have add support for serving CVMFS over HTTPS.
Progression
We started by introducing another option CVMFS_S3_USE_HTTPS (default to false) that force CVMFS to communicate to the S3 backend over HTTPS.
The next problem was to detect all the time the string "http" was hardcoded.
They were mostly checks if the files is local or remote, we allow remote URI to start also with https and not only with http.
At this point we could start to make HTTPS requests, however they all failed since no CA authority was recognized.
There was some checks already in place, on the client part, to add CA authorities. We use to check either the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR or the directory in /etc/grid-security/certificates.
I refactor this check to work in:

the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR
/etc/grid-security/certificates
/etc/ssl/certs/
other less used directories

We try to be smart about which directory to load. Hopefully it will just work in all systems.
Then we make sure to enable the HTTPS checks and to load the certificates only if necessary.
During the development we also enable the errorbuffer provided by libcurl. It is not strictly necessary but it can provide useful information when something failed and I would suggest to leave it on.
One last touch was to enable by default the signature V4 instead of the V2 for S3. It seems that some S3 provider support only the V4.
What is missing

 We miss documentation for the CVMFS_S3_USE_HTTPS (added with: cvmfs/doc-cvmfs#150)

There was some checks already in place, on the client part, to add CA authorities. We use to check either the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR or the directory in /etc/grid-security/certificates.
I refactor this check to work in:

the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR
/etc/grid-security/certificates
/etc/ssl/certs/
other less used directories

We try to be smart about which directory to load. Hopefully it will just work in all systems.
Then we make sure to enable the HTTPS checks and to load the certificates only if necessary.
During the development we also enable the errorbuffer provided by libcurl. It is not strictly necessary but it can provide useful information when something failed and I would suggest to leave it on.
One last touch was to enable by default the signature V4 instead of the V2 for S3. It seems that some S3 provider support only the V4.
What is missing

 We miss documentation for the CVMFS_S3_USE_HTTPS (added with: cvmfs/doc-cvmfs#150)

column21:
@jblomer  As I was mentioning there is a last issue with the signing.
The sign is called inside runuser ( here the call ) and this reset the environmental variables that should signal to the download manager to use the system certificates. The system certificates are not loaded, and we cannot reach the HTTPS storage.
If I short-circuit the check (setting the variable here to true) for using or not the system certificates everything seems to work fine.
Not sure what is the best solution here.

column13: S3 over HTTPS
column20:
As the S3 is becoming always more and more widespread, some provider started to accept only HTTPS connections.
While this is not an immediate problem for us, it would be nice to stay up to date.
The main objective of this PR is to allow to create a CVMFS repo over HTTPS on S3 backend storage.
While reaching for this objective we also tidy up a little bit several pieces of code.
More checks are necessary, especially on the client side, but this PR might accidentally have add support for serving CVMFS over HTTPS.
Progression
We started by introducing another option CVMFS_S3_USE_HTTPS (default to false) that force CVMFS to communicate to the S3 backend over HTTPS.
The next problem was to detect all the time the string "http" was hardcoded.
They were mostly checks if the files is local or remote, we allow remote URI to start also with https and not only with http.
At this point we could start to make HTTPS requests, however they all failed since no CA authority was recognized.
There was some checks already in place, on the client part, to add CA authorities. We use to check either the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR or the directory in /etc/grid-security/certificates.
I refactor this check to work in:

the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR
/etc/grid-security/certificates
/etc/ssl/certs/
other less used directories

We try to be smart about which directory to load. Hopefully it will just work in all systems.
Then we make sure to enable the HTTPS checks and to load the certificates only if necessary.
During the development we also enable the errorbuffer provided by libcurl. It is not strictly necessary but it can provide useful information when something failed and I would suggest to leave it on.
One last touch was to enable by default the signature V4 instead of the V2 for S3. It seems that some S3 provider support only the V4.
What is missing

 We miss documentation for the CVMFS_S3_USE_HTTPS (added with: cvmfs/doc-cvmfs#150)

They were mostly checks if the files is local or remote, we allow remote URI to start also with https and not only with http.
At this point we could start to make HTTPS requests, however they all failed since no CA authority was recognized.
There was some checks already in place, on the client part, to add CA authorities. We use to check either the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR or the directory in /etc/grid-security/certificates.
I refactor this check to work in:

the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR
/etc/grid-security/certificates
/etc/ssl/certs/
other less used directories

We try to be smart about which directory to load. Hopefully it will just work in all systems.
Then we make sure to enable the HTTPS checks and to load the certificates only if necessary.
During the development we also enable the errorbuffer provided by libcurl. It is not strictly necessary but it can provide useful information when something failed and I would suggest to leave it on.
One last touch was to enable by default the signature V4 instead of the V2 for S3. It seems that some S3 provider support only the V4.
What is missing

 We miss documentation for the CVMFS_S3_USE_HTTPS (added with: cvmfs/doc-cvmfs#150)

column13: S3 over HTTPS
column20:
As the S3 is becoming always more and more widespread, some provider started to accept only HTTPS connections.
While this is not an immediate problem for us, it would be nice to stay up to date.
The main objective of this PR is to allow to create a CVMFS repo over HTTPS on S3 backend storage.
While reaching for this objective we also tidy up a little bit several pieces of code.
More checks are necessary, especially on the client side, but this PR might accidentally have add support for serving CVMFS over HTTPS.
Progression
We started by introducing another option CVMFS_S3_USE_HTTPS (default to false) that force CVMFS to communicate to the S3 backend over HTTPS.

At this point we could start to make HTTPS requests, however they all failed since no CA authority was recognized.
There was some checks already in place, on the client part, to add CA authorities. We use to check either the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR or the directory in /etc/grid-security/certificates.
I refactor this check to work in:

the directory pointed by X509_CERT_DIR
/etc/grid-security/certificates
/etc/ssl/certs/
other less used directories

We try to be smart about which directory to load. Hopefully it will just work in all systems.
Then we make sure to enable the HTTPS checks and to load the certificates only if necessary.
During the development we also enable the errorbuffer provided by libcurl. It is not strictly necessary but it can provide useful information when something failed and I would suggest to leave it on.
One last touch was to enable by default the signature V4 instead of the V2 for S3. It seems that some S3 provider support only the V4.
What is missing

 We miss documentation for the CVMFS_S3_USE_HTTPS (added with: cvmfs/doc-cvmfs#150)

column13: Add integration test for k8s daemonset
column20:
Following the OSG blueprint, this test demonstrates how to run a cvmfs daemonset that makes cvmfs available to pods. It might make sense to turn the configuration at some point into a helm chart.
@sfiligoi Many thanks for making the blueprint available! This approach looks like something we can maintain in the cvmfs development team. A useful bit might be the "cvmfs service container" (your nodeplugin image).  It's a busybox and the cvmfs client in a docker container image that is now regularly built together with all the other cvmfs packages.

Debian Packaging: Only recommend apache2
column20:
cvmfs-server currently strictly depends on apache2.
On a publisher node, one does not need apache2.
So turn the "Depends: apache2" into a "Recommends: apache2".
Recommends means "You really should install this. If you don't, expect missing functionality". Which fits very well: If one does not install apache2, one can't run a stratum-0.

Recommends means "You really should install this. If you don't, expect missing functionality". Which fits very well: If one does not install apache2, one can't run a stratum-0.

Add support for WSL2
column20:
Version 2 of the Windows sub sytem for Linux starts a full, virtualized Linux kernel with fuse and autofs support.  Therefore, cvmfs can be used on the available distributions almost like on their native counterparts.  One difference is that the WSL2 Linux starts like being in singe-user mode.  The /init process is not systemd but a custom one.  So systemd, even though available as a binary, cannot be used as service manager.  This patch adds a cvmfs_config wsl2_start command to manually start the automounter.  Whenever opening a WSL2 Linux terminal, one needs to write sudo cvmfs_config wsl2_start to find the normal autofs-managed /cvmfs area.
Tested on Ubuntu 20.04 / WSL2.

Add `cvmfs_server enter` command
column20:
The cvmfs_publish enter command opens a writable subshell given read-only access to a repository.  It does so by

Creating a user, mount, and pid namespace
Creating an underlay using the current root file system tree
Mounting /cvmfs/$repo with fuse-overlayfs

The state of the writable shell is kept in $HOME/.cvmfs
Corresponding ticket: https://sft.its.cern.ch/jira/browse/CVM-1924

column13: [WIP] Fix for catalogs from dirs to symlink
column20: Ref to: https://sft.its.cern.ch/jira/browse/CVM-1927
column21:
So the call is hanging in 
  
    
      cvmfs/cvmfs/swissknife_lease_curl.cc
    
    
         Line 90
      in
      4a66069
    
  
  
    

        
          
           bool MakeEndRequest(const std::string& method, const std::string& key_id, 
        
    
  


At first I believe we should add a timeout in that call.
We don't want to wait forever, maybe a long timeout, 1 minute?, but a timeout should be in place.
Then, we should understand, why the gateway does not return anything.

column13: importing s3 backed cmvfs and be able to publish to the cvmfs from new master node
column20: this patch will add s3 backed import capability to cvmfs_server import , and adds the remove_reflog_hash option to cvmfs_server publish; so that the first publish from the new master node can be forced.

column13: read credentials for different docker registry from env
column20:
This change should be enough to allow us to work with docker hub after the implement their rate limiting, providing a set of configuration variables.
It is necessary to add the environment variables:
DUCC_DOCKERHUB_USER
DUCC_DOCKERHUB_PASS
DUCC_GITLAB_REGISTRY_USER
DUCC_GITLAB_REGISTRY_PASS

I got a build error when building this PR:
go: inconsistent vendoring in /cloud/login/dwd/work/RPMBUILD/BUILD/cvmfs-2.8.0/ducc:
	github.com/otiai10/copy@v1.3.0: is explicitly required in go.mod, but vendor/modules.txt indicates github.com/otiai10/copy@v1.2.0
	github.com/otiai10/copy@v1.2.0: is marked as replaced in vendor/modules.txt, but not replaced in go.mod

run 'go mod vendor' to sync, or use -mod=mod or -mod=readonly to ignore the vendor directory

I see this was changed in a commit to go.mod today.  If I run go mod vendor as it suggests it updates the needed files and the build succeeds.

Ducc sneaky layers
column20:
This PR contains 3 main objective. In order.

Overdue refactor of the DUCC code
Implementation of the chain for fast image/user code ingestion
Updates of the libraries

While from a code hygiene perspective it would have been better to have 3 separate PR, none of the steps make sense without the preceding one.
Moreover, step 3 was kind of necessary for step 2.
I also write code that I ended up not using, but that could be of some interest, so I packed it up in a separate go libraries.
https://github.com/siscia/gooverlay
If code review get difficult due to the sheer amount of changes, I can split the PR. If that does not endup being an issue, I will leave it as it is.

column21:
So ... when does this go into effect? Is a new cvmfs service container built with each new cvmfs release?

Yes, so with 2.8.1, probably in March.

Does this make the behavior with respect to CDN and WPAD the same as the default in CernVM?

It's the other way round, CVMFS_USE_CDN=yes is yet to become the default in CernVM.

column13: Fix service container config

column21:
I just had a chance to look at this more carefully, and I tried running the currently released cvmfs/service container with -e CVMFS_USE_CDN=yes -e CVMFS_HTTP_PROXY=auto.  That failed with
CernVM-FS: loading Fuse module... failed to discover HTTP proxy servers (23 - proxy auto-discovery failed)

Would you have expected that to work?  I didn't have any luck with guessing how to get more debug info.  Can you reproduce it?

column13: Fix service container config
column20: @DrDaveD As discussed at the workshop, this fix makes OpenHTC servers the default for the service container
column21: Note that it failed on the first mount, when mounting the config repo.  I think the problem is that the config repo does not support WPAD.  Indeed, if I change it to -e CVMFS_HTTP_PROXY="auto;DIRECT" then it succeeds.  It results still in using the openhtc.io servers for all repositories, but the local proxy is found only for the non config-repo repositories.

column13: Fix service container config
column20: @DrDaveD As discussed at the workshop, this fix makes OpenHTC servers the default for the service container
column21:
What we do in the EGI and OSG configurations (rpm and config repo) is the following:
if [ -z "$CVMFS_USE_CDN" ]; then
  if [ "$CVMFS_HTTP_PROXY" = "DIRECT" ] || [ "$CVMFS_HTTP_PROXY" = "auto;DIRECT" ]; then
    # If an explicit site proxy and CDN use/nonuse are not set, use the CDN
    CVMFS_USE_CDN=yes
  fi
fi

The advantage of that is that it only uses the CDN by default when no explicit squid is specified.  What do you think about doing that here instead of always enabling CVMFS_USE_CDN?

column13: Fix service container config

column21: For the cvmfs-config.cern.ch repository, it should work with -e CVMFS_CLIENT_PROFILE=single

column13: Fix service container config

column21: I'm not sure which question you were answering.  I don't see how setting -e CVMFS_CLIENT_PROFILE=single helps anything with the cvmfs/service container.

column13: Fix service container config

column21: Oh it does avoid needing to set -e CVMFS_HTTP_PROXY='auto;DIRECT' but it doesn't affect the use of the CDN.

column13: Do not escape '@' in URI strings
column20:
RFC 3986 section 3.2.1 defines inline user information within a URI in
the form of "user:password@host".
The '@' character is currently escaped unconditionally when setting
CURLOPT_URL in DownloadManager::SetUrlOptions().  This causes any such
URIs to be treated as invalid and hence requests will eventually fail
with kFailBadUrl.
Fix by adding '@' to the list of characters that do not require URI
escaping.  The '@' character has no special meaning outside of the
user information field, and so this will not alter the interpretation
of any other part of the URI.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Allow for user information in DNS-resolved URI strings
column20:
RFC 3986 section 3.2.1 defines inline user information within a URI in
the form of "user:password@host".
The host name extraction logic in dns::PinpointHostSubstr() does not
currently understand inline user information, and will therefore end
up taking the username as the hostname.
Fix by searching for and skipping inline user information before
extracting the hostname.
This allows the CVMFS_HTTP_PROXY list to include proxies that require
authentication via the Proxy-Authorization header.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column21:
One problem was that OBS expects the spec file name to be .spec, i.e. cvmfs.spec. So the renaming is part of the proposed changes.
There are other issues: the cvmfs.tar.gz with the packaging subfolder unpacks in an unusual way to cvmfs/cvmfs which leads to build failure on OBS. I had to get the cvmfs.tar.gz from https://ecsft.cern.ch/dist/cvmfs, which lacks the packaging subfolder though, and upload that together with the renamed spec file from this repo to have a start on OBS.
It would be a great help for OBS (or COPR) or any other rpm builds to post (a fully working) cvmfs.spec on https://ecsft.cern.ch/dist/cvmfs
I don't understand how the cvmfs.tar.gz on https://ecsft.cern.ch/dist/cvmfs (w/o packaging and with regular unpacking) is generated from the repo, but at that point the cvmfs.spec should also be transported to https://ecsft.cern.ch/dist/cvmfs .

I'd like to keep only one spec file in the sources. If we change the name from cvmfs-universal.spec to cvmfs.spec, it would need further adjustments to keep our build and tests from breaking.  We might still decide to change the name but for this PR, please use the cvmfs-universal.spec name.
The source tarball is created by a script in the ci folder. Perhaps we could extend the PR to copy the cvmfs-universal.spec file as a cvmfs.spec file in the source tarball.

column21:
It would be best if a single cvmfs-universal.spec worked for OBS and non-OBS, and if we get that then at that point OBS can download it from github.

yes I fully agree "there can only be one", that is what I wanted to say. But due to e.g. fedora naming convention is should be cvmfs.spec, and yes, one should be able to link to it as e.g. a "OBS service" directly out of the github repo, or from the ecsft repo.

It might be nice to change the name, but I don't think there's a compelling need to stick with the Fedora naming convention.  cvmfs-universal.spec works too.

Note that currently the tarball from github (if you click https://github.com/cvmfs/cvmfs/releases) is broken (unpacks to cvmfs/cvmfs) for automated build systems. This is greatly confusing to non-insiders ...

That's true, and it's because cvmfs uses tag names that start with 'cvmfs' even though github always prepends  repository names to the directory names inside tarballs that it dynamically creates from the archives/refs/tags/-.tar.gz.  It's a github convention, and cvmfs hasn't used those downloads so far so the issue hasn't come up.  It's not clear to me that it is worth changing, however, since there is an alternate download location.
You haven't mentioned it in this ticket, but where you first brought this up on the CernVM forum you said your motivation was to get an OpenSUSE Tumbleweed build.  So far the CernVM project hasn't tried to use OBS because they instead have a large set of VMs in their own build system. It may be less effort for the CernVM project to set up an OpenSUSE Tumbleweed VM in their build system than to try to make the complicated cvmfs build work on OBS with all its different constraints.

yes I fully agree "there can only be one", that is what I wanted to say. But due to e.g. fedora naming convention is should be cvmfs.spec, and yes, one should be able to link to it as e.g. a "OBS service" directly out of the github repo, or from the ecsft repo.

It might be nice to change the name, but I don't think there's a compelling need to stick with the Fedora naming convention. cvmfs-universal.spec works too.

Note that currently the tarball from github (if you click https://github.com/cvmfs/cvmfs/releases) is broken (unpacks to cvmfs/cvmfs) for automated build systems. This is greatly confusing to non-insiders ...

That's true, and it's because cvmfs uses tag names that start with 'cvmfs' even though github always prepends repository names to the directory names inside tarballs that it dynamically creates from the archives/refs/tags/-.tar.gz. It's a github convention, and cvmfs hasn't used those downloads so far so the issue hasn't come up. It's not clear to me that it is worth changing, however, since there is an alternate download location.
You haven't mentioned it in this ticket, but where you first brought this up on the CernVM forum you said your motivation was to get an OpenSUSE Tumbleweed build. So far the CernVM project hasn't tried to use OBS because they instead have a large set of VMs in their own build system. It may be less effort for the CernVM project to set up an OpenSUSE Tumbleweed VM in their build system than to try to make the complicated cvmfs build work on OBS with all its different constraints.

There are two objectives:


cvmfs can become a package in fedora or opensuse (or debian) and thus become available to a much broader audience. For this cvmfs packaging has to follow the distro rules of course. A clean OBS or COPR build proves that to the distro. This also requires the spec file to have the proper name cvmfs.spec.


If a cvmfs build based on OBS "service links" (or equivalent in COPR) exists and works it is practically zero work for the cvmfs team to support TW, and various other opensuse variants, Fedora, Centos8 etc pp. OBS (or COPR) automatically rebuilds for any upstream changes, and also for any dependency package changes in the distro. If you do it yourself, you'll have to maintain and update a TW VM frequently and manually, and that is guaranteed to fall behind and become inconsistent.

column21:
Thanks a lot for the patch! See comments inline. Please also add a change log entry.
I would like to provide from our infrastructure a SLES15 build (see JIRA ticket). Assuming that such a build works fine on Tumbleweed, too, I don't think we would add an extra build & test node for the rolling release.

Thats a long shot, TW is meant to integrate upstream changes, so by construction you can't rely on TW being compatible with sle15. Quite often it is, but you can't rely on it. TW really needs a constantly updated build tracking TW changes. That is actually my original motivation for doing the OBS build.

Making 3rd party builds easy is great to figure out potential problems early on and to enable cvmfs on less used platforms. However, we'll continue to provide our prebuilt packages on a set of core / production platforms in order to facilitate the support. In case of problems, we give priority to the issues that come from binaries that were built in a well-controlled environment and where we have the infrastructure to reproduce problems readily available.

Yes sure. But it isolates you from your user community, because nobody can do the build in exactly the same way as you do it. When I worked with opensuse on the fuse crashes they gave us kernels built on OBS with their patches, that was very quick and transparent.

Do not include an explicit default port number within S3 upload URI
column20:
The S3 uploader will currently always include an explicit port number
within URIs (e.g. "http://mybucket.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com:80")
even when using the default HTTP port 80.
This is not incorrect, but unfortunately triggers a bug within libcurl
(see curl/curl#6769) that causes it to
construct requests that will be rejected if they happen to pass
through HAProxy.
Work around this libcurl bug by omitting an explicit port number from
the constructed URI when the default port is used.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

(see curl/curl#6769) that causes it to
construct requests that will be rejected if they happen to pass
through HAProxy.
Work around this libcurl bug by omitting an explicit port number from
the constructed URI when the default port is used.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Do not include an explicit default port number within S3 upload URI
column20:
The S3 uploader will currently always include an explicit port number
within URIs (e.g. "http://mybucket.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com:80")
even when using the default HTTP port 80.
This is not incorrect, but unfortunately triggers a bug within libcurl
(see curl/curl#6769) that causes it to
construct requests that will be rejected if they happen to pass
through HAProxy.
Work around this libcurl bug by omitting an explicit port number from
the constructed URI when the default port is used.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Do not include an explicit default port number within S3 upload URI

within URIs (e.g. "http://mybucket.s3.us-east-1.amazonaws.com:80")
even when using the default HTTP port 80.
This is not incorrect, but unfortunately triggers a bug within libcurl
(see curl/curl#6769) that causes it to
construct requests that will be rejected if they happen to pass
through HAProxy.
Work around this libcurl bug by omitting an explicit port number from
the constructed URI when the default port is used.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Fail readconfig when parsing config fails
column20: I noticed that if there's any problem parsing a repository's configuration, cvmfs_config showconfig does show a failure but instead shows a bunch of empty variables.  This changes the cvmfs_readconfig function to return an error if cvmfs2 -o  parse returns an error.
column21:
The problem is is that the cvmfs_config probe in the cvmfs_mount test function is failing with an error
PANIC: /cloud/login/dwd/work/RPMBUILD/BUILD/cvmfs-2.8.1/cvmfs/loader.cc : 786
must be root to mount with suid option
Failed to read CernVM-FS configuration

If I put a sudo ahead of that, it succeeds.
Without the change in this PR, the cvmfs_config probe still prints the 'must be root to mount with suid option' but it does not print 'Failed to read CernVM-FS configuration' and it returns a success code instead of an error code.
Do you want me to change cvmfs_mount to always put in sudo, or only when CVMFS_SUID=yes?

column21:
@jblomer I've rebased onto current devel, and refactored it to avoid using WritableCatalogManager methods (essentially by duplicating the logic from WritableCatalogManager::RemoveNestedCatalog within WritableCatalogManager::SwapNestedCatalog, so that there's no need to subsequently call WritableCatalogManager::FindCatalog in order to get the parent catalog object).  Hopefully this is along the lines you were thinking.
The previous version is still available within the mcb30:nested-merge-v1 branch.

column21:
Test 802 seems to be unhappy

The error I'm seeing locally is
PANIC: /home/mcb30/work/extcvs/cvmfs/cvmfs/catalog_mgr_rw.cc : 928
failed to swap nested catalog '/a': already attached

I think the problem is that the call to output_catalog_mgr_->TouchDirectory() ends up calling FindCatalog() and therefore attaching the old catalog:

  
    
      cvmfs/cvmfs/catalog_mgr_rw.cc
    
    
        Lines 703 to 707
      in
      65dd008
    
  
  
    

        
          
           WritableCatalog *catalog; 
        

        
          
           if (!FindCatalog(parent_path, &catalog)) { 
        

        
          
             PANIC(kLogStderr, "catalog for entry '%s' cannot be found", 
        

        
          
                   entry_path.c_str()); 
        

        
          
           } 
        
    
  


This violates the precondition that the old catalog has not been previously attached, and (correctly) triggers the PANIC error.
It feels as though SwapNestedCatalog() ought to be allowed to handle the situation in which the old catalog happens to be already attached, with the overall effect being similar to first calling RemoveNestedCatalog() with merge=false.
@jblomer Is there a reason why SwapNestedCatalog() should not be allowed to just detach the old catalog?

column13: Nested catalog merge optimisation
column20: This is an untested first draft of the nested catalog merge optimisation described in #2707.  It is compile-tested only.
column21:
Oh, I see. But in this case, let's just move down the TouchDirectory call in the merge tool.  We only need it if we don't swap nested catalogs.
I'm hesitant to detach because in general it's hard to figure out what exactly changed in the attached subtree.  We currently want to call SwapNestedCatalog only in a context where we didn't make changes to the tree, but the API would still allow for misuse.

column20:
The EXPECT_DEATH() macro will currently give false positive results on any catalog tests, since the act of running a catalog test via EXPECT_DEATH() will unconditionally die due to a failure to create the test catalog history database (rather than due to the expected failure).
This fix has the side benefit of making the EXPECT_DEATH() regexp argument usable, which allows the test to verify that the death occurred for the expected reason.
Fixes: #2717

column13: Avoid starting autofs for tests that require autofs to be disabled
column20:
The current logic in setup_environment() will always restart the
autofs service, and will then stop it if the test specifies
cvmfs_test_autofs_on_startup=false.  This causes a test failure if the
autofs service cannot be started (e.g. because the service has been
deliberately masked), even though autofs is not required for the test
to run.
Fix by attempting to restart autofs only if autofs is required by the
test being performed.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Do not consume 100% CPU while waiting for upload jobs to complete
column20:
The current logic in SessionContext::UploadLoop() degenerates into a
CPU spinloop while waiting for the final upload jobs to complete.
Fix by using an end-of-queue dummy terminator job instead of an atomic
flag, thereby allowing the loop to sleep instead of spinning.
There seems to be no need to use the atomic compare-and-swap in
FinalizeDerived() to guarantee that pthread_join() is called exactly
once, since the surrounding control flow already appears to require
that FinalizeDerived() is called exactly once.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk
Fixes: #2720

Webhook: registry application
Limit lsof to searching only the specified mountpoint
column20:
When performing an operation such as "cvmfs_server publish", a
substantial length of time (around 10-30 seconds on a typical system)
is spent in the invocation of lsof.
Use the "+f -- " option to limit lsof to listing only the
specified mountpoint, rather than listing every open file handle in
the system.  Experimentation shows that this cuts the execution time
for "lsof" by around 95%.
A side benefit is that any integration tests that involve publishing a
repository will also complete substantially faster.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

Yes. With gdb breakpoint set I observe the following execution sequence.

And crash backtrace log.

I suggest that we should also make copy assignment operator custom/private, or compiler will still invoke the implicitly-declared copy assignment operator. See https://wandbox.org/permlink/fhhYAiVg5Alo8vYT

column13: Do not consume 100% CPU while waiting for S3 upload jobs to complete
column20:
The current logic in S3Uploader::MainCollectResults() is a pure CPU
spinloop that lasts for the duration of any S3 upload.  The call to
sched_yield() ensures that other threads are allowed to execute, but
produces no blocking behaviour that will prevent the mostly-idle
thread from consuming 100% of a CPU core.
Fix by extending the existing pipe-based pointer queue in
S3FanoutManager to add a queue of pointers to completed jobs that can
be retrieved by S3Uploader::MainCollectResults(), with a NULL pointer
used to request termination of the thread.
Fixes: #2726
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

produces no blocking behaviour that will prevent the mostly-idle
thread from consuming 100% of a CPU core.
Fix by extending the existing pipe-based pointer queue in
S3FanoutManager to add a queue of pointers to completed jobs that can
be retrieved by S3Uploader::MainCollectResults(), with a NULL pointer
used to request termination of the thread.
Fixes: #2726
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

thread from consuming 100% of a CPU core.

S3FanoutManager to add a queue of pointers to completed jobs that can
be retrieved by S3Uploader::MainCollectResults(), with a NULL pointer
used to request termination of the thread.
Fixes: #2726
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk
column21: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

column13: Do not consume 100% CPU while waiting for S3 upload jobs to complete
column20:
The current logic in S3Uploader::MainCollectResults() is a pure CPU
spinloop that lasts for the duration of any S3 upload.  The call to
sched_yield() ensures that other threads are allowed to execute, but
produces no blocking behaviour that will prevent the mostly-idle
thread from consuming 100% of a CPU core.
Fix by extending the existing pipe-based pointer queue in
S3FanoutManager to add a queue of pointers to completed jobs that can
be retrieved by S3Uploader::MainCollectResults(), with a NULL pointer
used to request termination of the thread.
Fixes: #2726
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk
column21: This is compile-tested only at this point.  @jblomer Could you check to see if the overall logic matches the design that you had in mind?  Thanks!

column13: Graft uncompressed files via gateway
column20: Add the ability to flag grafted files as uncompressed, and tests to verify that uncompressed grafted files can be published via a gateway.
column21:
Is this meant to support grafting compressed and uncompressed files in the same transaction? To graft all files uncompressed, it should be enough to set CVMFS_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHM=none on the publisher node.

It does support grafting a mixture of compressed and uncompressed files in the same transaction, but my primary motivation was to make the process of using uncompressed files less confusing by recording the compression information within the graft metadata so that the publisher does the right thing without requiring the user to know about setting CVMFS_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHM.  (I personally messed up several times trying to get grafting of uncompressed files to work, and I suspect I'm not alone in this.)

column13: Graft uncompressed files via gateway
column20: Add the ability to flag grafted files as uncompressed, and tests to verify that uncompressed grafted files can be published via a gateway.
column21:
I'm hitting an error that I don't understand:
+ cvmfs_swissknife upload -i file1 -o data/bf/c7a4e4317c6601b632801b210d0359a6315a11 -r gw,/srv/cvmfs/test.repo.org/txn,http://localhost:4929/api/v1 -a sha1
Failed to configure gateway uploader. Missing session token file.

At the point that the error occurs, the file /var/spool/cvmfs/test.repo.org/session_token does exist, and a cvmfs_server publish test.repo.org at this point would succeed.
I can't find the portion of code that is supposed to construct the path to the session_token file.  The string "session_token" appears only twice across the whole C++ codebase, both of which are using it as a key name for JsonDocument::SearchInObject().  Where within the code does anything access this file?
Thanks

column13: Graft uncompressed files via gateway
column20: Add the ability to flag grafted files as uncompressed, and tests to verify that uncompressed grafted files can be published via a gateway.
column21:
That's right, the cvmfs_swissknife upload command only works with the local and the S3 backend.  It would be better to bail out with an error message when this is called with a gateway uploader.
In the integration tests, the gateway runs on the same machine that the publisher, so we should pick the backend configuration of the gateway.  You can get this original backend from TEST_CVMFS_RECEIVER_UPSTREAM_STORAGE in /etc/cvmfs/repositories.d/test.repo.org/server.conf.  It might be best to adjust upload_into_backend accordingly.

column13: Handle zero-length uncompressed objects in object pack consumer
column20:
The current logic in ObjectPackConsumer::ConsumePayload() behaves
incorrectly in the case of a zero-length object at the end of the
buffer: the loop terminates prematurely since the end of the buffer
has been reached, but the method then returns kStateContinue since not
all objects have been processed.  This causes the receiver to
erroneously wait for further data that will never arrive.
Fix by ensuring that the loop continues until either all objects have
been processed or an incomplete object is encountered.
Note that a zero-length object can occur only when using uncompressed
objects, since even a zero-length object will have a non-zero length
after compression.
Fixes: #2730
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Report modified nested catalog hashes as modifications when diffing
column20:
A change in a nested catalog hash value is not detected as a
difference via DirectoryEntry::CompareTo(), as exemplified by the
logic in CatalogDiffTool::DiffRec() to detect identical nested
catalogs.
The current logic will therefore not call ReportModification() for a
change in a nested catalog hash value unless there is some other
modification (e.g. mtime) to the corresponding directory entry.
Fix by treating a modified hash as a modification that should be
reported via ReportModification().
This ensures that any nested catalog swapping always occurs at the
highest possible level within the tree, thereby avoiding unnecessary
recursion.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Do not truncate recursion for a modification above the lease pat
column20:
Commit e9df405 ("Avoid recursing into paths outside the lease when
performing a merge") introduced a bug by omitting to consider the case
of a modification detected in a directory that is a parent of the
lease path.  Such a path is not within the lease path, but a child
path may still lie within the lease path.
Fix by continuing recursion if the current path is a parent of the
lease path, and add a test case that covers this scenario.

column13: Add support for cvfmsbundles file
column20:
Support for .cvmfsbundles files
To improve cold cache loading, a new content type, bundle, is introduced
(PR 2741). The bundle has a binary format of an object pack
A bundle specification file, named .cvmfsbundles, allows the creation of such
bundles on the server-side. The .cvfmsbundles file is maintained by the
repository owners. During publication, the bundles are created and
stored according to the contents of this file.
This PR will

allow recognition of the bundle specification files on the server-side.
enforce the requirement that such files must be regular and not a hard link.
Additionally, ensure that the file is in the root directory of a repository.
reserve the filename, .cvmfsbundles, for the bundle specification files.

Corresponding JIRA issue: CVM-1886

column13: Allow nested catalog to be swapped even if already attached
column20:
There exist situations in which SwapNestedCatalog() may encounter a catalog that has already been attached.  For example: if a directory is converted into a nested catalog then any child catalogs will be attached during the call to CreateNestedCatalog() on that directory.  A subsequent call to SwapNestedCatalog() for one of the child catalogs will currently hit an assertion failure due to the old catalog having already been attached.
Fix by calling RemoveNestedCatalog() to cleanly handle the removal of the old catalog whatever its current state, and then adding the new catalog as before.
Convert SyncLock() to a recursive lock, to allow for calling RemoveNestedCatalog() from within SwapNestedCatalog().
Add a test case to cover the issue as described in #2737
Fixes: #2737
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column21:
I'm actually surprised that nested_catalog->RemoveFromParent() does not cause any problems in the current implementation of SwapNestedCatalog. Shouldn't it distort the catalog counters?

I believe RemoveFromParent() already has to successfully update the counters to compensate for the removed catalog, and the revised version of the patch then applies the modifications due solely to adding the new catalog.  This seems to work as expected, based on the integration test results.

I think we can go a little bit different about this: currently we are already trying to find the nested catalog in the tree of attached catalogs. We fail if we find it. Instead, if we find it we can check with GetModifiedCatalogLeafsRecursively() if the nested tree has any changes recorded (it must not).
Since we have the catalog already open, we can then reuse that open file and don't need to redownload it.
I think from RemoveNestedCatalog we then only need the DetachCatalog call (actually better a DetachSubtree call), and we don't need to make the mutex recursive.

OK, will have a go at implementing this approach.

column13: Allow nested catalog to be swapped even if already attached
column20:
There exist situations in which SwapNestedCatalog() may encounter a catalog that has already been attached.  For example: if a directory is converted into a nested catalog then any child catalogs will be attached during the call to CreateNestedCatalog() on that directory.  A subsequent call to SwapNestedCatalog() for one of the child catalogs will currently hit an assertion failure due to the old catalog having already been attached.
Fix by calling RemoveNestedCatalog() to cleanly handle the removal of the old catalog whatever its current state, and then adding the new catalog as before.
Convert SyncLock() to a recursive lock, to allow for calling RemoveNestedCatalog() from within SwapNestedCatalog().
Add a test case to cover the issue as described in #2737
Fixes: #2737
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk
column21:

Since we have the catalog already open, we can then reuse that open file and don't need to redownload it.
I think from RemoveNestedCatalog we then only need the DetachCatalog call (actually better a DetachSubtree call), and we don't need to make the mutex recursive.

OK, will have a go at implementing this approach.

I've updated it to use this approach.  I find the code harder to read now, but it does still seem to pass the test cases.

column13: Fix potential crash when accessing extended attributes
Fix potential crash when accessing extended attributes
Fix potential crash when accessing extended attributes
Fix potential crash when accessing extended attributes
Fix potential crash when accessing extended attributes
Avoid diff recursion outside of the lease path during a catalog merge
column20:
The existing logic allows for recursion to be terminated early upon
encountering a reported modification that lies outside of the lease
path, in order to avoid wasting time comparing subdirectories that can
never be of interest.
Generalise this to terminate recursion as soon as any path that lies
outside of the lease path is encountered, even if such a path does not
contain a modification.
This generalisation requires centralising the concept of an ignored
path into the DiffRec() function.  For the sake of consistency, also
centralise the related concept of a reportable path, and test for
reportability prior to calling ReportModification() et al.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

path, in order to avoid wasting time comparing subdirectories that can
never be of interest.
Generalise this to terminate recursion as soon as any path that lies
outside of the lease path is encountered, even if such a path does not
contain a modification.
This generalisation requires centralising the concept of an ignored
path into the DiffRec() function.  For the sake of consistency, also
centralise the related concept of a reportable path, and test for
reportability prior to calling ReportModification() et al.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Introduce bundles content type in the repository
column20:
Introduce bundles content type
To improve cold cache loading, several files which are known to be required in sets can be bundled together and streamed as an object pack. This is the case, for instance, for well-known Python libraries (e.g. Tensorflow) that upon start always load a certain set of inter-dependent python files.
To support this, a new content type bundles is introduced. A bundle can have the binary format of object packs used by the gateway as a form to concatenate multiple objects in a single BLOB. Such bundles would be created using a special hidden file (.cvmfsbundles in draft PR 2736). Bundle files can be chunked the same way regular large files get chunked. Chunked and non-chunked bundle files would get a B as a hash suffix.
Corresponding JIRA issue: CVM-1886

column13: Extend catalog table to support bundle files
column20:
Extend the catalog table
The catalog table in the file catalogs needs an additional column that specifies a bundle ID that can be optionally associated with a regular file.
An additional file catalog table will register the bundles (or the respective bundle chunks) and their IDs
Corresponding JIRA issue: CVM-1886

column13: Add client-side support for bundle files
column20:
Bundle files would allow improving cold cache loading of certain sets files that are known to be required if any of the files in the set is accessed. The Bundle files would be created on the server-side according to .cvmfsbundles files
On the client-side when there is a cache miss for a file that is part of a bundle, the file catalog can be checked for the list of files part of that bundle. So the client can then decide based on the cache contents whether to download the individual requested file or the entire bundle. Being an object pack, the bundle would be directly streamed into the local cache.
For more background please refer to CVM-1886

column13: Add support for direct I/O files
column20: Allows to mark files as "direct I/O" during publish.  This can be a workaround for files that are known to be subject to in-place updates (see CVM-2001) at the cost of a performance penalty.  Also adds the direct_io extended attribute.

column13: Add support for attaching mount to an existing fuse module
column20:
Allows the mount helper to ask an existing fuse module for its /dev/fuse file descriptor and use it to attach the mountpoint. That helps when the fuse module serves a process with another mount namespace and has been unmounted from the system-wide mount namespace.
It requires a kernel patch.
column21:

It requires a kernel patch.

column13: Use systemctl to unmount filesystems when available
column20:
When systemctl is available, cvmfs_suid_helper will use it to mount
filesystems in order to prevent the cvmfs2 process from being
terminated unexpectedly by systemd (see CVM-1398 for details).
Generalise this logic to use systemctl for unmounting as well as
mounting, to avoid ending up in a situation in which the systemd mount
unit is still marked as active even though cvmfs_suid_helper has
unmounted the corresponding filesystem.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column21:
I'm seeing multiple failures during test setup, which seem to arise from the direct invocation of umount in unmount_and_teardown_repository(): 
  
    
      cvmfs/cvmfs/server/cvmfs_server_common.sh
    
    
        Lines 1258 to 1267
      in
      4793b85
    
  
  
    

        
          
           unmount_and_teardown_repository() { 
        

        
          
             local name=$1 
        

        
          
             load_repo_config $name 
        

        
          
             sed -i -e "/added by CernVM-FS for ${name}/d" /etc/fstab 
        

        
          
             local rw_mnt="/cvmfs/$name" 
        

        
          
             local rdonly_mnt="${CVMFS_SPOOL_DIR}/rdonly" 
        

        
          
             is_mounted "$rw_mnt"     && ( umount $rw_mnt     || return 1; ) 
        

        
          
             is_mounted "$rdonly_mnt" && ( umount $rdonly_mnt || return 2; ) 
        

        
          
             return 0 
        

        
          
           } 
        
    
  


All other unmounting logic in this file seems to use run_suid_helper, so I suspect that this logic should do the same.
@jblomer I'll update unmount_and_teardown_repository() to use run_suid_helper unless you think this would be the wrong thing to do?

Lots of the tests seem to be failing because cvmfs_suid_helper is reporting "Unknown repository":
Repository test.cern.ch is already present... removing it
Wiping local repository storage in gateway setup /srv/cvmfs/test.cern.ch
Unmounting CernVM-FS Area... unknown repository: test.cern.ch
done
Removing Spool Area... rmdir: failed to remove '/cvmfs/test.cern.ch': Device or resource busy

I have unfortunately not been able to reproduce this failure locally.
I've pushed an extra commit that bypasses the repository existence check for the root user, on the assumption that something in the cloudtests setup might be deleting the /var/spool/cvmfs/<reponame> directory between tests.  @jblomer Could you retrigger cloudtests again, if this seems like a viable fix?

column21:
@jblomer Thanks for helping me establish a test environment that reproduces the CI builders.  I think I've found the root cause - systemctl stop doesn't work on any autofs mounts, since there is no generated mount unit for those.
I tried extending this PR to always perform both systemctl stop and umount, so as to be able to cope with both autofs and fstab mount points, but it's getting to be far too messy.
I still believe that avoiding systemctl altogether is the correct solution (which would require finding an alternative fix for CVM-1398).  However, an alternative change that at least fixes the symptoms on Fedora 34 is to use systemctl restart instead of systemctl start - that is sufficient to make the mount happen as expected even when mixed with manual umounts.
Closing this in favour of #2752, which implements the systemctl restart approach.

column13: Ensure that filesystem is really mounted when using systemctl
column20:
On some versions of systemd (observed with systemd 248 on Fedora 34),
the systemd mount unit activity status seems not to track the mount
state.  In particular, the following sequence of events:

systemctl start cvmfs-repo.name.mount
umount /cvmfs/repo.name
systemctl start cvmfs-repo.name.mount

will fail to remount the filesystem, since systemd believe that the
mount unit is still in the active state after the manual "umount".
Work around this problem by using "systemctl restart" instead of
"systemctl start" in cvmfs_suid_helper.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Use "cvmfs2" as the FUSE fsname option
column20:
When neither fsname nor FUSE subtype is specified, libfuse will
default to using "/dev/fuse" as the underlying device for a mounted
FUSE filesystem.
This can cause some versions of systemd to infer a dependency upon the
dev-fuse.device unit, which is itself non-functional since the default
systemd udev rules do not set the "systemd" tag for the /dev/fuse
device node (see systemd/systemd#20236).  On
Fedora 34, this causes all CVMFS mounts to fail due to a timeout
waiting for the underlying dev-fuse.device unit.
Some code paths (e.g. in mount/mount.cvmfs.cc) already specify
"-ofsname=cvmfs2".  Add this to cvmfs/loader.cc so that the option is
used consistently for all CVMFS mounts.
This changes the entry in /proc/mounts from e.g.
/dev/fuse on /var/spool/cvmfs/test.repo.org/rdonly type fuse
to
cvmfs2 on /var/spool/cvmfs/test.repo.org/rdonly type fuse
and results in systemd no longer inferring a (broken) dependency
upon dev-fuse.device.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Use repository name as the fsname option for read-only mount points
column20:
When neither fsname nor FUSE subtype is specified, libfuse will
default to using "/dev/fuse" as the underlying device name for a
mounted FUSE filesystem.
This can cause some versions of systemd to infer a dependency upon the
dev-fuse.device unit, which is itself non-functional since the default
systemd udev rules do not set the "systemd" tag for the /dev/fuse
device node (see systemd/systemd#20236).  On
Fedora 34, this causes CVMFS mounts to fail due to a timeout waiting
for the underlying dev-fuse.device unit.
When using /sbin/mount.cvmfs, the code in mount/mount.cvmfs.cc will
specify "-ofsname=cvmfs2" (as a means of differentiating "private
mounts" from "system mounts").  This happens to avoid triggering the
systemd bug, since it prevents libfuse from falling back to using
"/dev/fuse" as the underlying device name.
Extend the fstab entries generated for the read-only branch of
server-side mounts to include the fsname option, using the repository
name rather than "cvmfs2" in order to maintain the differentiation
between "private mounts" and "system mounts".  This changes the entry
in /proc/mounts from e.g.
/dev/fuse on /var/spool/cvmfs/test.repo.org/rdonly type fuse
to
test.repo.org on /var/spool/cvmfs/test.repo.org/rdonly type fuse
and results in systemd no longer inferring a (broken) dependency upon
dev-fuse.device for these mount points.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

When neither fsname nor FUSE subtype is specified, libfuse will
default to using "/dev/fuse" as the underlying device name for a
mounted FUSE filesystem.
This can cause some versions of systemd to infer a dependency upon the
dev-fuse.device unit, which is itself non-functional since the default
systemd udev rules do not set the "systemd" tag for the /dev/fuse
device node (see systemd/systemd#20236).  On
Fedora 34, this causes CVMFS mounts to fail due to a timeout waiting
for the underlying dev-fuse.device unit.
When using /sbin/mount.cvmfs, the code in mount/mount.cvmfs.cc will
specify "-ofsname=cvmfs2" (as a means of differentiating "private
mounts" from "system mounts").  This happens to avoid triggering the
systemd bug, since it prevents libfuse from falling back to using
"/dev/fuse" as the underlying device name.
Extend the fstab entries generated for the read-only branch of
server-side mounts to include the fsname option, using the repository
name rather than "cvmfs2" in order to maintain the differentiation
between "private mounts" and "system mounts".  This changes the entry
in /proc/mounts from e.g.
/dev/fuse on /var/spool/cvmfs/test.repo.org/rdonly type fuse
to
test.repo.org on /var/spool/cvmfs/test.repo.org/rdonly type fuse
and results in systemd no longer inferring a (broken) dependency upon
dev-fuse.device for these mount points.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk
