column13: Reset restart counter after successfully starting a mount unit
column20:
Some test cases will perform a rapid sequence of mounts and unmounts.
Since mounts are performed by starting a systemd mount unit, this can
result in tripping the restart rate limit counter, with an error such
as:
cvmfs-test.cern.ch.mount: Start request repeated too quickly
Fix by resetting the restart counter (via "systemctl reset-failed")
after a successful mount.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Use "setcap -v" rather than "getcap" to verify capabilities
column20:
The format of the output from "getcap" was changed in libcap commit
177cd41 ("A more compact form for the text representation of
capabilities").  Test 585 currently expects the output:
/cvmfs/test.cern.ch/dir/capabilities = cap_chown+ep
but any version of libcap from version 2.41 onwards will instead
produce:
/cvmfs/test.cern.ch/dir/capabilities cap_chown=ep
Fix by using "setcap -v" to verify the capability set, since this
method does not depend on the precise "getcap" output format.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk
column21:

Derek McGowan

column13: Use "Cache-Control: no-cache" instead of bypassing system proxy
column20:
The get_item() shell function has an optional "noproxy" parameter.
The purpose of this parameter is unclear, but the most plausible
explanation seems to be as a means of ensuring that the download
fetches the current upstream file, ignoring any versions that may have
previously been cached in intermediate proxy servers.
This fails on any system where use of a proxy server is required for
all downloads, since direct origin server fetches are not permitted on
such systems.
Unconditionally add the HTTP/1.1 standard request header
"Cache-Control: no-cache" to force an origin server download, thereby
eliminating the need to bypass the system proxy.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column21: Where is this used from?  We have to be careful that it is never used from large numbers of nodes at a time.   It's generally much better to use something like Cache-Control: max-age=N where N is a number of seconds.

This is all within the cvmfs_server script: it's not code that ever executes on the client nodes.

column13: Allow use of proxy server by publisher and gateway machines
column20:
This patch series adds the ability to specify a proxy server to be used by a publisher or gateway machine in order to download files from the Stratum 0 repository.
This is particularly useful when the Stratum 0 files are held in cloud storage such as AWS S3: it allows for the use of an authenticating proxy (to avoid exposing the S3 reader credentials directly to every client) and opens up the possibility of using the proxy to cache files uploaded by a publisher so that the gateway does not need to waste time immediately re-downloading those same files from the cloud storage.

This is particularly useful when the Stratum 0 files are held in cloud storage such as AWS S3: it allows for the use of an authenticating proxy (to avoid exposing the S3 reader credentials directly to every client) and opens up the possibility of using the proxy to cache files uploaded by a publisher so that the gateway does not need to waste time immediately re-downloading those same files from the cloud storage.

column13: Add "noautofs" option to cvmfs_config setup
Add "noautofs" option to cvmfs_config setup
Add "noautofs" option to cvmfs_config setup
Treat HTTP 503 Service Unavailable as a possible proxy error
column20:
Proxy servers such as Squid or Varnish will typically return an HTTP
503 Service Unavailable error when they are unable to connect to the
origin server.  CVMFS will currently treat HTTP 503 as a host error,
which will prevent the client from failing over to the next available
proxy server.
Fix by treating an HTTP 503 as a potential proxy error (as is
currently done for any unrecognised HTTP 4XX errors).
column21:

column21: The current behavior is documented so at minimum if the behavior changes the document has to change.  In what cases is 503 Service Unavailable a proxy failure?  Why would we not want it to keep the same proxy and try the next server, the current behavior?  The cvmfs failover rules are based on the frontier client retry strategy and it treats all 500 series errors as server errors.

column21: If it's a matter of a proxy's outgoing network being down, Linux will typically try for longer than cvmfs does, so cvmfs will get a timeout and consider it a proxy error.  If it is connection refused, that happens right away but it indicates a server error, not a proxy error.  So are there any cases that a proxy will return a 503 Service Unavailable in less than 10 seconds that really is a problem on the proxy?

column13: Treat HTTP 503 Service Unavailable as a possible proxy error
column20:
Proxy servers such as Squid or Varnish will typically return an HTTP
503 Service Unavailable error when they are unable to connect to the
origin server.  CVMFS will currently treat HTTP 503 as a host error,
which will prevent the client from failing over to the next available
proxy server.
Fix by treating an HTTP 503 as a potential proxy error (as is
currently done for any unrecognised HTTP 4XX errors).
column21:
If it's a matter of a proxy's outgoing network being down, Linux will typically try for longer than cvmfs does, so cvmfs will get a timeout and consider it a proxy error. If it is connection refused, that happens right away but it indicates a server error, not a proxy error. So are there any cases that a proxy will return a 503 Service Unavailable in less than 10 seconds that really is a problem on the proxy?

Yes, these situations do exist:

A proxy in maintenance mode will return a 503 Service Unavailable
An overloaded proxy will return a 503 Service Unavailable
A proxy suffering a temporary DNS outage will return a 503 Service Unavailable

This is a case of type 1 vs type 2 errors:

If the origin server returns 503 but CVMFS considers it to be a proxy error, then CVMFS will erroneously send some more requests to the same origin server.  This will degrade service slightly.
If the proxy server returns 503 but CVMFS considers it to be an origin server error, then CVMFS will erroneously abandon the entire request and return EIO to the application.  This will cause a total failure of the service.  (We have observed this happening in real-world deployments.)

Given these impacts and since it is plausible that the 503 could be generated by either the proxy or the origin server, the safest course of action is to assume that it represents a proxy error.

column21:
You have observed these behaviors in squid, or only varnish?  I have never seen a squid in maintenance mode or returning a 503 for being overloaded.  I'll have to try simulating a DNS failure.
Does varnish actually do a decent job of being a forward proxy?  Last I checked it was only good as a reverse proxy, which cvmfs treats as a server.  If the problem is only in varnish perhaps there should be a non-default option in the cvmfs client.

column21:
I was able to reproduce a 503 error on a simulated DNS failure on squid.  The first time it happens for a particular host it takes longer the cvmfs timeout time, but after that squid negatively caches the error for a period of time.
This type of error can be distinguished between real server errors with squid, however, because squid inserts an X-Squid-Error header.  Does varnish have a similar header?  I would prefer to only treat it as a proxy failure by default if the extra header is there.  The 503 error is almost always a server error, and it's quite common.

column13: Treat HTTP 503 Service Unavailable as a possible proxy error
column20:
Proxy servers such as Squid or Varnish will typically return an HTTP
503 Service Unavailable error when they are unable to connect to the
origin server.  CVMFS will currently treat HTTP 503 as a host error,
which will prevent the client from failing over to the next available
proxy server.
Fix by treating an HTTP 503 as a potential proxy error (as is
currently done for any unrecognised HTTP 4XX errors).
column21:
The closest I can find to a standardised way to identify a response generated by a proxy is the draft RFC https://httpwg.org/http-extensions/draft-ietf-httpbis-proxy-status.html#name-the-proxy-status-http-field which defines a 'Proxy-Status' header with values such as:
Proxy-Status: SomeCDN; error=destination_unavailable

CVMFS could potentially apply a heuristic of assuming that if a response comes via a proxy (i.e. is not DIRECT) and includes a Proxy-Status header which includes an error= indication, then this response represents a proxy error rather than an origin server error.
We can configure our proxy to include a Proxy-Status header for any synthesised response, so this would work for our setup, and would hopefully become generally useful in future once the Proxy-Status header is more widely supported.

If you're using varnish as a forward proxy and can recommend a specific configuration for use with cvmfs I suggest that you also submit an update to the cvmfs documentation with that recommendation.

column21:
Good find. I would support that, and have it also look for X-Squid-Error which would take care of the vast majority of existing deployments.

I'm happy to implement support for both Proxy-Status and X-Squid-Error if that is the preferred approach.  @jblomer do you have any comments?

If you're using varnish as a forward proxy and can recommend a specific configuration for use with cvmfs I suggest that you also submit an update to the cvmfs documentation with that recommendation.

We are using Varnish configured as a pseudo-forward proxy: it has a limited set of predefined backends (one per CVMFS upstream) so appears similar to a normal proxy with a very strict access policy.  I'm not sure how much of our implementation is generally applicable, but we could think about pulling together some documentation.

column21:
I'm happy to implement support for both Proxy-Status and X-Squid-Error if that is the preferred approach. @jblomer do you have any comments?

I think that makes sense! It was always a problem that we could not clearly distinguish between proxy and server errors and this approach hopefully gives us a good heuristics.

We are using Varnish configured as a pseudo-forward proxy: it has a limited set of predefined backends (one per CVMFS upstream) so appears similar to a normal proxy with a very strict access policy. I'm not sure how much of our implementation is generally applicable, but we could think about pulling together some documentation.

That would be much appreciated!

column13: [ducc] Fix authenticated requests to registries
column20:
Rename DUCC_DOCKER_REGISTRY_PASS --> DUCC_OUTPUT_REGISTRY_PASS.
Introduces DUCC_AUTH_REGISTRIES=val1,val2,... environment variable to
specify names of registries requiring user name and password. For each
$name from the list, there needs to be 3 environment variables
DUCC_$name_USER
DUCC_$name_PASS
DUCC_$name_IDENT

The last one is a string that is used to identify URLs of that registry,
e.g. "registry.hub.docker.com".

column13: Add diagnostics utility to identify repos at risk to become zombies
column20:
This utility is supposed to run as root. It identifies processes that run in a different mount namespace and have a file descriptor open on a cvmfs repository.  The output can be used to actively "ping" the repositories in the system/root mount namespace so that the automounter does not unmount them.  It is a workaround for the issue fixed in CVM-2004.
Compile with
g++ -Wall -o find_zombie find_zombie.cc

@DrDaveD Perhaps this could be interesting for batch farm admins in addition to cvmfs_config fuser.

Is there still a separate gateway package, or is it just cvmfs-server now?

column13: Kill any remaining cvmfs_receiver processes when stopping gateway service
column21:
I think killall is part of the psmisc package (at least on EL), which we should then make dependency of the cvmfs-gateway package.

Is there still a separate gateway package, or is it just cvmfs-server now?

It's still a separate package, but a sub package of the cvmfs package (i.e. it comes all from the same build process).  The sources are under packaging/rpm and packaging/deb.

column21:
I confirm that bizarre behavior happens also with dash installed from epel on centos7.  With gdb it shows the problem is in memcpy:
Program received signal SIGSEGV, Segmentation fault.
0x000000000040dba7 in memcpy (__len=91708, __src=0x7ffff7fb8b08,
    __dest=0x7fffff7f7550) at /usr/include/bits/string3.h:51
warning: Source file is more recent than executable.
51	  return __builtin___memcpy_chk (__dest, __src, __len, __bos0 (__dest));
(gdb) bt
#0  0x000000000040dba7 in memcpy (__len=91708, __src=0x7ffff7fb8b08,
    __dest=0x7fffff7f7550) at /usr/include/bits/string3.h:51
#1  readtoken1 (firstc=<optimized out>, syntax=<optimized out>,
    eofmark=eofmark@entry=0x0, striptabs=striptabs@entry=0) at parser.c:1377
#2  0x000000000040cd0d in xxreadtoken () at parser.c:836
#3  0x000000000040ce42 in xxreadtoken () at parser.c:792
#4  readtoken () at parser.c:714
#5  0x000000000040e3e5 in peektoken () at parser.c:691
#6  list (nlflag=2, nlflag@entry=0) at parser.c:185
#7  0x000000000040e4b6 in command () at parser.c:466
#8  0x000000000040ea9f in simplecmd () at parser.c:567
#9  command () at parser.c:472
#10 0x000000000040ebb3 in pipeline () at parser.c:275
#11 0x000000000040e2da in andor () at parser.c:239
#12 list (nlflag=3, nlflag@entry=1) at parser.c:189
#13 0x000000000040ecda in parsecmd (interact=<optimized out>) at parser.c:158
#14 0x000000000040a981 in cmdloop (top=top@entry=1) at main.c:216
#15 0x000000000040217a in main (argc=2, argv=0x7fffffffdda8) at main.c:174

If I do print (char *) __src I see that it is copying the section that I added in __do_all_checks beginning with repos="$((.  If I put that whole section into a function, it doesn't crash.  I'll make an update with the workaround.

Improvements to error logging and reporting
column20:
Adds an in-memory circular buffer of the last 10 log messages, which can be queried through the logbuffer extended attribute. The attribute is throttled because printing the logbuffer is potentially costly (string copies). A new kLogSensitive flag can be used to hide messages from the log buffer.


Adds the timestamp_last_ioerr extended attribute to report when the most recent i/o failure took place.  That can be used by monitoring to ignore old i/o errors.

Release notes
Sourced from github.com/containerd/containerd's releases.

containerd 1.4.11
Welcome to the v1.4.11 release of containerd!
The eleventh patch release for containerd 1.4 is a security release to fix CVE-2021-41103.
Notable Updates

Fix insufficiently restricted permissions on container root and plugin directories GHSA-c2h3-6mxw-7mvq

See the changelog for complete list of changes
Please try out the release binaries and report any issues at
https://github.com/containerd/containerd/issues.
Contributors

Derek McGowan
Samuel Karp
Phil Estes

Changes


5b46e404f Merge pull request from GHSA-c2h3-6mxw-7mvq
adc279b83 Prepare release notes for v1.4.11
0b1bde385 btrfs: reduce permissions on plugin directories
38532c6ed v1 runtime: reduce permissions for bundle dir
403846c95 v2 runtime: reduce permissions for bundle dir
8a3cfaf33 Merge pull request  #6075 from dmcgowan/1.4-update-test-images
3cd12c7d4 Update test images to use Github package registry


Dependency Changes
This release has no dependency changes
Previous release can be found at v1.4.10
containerd 1.4.10
Welcome to the v1.4.10 release of containerd!
The tenth patch release for containerd 1.4 contains minor fixes and updates
including an updated runc and hcsshim.
Notable Updates

Update runc to v1.0.2 #5899
Update hcsshim to v0.8.21 #5957

Make "inspecting catalog" check message verbose
column20: This is idea 5 from CVM-1524.

column13: Make "inspecting catalog" check message verbose
column20: This is idea 5 from CVM-1524.
column21: Can one of the admins verify this patch?

column13: Make "inspecting catalog" check message verbose
column20: This is idea 5 from CVM-1524.
column21:
But the verbose level is used to print "[path]" too.
If I could separate those two messages to different log levels, I could add a default -l setting by setting CVMFS_LOG_LEVEL if it is not already set to something else, only when invoking __do_check when there's no -a option.  What kLog level should I use for "[inspecting]", what level for "[path]", and what are the -l numbers corresponding to them?

column13: Make "inspecting catalog" check message verbose
column20: This is idea 5 from CVM-1524.
column21: Good point! The messages for [path] would then also need to be lowered to kLogLevel0

column13: Make "inspecting catalog" check message verbose
column20: This is idea 5 from CVM-1524.
column21: I can't get that to work.  If I put in just kLogLevel0 the message never comes out with any setting of CVMFS_LOG_LEVEL 0 to 3.  If I make it look like the definition of kLogVerboseMsg, that is, kLogStdout | kLogShowSource | kLogLevel0 then it behaves just like kLogVerboseMsg, in that it is printed with any value of CVMFS_LOG_LEVEL.  Based on the implementation of '-l' I would expect kLogLevel0 to be a lower level than verbose, not higher, but it isn't behaving at all as I expect it.

column13: Make "inspecting catalog" check message verbose
column20: This is idea 5 from CVM-1524.
column21: Sorry, my bad!  The kLogLevel0 is actually not itself a log level, it is used only as a lower marker.  We need to introduce an additional log level.  I'd suggest to add in logging_internal.h an additional level, e.g. kLogGossipy (feel free to pick a better name), and to shift all following constants by a factor of two.

column13: Make "inspecting catalog" check message verbose
column20: This is idea 5 from CVM-1524.
column21: Ok, I ended up having to do quite a lot for that.  The '-l' options to swissknife were broken, trying to shift the number 1 by a mask level (a power of 2) rather than a number of bits.  I added a kLogInfoMsg alias (with mask kLogInform) between the kLogWarning (kLogNormal) and kLogVerboseMsg (kLogVerbose) levels.  I reversed the order so the log levels increase as people expect, where level 1 corresponds to Warning/Normal, level 2 is Info, and level 3 is Verbose.  I removed kLogDiscrete because it was only used during one test to turn off all log levels, and kLogLevel0 does that now.

column13: Proxy sharding
column20:
Add support for sharding requests across multiple proxies using consistent hashing, controlled via the CVMFS_PROXY_SHARD option in the client configuration.  This allows load to be distributed approximately equally across multiple proxies, with clients independently choosing the same proxy for a given piece of content.
This pull request does not implement bounded loads (as used in e.g. haproxy's hash-type consistent) since there is no obvious way for clients to share knowledge about pending requests, and there is probably limited utility in bounding the per-proxy load generated by a single client acting in isolation.
column21:

This pull request does not implement bounded loads (as used in e.g. haproxy's hash-type consistent) since there is no obvious way for clients to share knowledge about pending requests, and there is probably limited utility in bounding the per-proxy load generated by a single client acting in isolation.

column13: Proxy sharding
column20:
Add support for sharding requests across multiple proxies using consistent hashing, controlled via the CVMFS_PROXY_SHARD option in the client configuration.  This allows load to be distributed approximately equally across multiple proxies, with clients independently choosing the same proxy for a given piece of content.
This pull request does not implement bounded loads (as used in e.g. haproxy's hash-type consistent) since there is no obvious way for clients to share knowledge about pending requests, and there is probably limited utility in bounding the per-proxy load generated by a single client acting in isolation.

column21: @mcb30 Have you done any measurements that demonstrate how much this improves performance?

column13: Proxy sharding
column20:
Add support for sharding requests across multiple proxies using consistent hashing, controlled via the CVMFS_PROXY_SHARD option in the client configuration.  This allows load to be distributed approximately equally across multiple proxies, with clients independently choosing the same proxy for a given piece of content.

column21:
@mcb30 Have you done any measurements that demonstrate how much this improves performance?

Not specifically for this implementation.  The overall approach of using consistent hashing is a very well-known design that improves cache locality when multiple caching proxies are in use, and the overall impact on system performance is going to depend heavily on the cache system design and implementation.
For us, this will be eliminating a separate sharding layer that is currently implemented using haproxy, and the impact will therefore be reduced bandwidth and CPU consumption since traffic does not first need to pass through an haproxy instance before reaching the real caching proxy.
The cost of performing the balanced tree lookup on each request is negligible in comparison to any download time, and so I would not expect to be able to measure any impact from this extra code path.  The (re)construction of the balanced tree happens only in the event of a proxy configuration change or proxy failure, which is sufficiently rare to make the cost also negligible.
Did you have a specific concern, or was it just general curiosity about the performance improvement?

column13: Proxy sharding

Add support for sharding requests across multiple proxies using consistent hashing, controlled via the CVMFS_PROXY_SHARD option in the client configuration.  This allows load to be distributed approximately equally across multiple proxies, with clients independently choosing the same proxy for a given piece of content.
This pull request does not implement bounded loads (as used in e.g. haproxy's hash-type consistent) since there is no obvious way for clients to share knowledge about pending requests, and there is probably limited utility in bounding the per-proxy load generated by a single client acting in isolation.
column21: I was just wondering if it was really worth the added complexity.   My own sense has been that the cache hit rates in our applications are typically so high that added delays from downloading the same object to a few more caches is negligible.  We also usually have plenty of disk space on the caches -- not a lot of space is needed -- so I don't see much benefit from the cache space savings.

column21:
I was just wondering if it was really worth the added complexity.

Most of the PR deals with cleaning up the existing code, and I'd suggest merging it even without the ability to shard across multiple proxies.  The extra code that implements the sharding logic is isolated to about 20 lines of code in UpdateProxiesUnlocked(): I've deliberately kept it clean and simple.

My own sense has been that the cache hit rates in our applications are typically so high that added delays from downloading the same object to a few more caches is negligible. We also usually have plenty of disk space on the caches -- not a lot of space is needed -- so I don't see much benefit from the cache space savings.

We definitely need the sharding with the size of data sets that we use, which is why we currently have the haproxy front end.

column21:
I was just wondering if it was really worth the added complexity. My own sense has been that the cache hit rates in our applications are typically so high that added delays from downloading the same object to a few more caches is negligible. We also usually have plenty of disk space on the caches -- not a lot of space is needed -- so I don't see much benefit from the cache space savings.

I see the benefit for software in improved cold-cache behavior, as it is enough to populate one of the possibly many caches with a new object. The space savings are relevant more for conditions data than for software.

Release notes
Sourced from github.com/containerd/containerd's releases.

containerd 1.4.12
Welcome to the v1.4.12 release of containerd!
The twelfth patch release for containerd 1.4 contains a few minor bug fixes
and an update to mitigate CVE-2021-41190.
Notable Updates

Handle ambiguous OCI manifest parsing (GHSA-5j5w-g665-5m35)
Update pull to try next mirror for non-404 errors (#5275)
Update pull to handle of non-https urls in descriptors (#6221)

See the changelog for complete list of changes
Please try out the release binaries and report any issues at
https://github.com/containerd/containerd/issues.
Contributors

Derek McGowan
Maksym Pavlenko
Samuel Karp
Sebastiaan van Stijn
Kohei Tokunaga
Phil Estes

containerd 1.4.12
Welcome to the v1.4.12 release of containerd!
The twelfth patch release for containerd 1.4 contains a few minor bug fixes
and an update to mitigate CVE-2021-41190.
Notable Updates

Handle ambiguous OCI manifest parsing (GHSA-5j5w-g665-5m35)
Update pull to try next mirror for non-404 errors (#5275)
Update pull to handle of non-https urls in descriptors (#6221)

See the changelog for complete list of changes
Please try out the release binaries and report any issues at
https://github.com/containerd/containerd/issues.

cvmfs-release.deb: fallback to focal 20.04 if >= 20
column20:
Instead of falling back to bionic 18.04, we can fall back to the supported focal 20.04 version when version_major >= 20. This avoids behavior on 21.04, 21.10 where fallback to 18.04 packages is done:
16:31:19 wdconinc@menelaos /tmp $ sudo dpkg -i cvmfs-release-latest_all.deb 
(Reading database ... 351038 files and directories currently installed.)
Preparing to unpack cvmfs-release-latest_all.deb ...
Unpacking cvmfs-release (3.3-1) over (3.2-1) ...
Setting up cvmfs-release (3.3-1) ...
Warning: this distribution is not supported. Using Ubuntu 18.04 packages as fallback.

column21:
This seems to be breaking the RPM builds for EL8:
+ /usr/lib/rpm/redhat/brp-mangle-shebangs
*** WARNING: ./usr/libexec/cvmfs/shrinkwrap/spec_builder.py is executable but has no shebang, removing executable bit
*** WARNING: ./usr/libexec/cvmfs/ducc/registry-webhook.py is executable but has no shebang, removing executable bit
*** ERROR: ambiguous python shebang in /var/www/wsgi-scripts/cvmfs-server/cvmfs-api.wsgi: #!/usr/bin/env python. Change it to python3 (or python2) explicitly.
error: Bad exit status from /home/sftnight/jenkins/workspace/CvmfsFullBuildDocker/CVMFS_BUILD_ARCH/docker-x86_64/CVMFS_BUILD_PLATFORM/cc8/build/TMP/rpm-tmp.WGart7 (%install)
    Bad exit status from /home/sftnight/jenkins/workspace/CvmfsFullBuildDocker/CVMFS_BUILD_ARCH/docker-x86_64/CVMFS_BUILD_PLATFORM/cc8/build/TMP/rpm-tmp.WGart7 (%install)

column13: Update geo api for python3
column20: See CVM-2052
column21: Ok I'll change it to python3 just to make rpmbuild happy, although it's really not relevant since python3-mod_wsgi starts python itself and ignores the shebang.

column13: Update geo api for python3
column20: See CVM-2052

column13: Update geo api for python3
column20: See CVM-2052
column21: @DrDaveD @radupopescu I think we also need to update the package sources to depend on python 3.

column13: Update geo api for python3
column20: See CVM-2052
column21: That might separately be a good thing but I don't believe it is necessary because as I said the .wsgi file in cvmfs does not end up executing python, it is the python3-mod_wsgi module that does it.  I'm pretty sure that is the default mod_wsgi in el8, and at run time cvmfs-server requires mod_wsgi.  I have evidence that somebody who tried to run the geo api on an el8 machine had errors because python3 had tried to execute it.

column13: Update geo api for python3
column20: See CVM-2052
column21: Ok, that makes sense. No need then to edit the package sources. Thanks for the clarification!

column13: Remove open-coded access to RepositoryTag private fields
column20:
Make the RepositoryTag "name_", "channel_", and "description_" fields
private, as implied by the trailing underscores.
Move the logic for constructing a generic timestamp-based tag name
from CommitProcessor::Commit() to RepositoryTag::SetGenericName(), to
allow for a single centralised implementation of this logic once
cvmfs_server_ingest.sh and cvmfs_server_publish.sh are ported to C++
code using the Publisher model.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

Make the RepositoryTag "name_", "channel_", and "description_" fields
private, as implied by the trailing underscores.
Move the logic for constructing a generic timestamp-based tag name
from CommitProcessor::Commit() to RepositoryTag::SetGenericName(), to
allow for a single centralised implementation of this logic once
cvmfs_server_ingest.sh and cvmfs_server_publish.sh are ported to C++
code using the Publisher model.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Spelling: docs and comments
column20:
This PR corrects misspellings identified by the check-spelling action.
The misspellings have been reported at jsoref@b81da4e#commitcomment-61970638
The action reports that the changes in this PR would make it happy: jsoref@6911cc0
Note: this PR does not include the action. If you're interested in running a spell check on every PR and push, that can be offered separately.

If you need things split, dropped, or squashed, just let me know, it isn't a big deal.
Note that one typo was identified by this tool and I sent a PR to remove it entirely.
I've tried to preserve whitespace indentation (including some trailing whitespace, which my editors hate).
I will try to call out a bunch of things (it'll take time).

column13: Clean up server lock file handling
column20:
The Publisher model is largely transliterated directly from the original shell scripts.  This leads to C++ code that is procedural in nature and difficult to follow, and prevents the use of object-oriented programming techniques such as RAII.
As a first step towards updating the Publisher to a full object-oriented model, clean up the handling of the server lock files:

Use an object model to represent a server lock file
Separate the logically distinct lock files and flag files
Clean up method names to more closely approximate C++11 standard library equivalents
Implement and use an RAII lock guard to hold a server lock file
Reimplement server lock files as regular POSIX lock files (as per the existing TODO comment)
Remove duplicated and redundant code

Commits have been structured for easy review.  Please retain the individual commits when merging this PR.

column20:
Commit d5fbe10 ("Allow nested catalog to be swapped even if already
attached") neglected to update the unit tests to match the new
functionality, in which SwapNestedCatalog() should fail for an
already-attached nested catalog only if the catalog has been modified.
Fix the unit test to match the intended behaviour as described in the
commit.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Fix broken unit test T_CatalogMgrRw.SwapNestedCatalogFailSlow
column20:
Commit d5fbe10 ("Allow nested catalog to be swapped even if already
attached") neglected to update the unit tests to match the new
functionality, in which SwapNestedCatalog() should fail for an
already-attached nested catalog only if the catalog has been modified.
Fix the unit test to match the intended behaviour as described in the
commit.
Signed-off-by: Michael Brown mbrown@fensystems.co.uk

column13: Remove concept of channels
column20:
The concept of a numeric update channel predates the introduction of named branches.  It is obsolete and unsupported: the command-line tools provide no sensible way to handle channels, and there is no way to configure a client to track a particular channel in its mountpoint.
Simplify the code by removing the entire concept of channels.  The "channel" column is left in the database to avoid potentially destroying existing metadata, since current versions of the code do allow a channel to be specified (even though the code does not allow a channel to be used in any meaningful way).

column21:
Looks good to me.
This changes the internal API between the server tools and the gateway, so both components should be deployed at once.

Is it worth keeping the API unchanged to avoid this problem? We could have the newer version always provide a channel value of zero, and ignore any received channel value.
More generally: how does the project aim to handle this class of API change?

column13: Remove concept of channels
column20:
The concept of a numeric update channel predates the introduction of named branches.  It is obsolete and unsupported: the command-line tools provide no sensible way to handle channels, and there is no way to configure a client to track a particular channel in its mountpoint.

column21:
Looks good to me.
This changes the internal API between the server tools and the gateway, so both components should be deployed at once.

Is it worth keeping the API unchanged to avoid this problem? We could have the newer version always provide a channel value of zero, and ignore any received channel value.
More generally: how does the project aim to handle this class of API change?

I'm not sure it would be worth it in this case, since we are discussing an internal API change. The API between the client and the server should be handled differently, maintaining backward compatibility - in our community, the server components are upgraded at a different rate than client components.

For this PR, what do you think about sending 0 as a channel from the remote publisher to the gateway (like it's done with the database) and ignoring the value on the gateway side?

Sounds good to me.  I've force-pushed an update that:

Applies an expanded version of your suggested comment for the BindInt64(5, 0)
Sends 0 as channel to the gateway, with a similar comment
Rebases on current devel

Will create the corresponding docs PR once this one is merged and final.

column13: Add possibility to hide magic xattr for root node only
column20: Instead of the binary CVMFS_HIDE_MAGIC_XATTRS=[yes|no], the new CVMFS_MAGIC_XATTRS_VISIBILITY=[never,always,rootonly] option allows for more fine grained control.  The new option, if present, takes precedent.

column20: Follow up to #2842

column13: Gateway backend refactoring
column20:
Removes BoltDB, keep only SQLite as storage backend
Reduces the number of external dependencies
Refactor lease tokens (remove JWT)
Improves alg complexity of conflicting lease checks
Separate data access layer (entities) from business logic (services)

containerd 1.4.13
Welcome to the v1.4.13 release of containerd!
The thirteenth patch release for containerd 1.4 is a security release to address
CVE-2022-23648.
Notable Updates

Use fs.RootPath when mounting volumes (GHSA-crp2-qrr5-8pq7)

See the changelog for complete list of changes
Please try out the release binaries and report any issues at
https://github.com/containerd/containerd/issues.

Kazuyoshi Kato
Michael Crosby

Changelog
Sourced from github.com/containerd/containerd's changelog.

Versioning and Release
This document details the versioning and release plan for containerd. Stability
is a top goal for this project and we hope that this document and the processes
it entails will help to achieve that. It covers the release process, versioning
numbering, backporting, API stability and support horizons.
If you rely on containerd, it would be good to spend time understanding the
areas of the API that are and are not supported and how they impact your
project in the future.
This document will be considered a living document. Supported timelines,
backport targets and API stability guarantees will be updated here as they
change.
If there is something that you require or this document leaves out, please
reach out by filing an issue.
Releases
Releases of containerd will be versioned using dotted triples, similar to
Semantic Version. For the purposes of this document, we
will refer to the respective components of this triple as
<major>.<minor>.<patch>. The version number may have additional information,
such as alpha, beta and release candidate qualifications. Such releases will be
considered "pre-releases".
Major and Minor Releases
Major and minor releases of containerd will be made from main. Releases of
containerd will be marked with GPG signed tags and announced at
https://github.com/containerd/containerd/releases. The tag will be of the
format v<major>.<minor>.<patch> and should be made with the command git tag -s v<major>.<minor>.<patch>.
After a minor release, a branch will be created, with the format
release/<major>.<minor> from the minor tag. All further patch releases will
be done from that branch. For example, once we release v1.0.0, a branch
release/1.0 will be created from that tag. All future patch releases will be
done against that branch.
Pre-releases
Pre-releases, such as alphas, betas and release candidates will be conducted
from their source branch. For major and minor releases, these releases will be
done from main. For patch releases, these pre-releases should be done within
the corresponding release branch.
While pre-releases are done to assist in the stabilization process, no
guarantees are provided.


... (truncated)

Changelog
Sourced from github.com/containerd/containerd's changelog.

Versioning and Release
This document details the versioning and release plan for containerd. Stability
is a top goal for this project and we hope that this document and the processes
it entails will help to achieve that. It covers the release process, versioning
numbering, backporting, API stability and support horizons.
If you rely on containerd, it would be good to spend time understanding the
areas of the API that are and are not supported and how they impact your
project in the future.
This document will be considered a living document. Supported timelines,
backport targets and API stability guarantees will be updated here as they
change.
If there is something that you require or this document leaves out, please
reach out by filing an issue.
Releases
Releases of containerd will be versioned using dotted triples, similar to
Semantic Version. For the purposes of this document, we
will refer to the respective components of this triple as
<major>.<minor>.<patch>. The version number may have additional information,
such as alpha, beta and release candidate qualifications. Such releases will be
considered "pre-releases".
Major and Minor Releases
Major and minor releases of containerd will be made from main. Releases of
containerd will be marked with GPG signed tags and announced at
https://github.com/containerd/containerd/releases. The tag will be of the
format v<major>.<minor>.<patch> and should be made with the command git tag -s v<major>.<minor>.<patch>.
After a minor release, a branch will be created, with the format
release/<major>.<minor> from the minor tag. All further patch releases will
be done from that branch. For example, once we release v1.0.0, a branch
release/1.0 will be created from that tag. All future patch releases will be
done against that branch.
Pre-releases
Pre-releases, such as alphas, betas and release candidates will be conducted
from their source branch. For major and minor releases, these releases will be
done from main. For patch releases, these pre-releases should be done within
the corresponding release branch.
While pre-releases are done to assist in the stabilization process, no
guarantees are provided.

column13: Optionally adding extra information to meta.json.
column20:
This patch seeks to add some useful system information to the meta.json file for logging and monitoring. This feature is optional.

Adds the following fields to meta.json:

cvmfs_version : version_string
os_version : $(lsb_release -d | cut -f2)


Can be disabled by setting PUBLISH_VERSIONS_IN_META_FILE to anything but "true".

column13: Optionally adding extra information to meta.json.
column20:
This patch seeks to add some useful system information to the meta.json file for logging and monitoring. This feature is optional.

Adds the following fields to meta.json:

cvmfs_version : version_string
os_version : $(lsb_release -d | cut -f2)


Can be disabled by setting PUBLISH_VERSIONS_IN_META_FILE to anything but "true".
column21:
Is this expected or something I've messed up?

That may be a problem due to the patch. Possibly just an issue with the test itself. We'd need to look into it, it may take a few days until I get to it.

column13: Track page cache state
column20:
Adds a new page cache tracker to the data structures that track the state of the kernel caches. The page cache tracker is only used if the mount point is not in NFS mode and if it is not hotpatched from a previous version without one.
The page cache tracker remembers the content hash of the data that are in the page cache for a given inode. This allows us to make an informed decision on whether or not to flush the page cache and when to use direct I/O (if the inode has open files with a different content hash). The page cache tracker evicts entries if the corresponding inode receives a fuse FORGET message.  Still to be verified if the FORGET message is coupled to the page cache (and not just to the dentry cache).

 Add counters for total number of files opened with cache (1), without cache (2), with direct i/o (3)
 Add integration test
 Confirm that removing from the tracker on FORGET is correct
 Respect "direct i/o" flag in the file catalogs
 Possibly: take only single lock on inode tracker and page cache tracker in FORGET_MULTI

Fixes #2879

column13: commitprocessor performance: remove ShortString counters
column20:
In profiling the commit processor critical path, we observed that a substantial amount of time in AbstractCatalogManager::MountSubtree->ShortString::ShortString.  Approx half of the time spent in this constructor is in the atomic_inc64() of num_instances_.
In our environment, we don't use the num_instances or num_overflows statistics for ShortString derived objects, so this PR removes them.
It might, perhaps, be more elegant to make these counters configurable, so they can be disabled only where required.
12.68% 0.76% cvmfs_receiver cvmfs_receiver
11.93% catalog::AbstractCatalogManager<catalog: : Catalog>: :MountSubtree
- 6.31% ShortString<(unsigned char)200, (char)0>::ShortString 2.53% ShortString<(unsigned char) 200, (char)0>:: Assign 2.44% atomic_inc64
0.59% ShortString<(unsigned char)200, (char)0>::GetLength
2.64% ShortString<(unsigned char) 200, (char)0>:: Append
1.11% ShortString<(unsigned char)200, (char)0>::GetLength
1.01% ShortString<(unsigned char)200, (char)0>:: StartsWith
+0.76% libc_start_main
[.] catalog::AbstractCatalogManager<catalog::Catalog>:: MountSubtree

column13: commitprocessor performance: remove ShortString counters
column20:
In profiling the commit processor critical path, we observed that a substantial amount of time in AbstractCatalogManager::MountSubtree->ShortString::ShortString.  Approx half of the time spent in this constructor is in the atomic_inc64() of num_instances_.
In our environment, we don't use the num_instances or num_overflows statistics for ShortString derived objects, so this PR removes them.
It might, perhaps, be more elegant to make these counters configurable, so they can be disabled only where required.

column13: commitprocessor performance: truncate instead of re-initializing PathString in DiffRec
column20:
The DiffRec function is the main function to compare the new and old catalogs. Inside this function, it compares the old and new entry and create PathStrings in each iteration of the loop. This is quite inefficient because each time it does a memcpy (ShortString::Assign) to initialize old_path and new_path from path. This gets worse as you traverse down the directory tree because the path gets longer.
This PR adds a Truncate function to ShortString which allows us to simply reduce the length of old_path and new_path and append the entry name, instead of re-initializing it from path.

column13: Make open fd checks on publisher mount optional

column13: unconditionally compress catalogs irrespective of `CVMFS_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHM` setting
column20:
If the publisher has CVMFS_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHM=none  then it will upload catalog objects in uncompressed form. But the cvmfs client always expects these to be compressed, irrespective of any CVMFS_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHM setting it may have.
The PR causes the publisher to unconditionally compress catalog objects irrespective of CVMFS_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHM
column21:

The PR causes the publisher to unconditionally compress catalog objects irrespective of CVMFS_COMPRESSION_ALGORITHM

column13: Restrict access to xattrs containing secrets; configure acl with CVMFS_PRIVILEGED_XATTR_GID
column20:
Some extended attributes may contain secrets (eg URLs containing basic auth credentials).
This PR:

restricts Proxy and Host extended attributes to root and other authorised groups
Adds the configuration option CVMFS_PRIVILEGED_XATTR_GID for specifying a comma-separated list of groupnames to be allowed access to sensitive xattrs
Extends  Xattr class's PrepareValueFenced() to allow gating of access based on uid, gid, and pid.

column13: Compile-time configuration of cvmfs_suid_helper's use of systemd
column20:
We have observed that systemd's autogenerated mount units can fail, with the result that an in-progress cvmfs_server publish will complete but error on the terminal remount.
This problem usually after a configuration management tool has run and made changes to the systemd configuration, while a  publication transaction is open.
This PR adds a cmake option to make the cvmfs_suid_helper's use of systemd compile-time configurable

This PR adds a cmake option to make the cvmfs_suid_helper's use of systemd compile-time configurable

column20:

column21: Is it possible for zlib-ng to be used in a compatible way?  That would be preferable to a compile time option.  Can it be configured to generate compressions that standard zlib can decode?  That would be the best, and then make that the default.  The next best thing would be to link with both libraries, have the client automatically detect which one is used, and have the publisher have a runtime non-default configuration option to choose the new library.

column21: https://github.com/zlib-ng/zlib-ng/blob/develop/PORTING.md says there's a zlib-compat mode; have you tried to see if that gives you sufficient speedup?  If not, it looks like zlib-ng native mode allows coexisting with zlib in the same application.

Ref: #2917
column21:
We use the zlib-compat mode, that enables wrapper functions that make zlib-ng a drop-in replacement for zlib, at the API level.
zlib-ng compressed data will always be decompressible by a standard zlib.
I don't know if there's any guarantee that zlib-ng will ever produce compressed results that are bitwise identical to zlib's.
We use zlib-ng on the client side as well as publisher, as it helps reduce latency on catalog load.

column13: zlib-ng as compile-time option with -DBUILD_ZLIB_NG=ON
column20:
Adds zlib-ng-2.0.6, optionally build and used in place of zlib-1.2.8 if -DBUILD_ZLIB_NG=ON is specified
Ref: #2917
column21: That sounds good.  It sounds like it should be the default then, not an option.

column20: set -DENABLE_ZLIB_BEST_SPEED=ON to set compression level to Z_BEST_SPEED, otherwise retain default of Z_DEFAULT_COMPRESSION

column13: Ducc: increase reliability during downloading images from repositories
column20:
increase reliability during downloading images from repositories. It has two primary changes:
It makes a probing request to determine if authentication is necessary (it is not for public images on quay) and continues without an auth token in that case. In the original branch, it necessarily needs an auth token.
The other change is implementing range requests for the layers along with a fail-retry logic. This is particularly helpful since we have firewalls which often block packets and can interrupt downloads (from external registries like docker hub)

column13: Gateway enhancements: kafka notifcations, telegraph telemetry, cache invalidation
column20:
Gateway enhancements:

Kafka notifications:

On publication event, publish a message to specified kafka topic. Used in conjunction with #2942

Telegraf telemetry
On publication event, emit event to configured telegraf collector. Metric sent is configured in telegraf->line, eg

cvmfs_publication,repository=REPOSITORY,revision=REVISION published=1 TIME

with substitutions made for the REPOSITORY, REVISION, TIME tokens

cache invalidation for .cvmfspublished objects. After publication, and before kafka notification, gateway will pull a list of HTTP cache hostnames from http-proxy->proxy_lookup (Json-encoded list of strings). It then makes a Cache-Control: no-cache request to a URL synthesised from http-proxy->url + /.cvmfspublished  + basic auth credentials taken from http-proxy->'username|password`

containerd 1.5.13
Welcome to the v1.5.13 release of containerd!
The thirteenth patch release for containerd 1.5 includes a fix for
CVE-2022-31030.
Notable Updates

Fix ExecSync handler to cap console output size (GHSA-5ffw-gxpp-mxpf)

See the changelog for complete list of changes
Please try out the release binaries and report any issues at
https://github.com/containerd/containerd/issues.
Contributors

Derek McGowan
Kazuyoshi Kato

Changes


Github Security Advisory GHSA-5ffw-gxpp-mxpf

1ab043141 Prepare release notes for v1.5.13
b40a356cf Implicitly discard the input to drain the reader
943588b54 [release/1.5] Limit the response size of ExecSync




Dependency Changes
This release has no dependency changes
Previous release can be found at v1.5.12
containerd 1.5.12
Welcome to the v1.5.12 release of containerd!
The twelfth patch release for containerd 1.5 includes various fixes and updates
along with an updated version of runc.
Notable Updates

Fix inotify fd leak when cgroup is deleted (#6961)
Close fifos when container is deleted in CRI plugin (#6857)
Update unpack to to respect MaxConcurrentDownloads (#6774)
Monitor OOMKill instead of OOM in cgroupv2 (#6735)
Make the temp mount as ready only in container WithVolumes (#6729)
